story:
Vertical Aerial Arts was founded in early 2012 by Jennifer Kovacs and Megan Hornaday. Primarily working as an aerial duo, VAA is known for their unique aerial apparatus and creating elegant and modern circus art. Recently, VAA were the featured aerialists at Ultra Music Festival in Miami and on NBC daytime television. 

This December, VAA is putting on their second annual Christmas production, The Nutcracker Circus Suite, which takes the classical tale of the Nutcracker and tells it through circus, theater, dance, modern music, and audience interaction. The action happens around and above the audience. 

We are seeking funding to pay our cast members and help with production costs. Production of a full length show adds up; rehearsal fees, costumes, props, theater rental, and marketing are just a few of the expenses that we will be paying out of pocket. We have an amazing cast on board and our main goal is to pay them as much as we possibly can. All proceeds of our campaign will go towards paying our cast members. 

We have a cast of 15 amazing artists who make a living as performance artists. Our cast has generously agreed to take on our low budget production. Our fundraising goal of $5000 will ensure that each of them is paid at least $300 for the run of our show. That breaks down to $75 a show. It is not much money, considering the the hours of rehearsal and time they have committed to this project, but it is a start. The more we can raise, the better! By donating to our campaign you will be helping VAA create a magical Christmas experience. 

We appreciate any help that you can offer! Please help to spread the word among your friends!

Best,

Megan and Jen

Vertical Aerial Arts

story:
Our Story

A Mile In My Shoes, Inc. (AMIMS) is a fiscally-sponsored arts organization founded in 2005 by composer, lyricist, and playwright Germono Toussaint. Our mission is to use the arts as a platform to address a diverse array of modern social issues, increasing the awareness of the societal impact of these issues. By creating events focused on these issues, audiences are motivated to action.

 

We will launch our 2012 Season with the First Annual Real Love Concert, which will bring together poets, singers and musicians in a two-act, catered extravaganza. In-between acts, we will show video clips of notable personalities stressing the value and importance of self-love and self-acceptance.


What is ï¿½realï¿½ love?

It is our strong belief that ï¿½realï¿½ love cannot have its foundation outside of us, but rather it must come from within. Many spend their lives searching for someone to celebrate them, someone to value them, or someone to tell them theyï¿½re beautiful. We believe it is imperative that these messages come from the most important person in our livesï¿½ourselves.

 

Why a concert about self-love?

AMIMS is launching its season with the First Annual Real Love Concert because we believe many of the social issues highlighted throughout our season would be remedied if self-love, self-respect and a positive self-image were engrained into the psyche of every human being. We believe that these fundamental ideals are central to the betterment of society. We will share the message that, regardless of what society tells us, we must think of ourselves as beautifully, wonderfully-made human beings. This February, we are celebrating the beauty of our uniqueness and individuality, and embracing real love by loving ourselves first.


What We Need & What You Get

Any size donation will help offset the costs and turn our vision into a reality. We are a start-up arts organization which is looking for $10,000 in order to fully realize the vision for this project. Some costs of producing The First Annual Real Love Concert include: securing a venue in New York City, booking performers, and renting audio and video equipment. Your support would be greatly appreciated. Also, there are perks for donating!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends or anyone you know who would be interested. You can easily share  with friends on LinkedIn, Twitter or Facebook through the links!

Also, if you know an organization or person that would be interested in working with us, we would love to hear from you!

 

Thank you for supporting Real Love!

 

 ...and remember to tell your friends: "Go Love Yourself!"

story:
Carlotta is searching.  For her lost luggage.  For a final end to her marriage.  And for her connection to Teresa, a 14th century nun.  She is not prepared for who she becomes after discovering TERESA'S ECSTASY.


Avila Productions, LLC by special arrangement with The Cherry Lane Theatre, presents the world premiere of Begonya Plazaâ€™s TERESAâ€™S ECSTASY â€“ directed by Will Pomerantz and starring Shawn Elliott, Linda Larkin and Begonya Plaza. Preview performances will begin March 4, prior to an official opening on March 14 at The Cherry Lane Theatre (38 Commerce Street) in NYC. We invite you to join the team in producing this battle of the sexes and bringing our play to life â€“ Off-Broadway in NYC.


In May 2011, INTAR Theater gave us the opportunity to workshop TERESA'S ECSTASY over the course of 29 hours. After its public showing, esteemed theater producer and angel, Jack Sharkey, saw its possibilities and agreed to sponsor half of the budget to mount it Off-Broadway. From there, Eduardo Machado, founder of INTAR, offered to help place this play in the historical Cherry Lane Theatre. Finally, the amazing director Will Pomerantz came on board to direct its premiere.


We are thrilled to be able to offer you, our donors, the chance to become a part of the production team to bring the story of TERESA'S ECSTASY to the stage. With your help, we will be able to pay our cast and crew, commission a painter to create original work specifically for this play, work with award-winning Catalan composer Albert Carbonell, who will write original music, purchase materials for costumes and the set, and, best of all, to share this humorous, sexy, and smart play with NYC audiences.


As you will see, we are offering several categories of giving: everything from a production poster signed by the cast and crew, to tickets for opening night and the following reception, to a copy of the musical score by Albert Carbonell and a tour of the historic Cherry Lane Theatre.  We cannot do this show without your help, so please donate. Team Ecstasy is deeply grateful to each and every one of you!


TERESA'S ECSTASY will challenge the audience's beliefs in politics, religion, sexuality, and what it means to connect to other human beings. The viewing experience will be one of laughter, fun, and sorrow.


Tickets $60. For reservations, call OvationTix at 212-352-3101.


or Buy Tickets Online.


The schedule is as follows: Tuesdays @ 7 PM, Wednesdays-Saturdays @ 8 and Sundays @ 2 PM. Please note the following exceptions: Sunday, March 4 and Sunday, March 11 performances are at 7 PM, with no matinee shows. There will be one Monday performance at 7 PM on the 12th but there is no performance on Sunday, March 18. 


Begonya Plaza: Playwright


Ms. Plaza studied writing at NYU, AFI and UCLA extension courses while working professionally as an actress. She wrote THE PERSISTENCE OF MEMORY, a screenplay about one year in the life of Salvador DalÃ­ and his muse, Gala, seen from the eyes of a young lover. Glenn Close has signed a letter or interest to play the role of Gala. She wrote, directed and edited SOUVENIR VIEWS, a 24-minute documentary shot in New York and Barcelona with English/Spanish subtitles, about a young man's rite-of-passage journey through New Yorkâ€™s 9/11 tragedy. SOUVENIR VIEWS premiered at the 2003 Tribeca Film Festival, the Festival International del Nuevo Cine Latinoamericano, and aired nationally on the Independent Film Channel. She wrote, directed, and acted in AMERICAN HERO, a 15-minute short film. AMERICAN HERO is a contemplation on the ravages of war as an Iraqi Veteran returns home and tries to regain a sense of self, with the help of his sister. TALK SHOW is a play in which historical characters Evita PerÃ³n, SimÃ³n Bolivar, Dolores Ibarruri, and Antonio MachÃ­n are interviewed in a live, talk-show setting by God. GERNIKA LIVES is a 45-minute personal documentary, narrated by John Randolph, in which Ms. Plaza explores her Basque heritage and the tragic events her father experienced as a young boy during the bombing of Guernica and the Spanish Civil War. 


Read more.


William Pomerantz: Director


Mr. Pomerantz has directed and developed new plays with theatres such as Playwrights Horizons, The Public Theatre, Hartford Stage, New York Theater Workshop, Ensemble Studio Theater, Soho Rep, Culture Project (Director-in-Residence), The Signature Theatre (Washington, DC), The Williamstown Theatre Festival, The Studio Theatre, The Mark Taper Forum and The Guthrie. He has directed world premieres by such playwrights as John Guare, David Auburn, Neil LaBute, Craig Lucas, Kia Corthron, David Lindsay-Abaire, Stephen Belber, Noah Haidle, Linda Cho, Kira Obolensky, and Carey Perloff . In addition to his work on new plays, Mr. Pomerantz has also directed texts by Chekhov, Ibsen, Strindberg, Shakespeare, Shaw and Sophocles. Mr. Pomerantz is proud to be associated with Epic Theatre Ensemble, where he is Associate Director for Artistic Development. For the company, he has directed the New York premiere of Howard Barkerâ€™s A HARD HEART, starring Kathleen Chalfant, and the world premiere of MAHIDAâ€™S EXTRA KEY TO HEAVEN, by Russell Davis.


Jack Sharkey: Executive Producer


Mr. Sharkey is a producer and benefactor for theater, film and music projects.  A great supporter of the solo form, Jackâ€™s theater credits include Nilaja Sun's celebrated tour-de-force NO CHILD...(Epic Theatre Ensemble, Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Dublin Theatre Festival). Other theater credits include Donnetta Lavinia Grays' THE NEW NORMAL (Coyote REP Theatre) and James Carter's FEEDER: A LOVE STORY (terraNOVA Collective), Anika Larsen's SHAFRIKA, THE WHITE GIRL (Jaradoa Theater) and Rock Wilk's BROKE WIDE OPEN (Unplugged National Tour). Music projects include Julie Foldesiâ€™s Debut CD "This Part of Town", Julie Reiberâ€™s Debut CD "Love Travels", Becca Ayersâ€™ "Live at The Laurie Beechman" and "Lovesick", and Lauren Molinaâ€™s music videos GONNA BE ALRIGHT and TRY TO SAY. Film projects include Samantha Buck, Jenny Maguire, and Sophia Raab Downsâ€™ documentary 21 BELOW and Alysia Reinerâ€™s short SPEED GRIEVING.


CAST:


Shawn Elliott: For the stage, Mr. Elliott co-starred on Broadway in the original productions of CITY OF ANGELS, MARIE CHRISTINE and JACQUES BREL IS ALIVE AND WELL AND LIVING IN PARIS. His Off-Broadway credits include CYRANO DE BERGERAC, A PARK IN OUR HOUSE, NEW JERUSALEM, and EULOGY FOR A SMALL-TIME THIEF. Regional theater credits include: HAMLET, MAN OF LA MANCHA, ANTIGONE, DON QUIXOTE, DARK RAPTURE, NOTHING SACRED, THE PROMISE, THE TEMPEST, DEATH AND THE MAIDEN and WHOSE AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? Mr. Elliott has appeared in a number of films including the award-winning festival favorite 13 CONVERSATIONS ABOUT ONE THING with Alan Arkin, Matthew McConaughey and John Turturro. Other film work includes DOUBLE TAKE, HURRICANE STREETS, IMPUSE, CAUGHT, DO THE RIGHT THING, THE DEAD POOL, SHORT EYES and CROSSOVER DREAMS. Mr. Elliott can also be seen in two soo-to-be-released films: ARBITRAGE, with Richard Gere, and BROKEN CITY with Mark Walberg, Russell Crowe and Catherine Zeta Jones. His television appearances include the made-for-TV-movies SOMEONE HAD TO BE BENNY (HBO), DEATH IN SMALL DOSES (ABC) and PROMISED A MIRACLE (CBS). He has had recurring roles on several series, including NBCâ€™s LAW & ORDER, THE DAYS AND NIGHTS OF MOLLY DODD (Lifetime), and the award-winning PBS show GHOSTWRITER. In addition, he has guest starred on many shows including CSI MIAMI (CBS), AMERICAN FAMILY (PBS), 100 CENTRE ST. (A & E), THE COSBY SHOW (NBC) and MIAMI VICE (NBC). In addition to his early solo recordings, he can be heard on the original cast recordings of JACQUES BREL IS ALIVE AND WELL AND LIVING IN PARIS, CITY OF ANGELS, and MARIE CHRISTINE. In 2000, Mr. Elliott was awarded the Rita Moreno Award for Excellence by the Hispanic Organization of Latin Artists (HOLA). Shawn is married to two-time Tony Award-winner Donna Murphy. He is a lifetime member of the Actorâ€™s Studio.


Linda Larkin: Ms. Larkin is the voice of Princess Jasmine in Walt Disneyâ€™s ALADDIN, as well as THE RETURN OF JAFAR, ALADDIN AND THE KING OF THIEVES, and the Emmy-nominated ALADDIN television series. Ms. Larkin has appeared in numerous plays, movies, and television series, most notably as Poppy in NOISES OFF (Alley Theatre), Dierdre in I HATE HAMLET (Actors Theatre of Louisville), Violet in NOTES FROM THE CONFEDERACY (Cherry Lane Theatre), Carrie in TWO NINAS (winner, GenArt Film Festival), Ms. Danforth in JOSHUA (Sundance, Fox Searchlight), Kelly in THE NEXT BEST THING (Paramount), and Meredith in the Webby-nominated series PUPPY LOVE. Ms. Larkin is married to Tony-nominated actor, Yul Vazquez.


Begonya Plaza: Ms. Plaza has been directed by Michael Mann, Clint Eastwood, Amy Jones, Oliver Stone, Tim Hunter and Walter Hill. Her stage credits include Philip Seymour Hoffman's IN ARABIA WE'D ALL BE KINGS, Austrian director Kurt Palm's one-woman show of erotic songs and poems by Bertolt Brecht, Yevnegy Lanskoy's YERMA AS YERMA, and IN FRIENDS. Ms. Plaza has acted opposite Robert De Niro, Tom Cruise, Willem Dafoe, Klaus Kinski, Roddy McDowall, and Carol O'Connor, and starred in the CBS series, DARK JUSTICE, shot on location in Barcelona.

story:
Our Story

Alyce Finwall Dance Theater (AFDT) was established in 1999 by artistic director and choreographer, Alyce Finwall.  The mission of AFDT is to blend an unabashed movement language with dramatic expression to create a powerful vehicle for theatrical dance.  Alyce Finwall's choreography has been presented throughout the US and in Europe.

We have been working on "Angel" for the past 4 1/2 months.  The piece premiered at the Garage Theater this past February to sold out and very enthusiastic audiences.  This July we will be performing it at ODC Theater as part of the WERK Collective performances.

"Angel" is a very rigorous 40-minute duet for two incredible dancers/performers, Julia Hollas and Vivian Aragon.  This piece is the third ballet in the "black ballets" trilogy, all of which have the same themes of femininity, isolation, aggression and sexuality.  Influenced by the work of Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s “The Yellow Wallpaper” and Virginia Woolf’s “A Room of Her Own”, “Angel" delves into the surreal and unnerving realm of sexuality and aggressions that pits the audience's glare against the demanding physicality and exposure of the performance. "Angel" is a tightly constructed dance piece that inhabits a dark and mysterious room.

The creation of this piece has been an incredible experience for me, and I can say without doubt, that I couldn't have done it without the candid and intelligent input from Julia and Vivian.

Thank you for reading, thank you for supporting!

Alyce Finwall, Artistic Director

 

What We Need

We would like to raise a minimum of $2000 so we can pay our two amazing dancers who commit their very heart and soul every time they enter a studio to rehearse, or step on stage to perform. Additionally we need money for studio rental and for marketing expenses heading into our July shows at ODC Theater in San Francisco.  Every dollar counts towards this goal!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see our shows, share this campaign with others, friend us on Facebook, buy a super stylish t-shirt at www.afdancetheater.org and/or join our mailing list!

Additionally we need money for studio rental and for marketing expenses heading into our July shows at ODC Theater in San Francisco.  Every dollar counts towards this goal!
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Come see our shows, share this campaign with others, friend us on Facebook, buy a super stylish t-shirt at www.afdancetheater.org and/or join our mailing list!

story:
Our Story

THEATREdART is about to launch what is by far our most daring, challenging, and ambitious season ever and we need your help.  For the past 8 years we have been endeavoring to bring Colorado Springs an alternative view of theatre, and function as “theatre evangelists” bringing those who would normally never consider attending a show in to the fold.   THEATREdART is also committed to producing original work by local writers, producing 9 world premieres since 2003, and producing 2 more in Season 5.

Speaking of Season 5, I have never, in my time as Artistic Director been as excited about a season as I am about Season 5.  We are producing 9, yes NINE shows next season,  and they range from hyper-experimental, to classical, to contemporary, and it might be hubris, but I would go so far as to say we have the most exciting and dangerous season in town. 

---Jonathan Margheim

Artistic Director, THEATREdART

CLICK HERE TO SEE A FULL LISTING OF SEASON 5


Our Mission Statement:

“THEATREdART is dedicated to enriching the arts community in Southern Colorado by staging bold and challenging plays that would otherwise not be seen locally.  Furthermore THEATREdART believes theatre to be a vital and relevant part of the cultural landscape of our region and works diligently to bring a new audience to this vibrant and engaging art form; challenging preconceived notions of what theatre is and can be.  THEATREdART  values diversity in art and all other forms of expression and does not discriminate based on sex, race, age, creed, religion, or sexual-orientation. We continually strive to improve ourselves and the artistic environment of Southern Colorado and will continue to produce theatre that is engaging to us and our audience.”


THEATREdART is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profits arts service organization.  Contributions for the purposes of THEATREdART must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


The Impact

THEATREdART is committed to bringing new, younger audiences in the Pikes Peak region in to the theatre.  By producing shows outside of the “mainstream” locally, and aggressively marketing to the 16-35 demographic, we hope to create a new generation of passionate, engaged theatre audiences and practitioners.  We also endeavor to generate and produce new work, producing new work by local writers, and encouraging new and aspiring writers, actors, designers, and directors to get their feet wet with our annual short-play festival Theatregasm.


What We Need & What You Get

THEATREdART has been a self-sustaining entity for the last five years, we’ve struggled to keep costs down so we can keep our ticket prices low.   With our recent move to our new space, rent, equipment purchases, and renovation costs have all been pretty brutal on our bank account.  As I type this, we have  roughly a $5000 budget shortfall on Season 4.  Any money donated will go towards production budgets, performance rights, and rent.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate? Being starving artists ourselves, we know how you feel.  Help us out without breaking the bank!  

1. Like us on Facebook

2. Tell your friends and family about our campaign using twitter, facebook, and everything else!

3. Come see our shows!

story:
The Route 66 Theatre Company will be producing The Downpour, a play by Caitlin Parrish about old childhood wounds opened up between two adult sisters when one of them announces she’s pregnant. The Downpour, which is funny, heart wrenching, and takes a very personal look at Postpartum Depression & Psychosis, will be running from September 11th through October 8th, and we need your help in getting this play off the ground.

Up to 25% of women experience symptoms of depression or anxiety after childbirth, and Route 66 and the Playwright Caitlin Parrish are honored to use this play as a way to help these mothers recognize they aren’t alone.

In The Downpour, we meet Hazel and Robin, two sisters played by the phenomenal Brenda Barrie (Steppenwolf Theatre Company, The House Theatre) and Caroline Neff (Steep Theatre, Steppenwolf Theatre Company). They suffered childhood abuse at the hands of their mother, who suffered from postpartum psychosis and had no options for treatment or medication. When older sister Robin tells Hazel that she is pregnant, Hazel is terrified of the worst – that the genetic predisposition for this disorder will destroy Robin’s life and take her sister from her just as it did their mother.

Your contributions will ensure that this heartbreaking and hopeful story of mental illness and survival can be enjoyed by Chicago audiences.

Route 66 is an official 501(c)3 Non-Profit organization.  All donations are 100% tax-deductible.

story:
Short Summary

Since 2005, Ross Dance has used jazz, modern and African styles of movement to bring the message of the Gospel to life. Founded by Dwight and Dr. Tecsia Evans, Ross Dance is a non-profit faith-based organization located in Oakland, CA. For 2014 we have been invited by internationally acclaimed leaders and pastors to share our gift of dance at their churches and conferences where thousands of guests from all over the world will be in attendance. If we receive the support we need we will begin our tour on February 20th where we will dance at the Gospel Heritage’s 20th Anniversary Praise and Worship Conference in Atlanta led by Dr. Teresa Hairston. During this event our company will minister work from our repertoire and provide dance accompaniment to some of the latest stars in Gospel music such as Vashawn Mitchell, Hezekiah Walker and Kurt Carr. Ross Dance will then visit Dallas in July to guest dance at the T.D. Jakes’ Potter’s House Dance Conference “Alive.” We will then conclude our summer tour by teaching and dancing at Sabrina McKenzie’s Dancing International Preachers in Los Angeles.

What We Need & What You Get

Ross Dance is a 501©3 Charitable Organization. All donations are tax-deductible. In order for us to launch our National Tour we will need to raise $8,500. These monies will go towards airfare, hotel accommodations and costumes for 4 professional praise dancers.

There are rewards for each level of support and we can’t wait to include you in the Ross Dance Family so we can share the work we are doing with you.  Find the reward that excites you the most and help us launch our National Tour.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to assist us with a contribution here you can still help us by spreading the word. Feel free to share links to this page on your personal Facebook and Twitter accounts. Like the official Ross Dance Company page on Facebook at the link below. The more awareness we can raise the better our chances of meeting our goal. Thank you for your support!

story:
Dancing on the Threshold

You know that sensation when a word is on the tip of your tongue, when an idea is on the edge of memory, when a choice is in the balance?  Then with a sudden rush of intuition, a new thought and a new action surges forward.  

This season Quicksilver Dance, a modern dance company based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, is celebrating these next steps.  We are "On The Threshold of Beginning" - and we welcome you to join us on April 18th & 19th at 8:00 pm for our fourth annual performance at Simmons Hall at MIT!

...where to begin? 

That is a question that we face every time we start a new dance, and beginning can be very daunting.  But for the last couple of months, Artistic Director Mariah Steele (named a "Rising Talent" by the Boston Globe Magazine in April 2013) has been embracing a new tack: we don't have to know where to begin, we just have to begin – and then follow our intuition on how a dance wants to develop. 

New Works, New Processes!

The works being created for the April performance are exploring such approaches to making dance - with breathtaking results!  The show will present several new works: 

  • "The Constant Effort of Beginning" – a product of our fall rehearsal season, this ever-moving poem of interlocking group-rhythms and disjunction evokes the uncertainty of an ever-changing world, and the eternal evolution of community.  
  • For our newest work, we are beginning simply with a title: "On The Threshold of Memory." While the piece started by exploring the hazy world of our earliest memories, its fate is currently unknown... Come be one of the first to see how it develops at the April show!
  • A collaboration with New York City-based video artist Sarah Outhwaite will mix dance and video in a never-before-seen exchange of light and motion.
  • ... and other favorites from Quicksilver's repertoire!

And our work doesn't end after the performance.  We are looking forward to beginning a whole new journey in the summer: for the first time, Quicksilver will be going on an international tour to the Montreal Fringe Festival in June 2014!  

$5,000 Today; Prized Careers Tomorrow

This fundraiser will support nine Quicksilver dancers through three months of development, rehearsal, and performance of "On the Threshold of Beginning." With the goal of $5,000, we will be able to:

  • Pay our dancers $12 per hour for "On the Threshold of Beginning" rehearsals and shows
  • Commission new scores for two dances from Boston-based composer Ryan Edwards 
  • Hire photographer Ganesh Ramashandran to document the performance

Because the same dances will be going on tour to Montreal in June, your contributions to the current rehearsal process will also: 

  • Pre-support our first international tour to the Montreal Fringe Festival in June! (If you are interested in sponsoring the Montreal tour specifically, please contact Mariah at quicksilverdance@gmail.com.)

Quicksilver has a firm commitment to paying dancers for their time.  We believe this commitment enhances the professionalism and artistry of our dancers, and helps us to generate relevant, vibrant work to touch audiences everywhere - and in two years of successful Indiegogo campaigns, we have seen this belief bear fruit!  

Thanks to the sponsorship of Simmons Hall, tickets for this show are FREE, so you can consider your donation as your ticket price.  Every dollar you give is a step toward making dance a viable career for Quicksilver's dancers and supports their passion for the art form. 

And in addition, we have several great perks to thank you for your goodwill: Quicksilver Dance greeting-cards, personalized dance signatures (you can see some of last year's here), a cameo appearance in the show, or a fully commissioned dance-on-film!  Please read the perk descriptions on the right for more details.  Whatever your level of donation, it's a win-win: and we thank you for helping us support dance and dancers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Dance is all about community, and without you, we can't make this work happen.  So if you want to lend a hand beyond donating, here's how:

  • Come to the show on April 18th and 19th! 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word to your contacts!
  • Tell your friends about our work and this campaign!
  • Have ideas? Feel free to email us at any time: quicksilverdance@gmail.com or talk to us in the comments above!

We hope you will be our partner in all of the above.  We can’t thank you enough for your support!

story:
Short Summary

August Theatre Company was founded in Bloomfield Hills during the Spring of 2013. Its ensemble was fully formed shortly after. Originally created for a chance for old highschool friends who missed performing together to have that experience again, the August Theatre Company evolved into a larger non-profit organization that hopes to inspire all people through theater. Their collaberation, love for theater and the dramatic arts, as well as passion for impacting and positively influencing the community have led to the creation of this company. 

Where is your money going?

Please read the list on the right where you can find different perks you will receive in exchange for donating. 

With your kind donations we will be able to pay for:

  • Sets
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Venue Rental (The Congregational Church of Birmingham)
  • Production Rights
  • Publicity Materials
  • Indiegogo fundraiser take-away fee
  • Leftover money will go straight to charity!

The Impact

The money raised from this online campaign will be divided among the production costs listed above. But every dollar that we raise from tickets sales will go directly to The Jed Foundation which promotes emotional health and prevents suicide among college students. Putting on this show will not only help this important cause, but it will help us apply the theatre knowledge that we have learned in college to the real world.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Share this campaign with anyone that might be interested!

    COME SEE RABBIT HOLE July 31st and August 1, 2014 at the Congregational Church of Birmingham at 7:30!


      Thank you for your time, we hope to see you at our show!

story:
Innovations

Innovations is a night where you can help us, Myles Lavallee, Astrit Zejnati, Nayon Iovino, and Tzu-Chia Huang, launch our choreographic careers. Our choreography will change your perception about ballet! We blend classical movements with fearless expressions, vibrant music, and new artistic vision.

See our work live and on the stage at Innovations in The Dorrance Theatre, May 22 through June 1st!

The Pieces of our Piece

Your donations will help us make our dreams, ideas and emotions a reality.

Choreographing a piece doesn't just mean putting steps together, to us, it means giving the audience an experience they will never forget.

"I want to take people on a roller coaster ride and let it be real" - Myles Lavallee

Each of us are creating all new costumes that will help us bring our pieces  and our stories to life.

"My story is simple, I want to capture the music through the phenomena of colors, and my costumes are based on this" - Astrit Zejnati

Music is also a big part of our process, without it we can't show our emotions, without music our pieces wouldn't have meaning.

"The music gave me a picture, I need to have good music first or else I cant see anything." - Tzu-Chia Huang

The Impact

Not only will you be helping us make our dreams come to reality, but you will also be giving us the opportunity to explore a different career path. Our careers as dancers are filled with uncertainty, and can be ended without notice.

Innovations is a way that we can explore another avenue of dance, through choreography. As any career, sometimes getting your foot in the door can be challenging, but Artistic Director Ib Andersen's commitment to dance innovation and encouragement of emerging choreographers helps us find a home to explore and grow.

"After dancing, [choreographing] is something I wanna work towards" - Nayon Iovino

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can help us succeed:

  • Purchase a ticket to our show May 22 - June 1!
  • Help us spread the word by sharing our story!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word to your contacts!

story:
Georgina Leo Melody our artistic director on the festival - check our "Galerie"!!!

WHAT IS BERLIN VOGUING OUT?

Berlin Voguing Out (BVO) is a festival, founded in 2012 in Berlin, Germany and till now an unique meeting platform. We want to connect people from different social and cultural backgrounds, establish voguing in Germany and support the already existing community. The age spectrum of participants and audience ranges from teenagers to seniors. Women, men, hetero- and transsexuals are practising and celebrating together, prejudices are being reduced and the commonalities, unification is moving into focus.

WHAT IS VOGUING?
A dance style, developed in the 1960’s in the Ballroom Scene of Harlem, NYC, that is dominated by homo- and transsexuals and inspired by the fashion magazine Vogue.

THE FESTIVAL

The BVO Festival is for national and international participants including workshops, 

film screenings & lectures, shows, partys and lastly the Voguing Ball, in order to teach, learn and establish historical and more recent forms of the dance. This year our international guests are voguing legends Archie Burnett (USA), Cesar Valentino (USA) & DJ Vjuan Allure (USA).

HIGHLIGHT of the Berlin Voguing Out Festival - THE VOGUING BALL. 

The Voguing Ball is a competition, with the categories "Vogue Performance", "Runway" and BVO special category "pose pour payette" a unique photo contest at the nhow hotel, Berlin. In each category the participants fight for the desired trophies, which are hand made by Archie Burnett and Cesar Valentino. 
The motto of this year’s Ball is JOURNEY TO THE FAR EAST and will integrate influences from the Chinese, Japanese, Indian and Polynesian.

WHAT MAKES THE VOGUING BALL SO SPECIAL? We offer a free space for expression where music, dance, creativity, individuality and mutual respect are a top priority. This provides an ideal foundation for a respectful artistic and personal exchange of participants.

WHATS NEW THIS YEAR? BVO offers a unique presentation platform called 321 FASHION-Watch me serve. An opportunity for design students and graduates, as well as new-comer designers to present their fashions on the runway of The Journey To The Far East Ball 2014.

WE NEED YOU

In order to realize this years Berlin Voguing Out Festival - we need your help!!! Support the very mixed COMMUNITY, help us to offer a stage for ARTISTS, DANCERS and DESIGNERS and EVERYONE who is willing to walk a runway and be a part of the scene - every donation is important to us!!!

BVO wants to pick up pressing issues like gender equality and emancipation of women, homo- and transsexuals, particularly those with a migrant background. Over the past years the audience has developed a new, more respectful view of the participants through their enthusiasm for the acrobatic abilities of the dancers. This is how Voguing sends out a clear signal against sexism, xenophobia, misogyny and homophobia in a heterosexual male-dominated world.

It is the only event in Germany that gives the platform to meet vogue legends, DJ´s and artists from New York and the opportunity to share real history, the dance and connect with each other.

YOUR SUPPORT

Your financial support will help cover expenses and make sure that the entrance prices are kept low. Your donation will finance material costs, our artists and musicians from the USA and FRANCE and the documenting of the festival through movies and pictures. This will not only create beautiful memories for audience and participants but will also serve as a useful tool for the project management in the acquisition of new funding and sponsorship partners in the future.
story_txt:
Georgina Leo Melody our artistic director on the festival - check our "Galerie"!!!

WHAT IS BERLIN VOGUING OUT?


Berlin Voguing Out (BVO) is a festival, founded in 2012 in Berlin, Germany and till now an unique meeting platform. We want to connect people from different social and cultural backgrounds, establish voguing in Germany and support the already existing community. The age spectrum of participants and audience ranges from teenagers to seniors. Women, men, hetero- and transsexuals are practising and celebrating together, prejudices are being reduced and the commonalities, unification is moving into focus.



WHAT IS VOGUING?A dance style, developed in the 1960’s in the Ballroom Scene of Harlem, NYC, that is dominated by homo- and transsexuals and inspired by the fashion magazine Vogue.



THE FESTIVAL
The BVO Festival is for national and international participants including workshops, 
film screenings & lectures, shows, partys and lastly the Voguing Ball, in order to teach, learn and establish historical and more recent forms of the dance. This year our international guests are voguing legends Archie Burnett (USA), Cesar Valentino (USA) & DJ Vjuan Allure (USA).


HIGHLIGHT of the Berlin Voguing Out Festival - THE VOGUING BALL. The Voguing Ball is a competition, with the categories "Vogue Performance", "Runway" and BVO special category "pose pour payette" a unique photo contest at the nhow hotel, Berlin. In each category the participants fight for the desired trophies, which are hand made by Archie Burnett and Cesar Valentino. The motto of this year’s Ball is JOURNEY TO THE FAR EAST and will integrate influences from the Chinese, Japanese, Indian and Polynesian.

WHAT MAKES THE VOGUING BALL SO SPECIAL? We offer a free space for expression where music, dance, creativity, individuality and mutual respect are a top priority. This provides an ideal foundation for a respectful artistic and personal exchange of participants.
WHATS NEW THIS YEAR? BVO offers a unique presentation platform called 321 FASHION-Watch me serve. An opportunity for design students and graduates, as well as new-comer designers to present their fashions on the runway of The Journey To The Far East Ball 2014.

WE NEED YOU

In order to realize this years Berlin Voguing Out Festival - we need your help!!! Support the very mixed COMMUNITY, help us to offer a stage for ARTISTS, DANCERS and DESIGNERS and EVERYONE who is willing to walk a runway and be a part of the scene - every donation is important to us!!!

BVO wants to pick up pressing issues like gender equality and emancipation of women, homo- and transsexuals, particularly those with a migrant background. Over the past years the audience has developed a new, more respectful view of the participants through their enthusiasm for the acrobatic abilities of the dancers. This is how Voguing sends out a clear signal against sexism, xenophobia, misogyny and homophobia in a heterosexual male-dominated world.It is the only event in Germany that gives the platform to meet vogue legends, DJ´s and artists from New York and the opportunity to share real history, the dance and connect with each other.
YOUR SUPPORT
Your financial support will help cover expenses and make sure that the entrance prices are kept low. Your donation will finance material costs, our artists and musicians from the USA and FRANCE and the documenting of the festival through movies and pictures. This will not only create beautiful memories for audience and participants but will also serve as a useful tool for the project management in the acquisition of new funding and sponsorship partners in the future.

story:
Land of Smiles

A musical about the trafficking of women in Thailand

Here is a story that almost no one knows. In northern Burma, the army is systematically attacking and slaughtering ethnic minorities.  Some of these minority women migrate to Thailand and become sex workers to support their families and keep their people alive.  But American and European aid workers are putting these women in prison for being “victims.”  Land of Smiles will change everything you think you know about human trafficking.

Many of you have already heard about Erin Kamler's Land of Smiles, a new musical about the complex issue of sex trafficking in Thailand. The musical just had a successful run of sold-out performances and standing ovations in Chiang Mai, Thailand and we are now working to raise funds for a production that will travel to the International Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August, 2014. The Edinburgh production will allow us the opportunity to expose the show to London critics, international audiences, and, we hope, garner respected festival awards. We are committed to international cultural diversity, so we are excited to be including a cast of actors from both the United States and Thailand.

The total amount needed for the Edinburgh production is $75,000. Here on Indiegogo, we hope to reach a goal of between $20,000-$50,000. But to do this, we need your help! Please join us and help make this production happen. Donate to our campaign and bring this powerful dramatic musical to a wide international audience and give it the recognition it deserves.  No amount is too small or too large. We sincerely appreciate your support!

All of our donors will have our eternal gratitude and thanks for supporting this project.  The money raised from this campaign will augment the support of our already committed investors.  If you would like more information on how to join our investment team, please contact us directly.  Our total budget of $75,000 will cover only our transportation, housing, and production costs-- no one gets paid.  Due to the importance of this story, all of our artists and production team are volunteering their time and talents to make this production happen.  

Thank you so much for your support in bringing Land of Smiles to a larger audience, and helping us tell a story that sheds light on the untold side of trafficking.


WHAT AUDIENCES ARE SAYING

LOS ANGELES, USA

“A unique, ambitious, extraordinary musical, about an ultimately heartbreaking subject.” 

     – Craig Bolotin, Screenwriter (Black Rain, Light it Up)

“An important story and compelling musical... Offers valuable insight into human trafficking in a very digestible way.” 

     – Sherine Badawi Walton, Deputy Director, USC Center on Public Diplomacy

CHIANG MAI, THAILAND

“The script is extremely perfect. It shakes my heart, made me tearing.” 

     – Moon Nay Li, Coordinator, Kachin Women’s Association of Thailand

"An insightful, beautiful representation of the stories of migrant women."

     – Cindy Wilkinson, Managing Director, We Women Foundation

“A compelling and heartfelt production that tackles a complex issue with insight and creativity."

     – Lindsey Higgs, MTV Exit Youth Engagement Manager


ABOUT THE PROJECT

The musical is designed to serve as a platform for dialogue and awareness about human trafficking, a subject that has recently exploded onto the international stage as one of the most disturbing, complex and, many claim, pervasive issues of our time. Often dubbed “modern day slavery,” the focus of the movement that has sprung up to stop trafficking has been to “rescue” girls from situations of labor exploitation—specifically having to do with sex work. The problem with these tactics, and indeed, the entire movement to end human trafficking, is that often the most well intended of advocates do little to empower the women they are trying to “save.”

Land of Smiles responds to the crippled policies, practices and moralisms that underlie the anti-trafficking movement, by zooming in on Thailand and Burma, two countries in a region of the world known as an “infamous” trafficking hub. The story explores the way a U.S. funded non-governmental organization (NGO) responds to Lipoh, a young Kachin sex worker caught in the wrong brothel at the wrong time. Trying in earnest to “rescue” this exploited “victim,” the NGO relies on Lipoh’s victim status in order to secure the prosecution of her supposed “traffickers.” But as the narrative unfolds, we soon discover that Lipoh does not see herself as a voiceless, agency-less trafficking victim. Rather, she shares emotional, social, financial and political bonds with both her “carrier” – the woman who transported her from Burma into Thailand—and her “Mama San”-- the owner of the brothel where she worked. Far from experiencing her situation as oppressive, or akin to conditions of slavery, Lipoh finds strength in her relationships with her supposed “traffickers,” and will do anything to protect them.

Such a contradictory understanding represents what feminist scholar Joan Scott described as a “corrective” to the problem of dismissing women’s perspectives that is so prevalent in traditional, positivist research. By making Lipoh’s experience visible the story challenges the normative construction of the trafficking victim and exposes the histories and realities that have previously been obscured, buried, stigmatized and marginalized, time and time again. 

The musical seeks to shed light on the “story” currently being told about human trafficking—a story used by advocates to reinforce ideas of Western superiority on the global stage and moralisms about sex work in the developing world. This story is rooted in ideas about intimacy, rights, and women’s proper role in society. It also grapples with notions of modernization and colonialism. But most importantly, the story we tell about trafficking is our story. For it is our Western—indeed, American desire to rescue and prove ourselves “exceptional” on the world stage, that haunts us as a nation and as a culture. Unless we change these tropes, grapple with complexity, and embrace women in the developing world as our equals and our partners, the policies of the Western anti-trafficking movement will continue to fail.   

Land of Smiles represents the important values of free inquiry and risk-taking; values that form the core of any strong democratic society. The story engages the human experience of migration, and sheds light on under-represented communities and voices.

The strong support and warm reception from the international community, combined with the intellectual discussion and dialogue that Land of Smiles has generated thus far make us confident that this production will be of the highest caliber, providing audiences with a satisfying artistic experience while actively engaging thoughtful and important discussion.


SYNOPSIS

Land of Smiles is a new musical about the trafficking of women in Thailand, as seen through the eyes of sex workers, grassroots activists, NGO employees and other members of the anti-trafficking movement. Based on field research including over 50 interviews, Land of Smiles presents a dramatic look at how the story about trafficking is told, and shows that finding a solution to this problem is even more complicated than it seems.

The story focuses on the aftermath of a brothel raid in Chiang Rai, Northern Thailand. Lipoh, a young Kachin (ethnic minority) migrant from Burma, seems to be underage, making her an automatic “trafficking victim” in the eyes of the law. Emma Gable, an NGO case worker from Cedar Falls, Indiana is sent to prepare Lipoh to be a witness in a trial to prosecute her trafficker. Emma must convince Lipoh to be the person everyone sees: a trafficking victim. But Lipoh is unwilling to cooperate. She insists that she is eighteen, and was working in the brothel willingly. Not only that—she wants to go back.

What transpires is a journey into Thailand’s anti-trafficking movement—a world burdened with politics, morality and the rhetoric of human rights. Through hearing Lipoh’s story, Emma discovers that grave atrocities are being committed against the Kachin people of Burma. But these atrocities are overshadowed by a narrative about trafficking that serves the needs of the anti-trafficking movement, rather than the women it is trying to help.


DEVELOPMENT HISTORY

Land of Smiles has been produced twice as a staged reading, first at the Edgemar Center for the Arts in Santa Monica, CA in September, 2012 and at the 2013 USC conference, From Prosecution to Empowerment: Fighting Trafficking and Promoting the Rights of Migrants, sponsored by the USC Center for Feminist Research, the USC Center for the Study of Immigrant Integration, and USC Department of Sociology, where it was well received among scholars, students, and members of the public. The musical, which was written as part of USC Annenberg PhD student Erin Kamler’s dissertation project, “From Victim to Subject: Dramatization as Research in the Anti-Trafficking Space in Thailand,” has received additional support from the Wallis Annenberg Chair of Communication Technology and Society, the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism Doctoral Program, the USC Graduate School, the USC Center for Feminist Research, and the USC Diploma in Innovation program.

Land of Smiles was also recently produced as a fully staged production at the Gate Theater Group in Chiangmai, Thailand, where it ran for four sold-out performances and received a standing ovation at every performance. The cast included actors from Los Angeles and Thailand and the production crew hailed from the US, Thailand, Burma and France. Audiences included members of the local Thai and ex-pat community and tourists from around the world. As the project was designed to be a platform for dialogue around the complex issues of trafficking and migration, the production team hosted migrant and NGO groups at each performance, followed by focus groups in which participants discussed the issues raised in the piece. In this way, the musical has already proven to be a successful vehicle for engaging the important, timely issues of the trafficking and migration of women, and serve as a launching point for dialogue among audiences.


ABOUT THE WRITER/COMPOSER 

It is unusual to find a musical that is both thoroughly researched and of the highest artistic caliber. The author, Erin Kamler, is not only a PhD candidate at USC’s Annenberg School, but is also an award-winning playwright and composer. Her recent credits include Divorce! The Musical which won the 2010 Los Angeles Ovation Award for Best Original Musical, Backstage Garland Awards for Best Script and Best Musical Score, and was nominated for five LA Weekly theater awards and an LA Drama Critics Circle Award; and Runway 69 which won New Dramatists’ prestigious Frederick Lowe Award and was produced as a workshop off-Broadway in 2009. Given this history, Kamler’s Land of Smiles uniquely combines the highest quality musical performances with exceptionally strong dramatic writing and thorough research, resulting in a unique and rare theatrical achievement.

story:
I had a dream....

Scala Theatre is bringing ‘My Fair Ladies’, a brand new theatrical concert, to you in London and across the UK.

But first: the workshop!

‘My Fair Ladies’ celebrates some of the most iconic divas in musical theatre from Liza Minnelli to Ethel Merman, from Judy Garland to Julie Andrews and will be performed by three of the West End's finest leading ladies - and with a special male guest too.

This venture has been a true labor of love for producers Niall Bailey and Chris Wheeler and we now need your help to pull it off.

Each of your invaluable contributions will help pay for the highest calibre leading ladies from the West End to work with our Director/Choreographer Martyn Knight in bringing all-new arrangements to life.

When you’re good to mama…..!

Our goal of £1,500 is made up of fees and expenses for a week long rehearsal for the cast of four plus our director/choreographer. At the end of the week we will present a private performance of the show to an invited audience of producers, investors, theatre managers and other industry professionals, with an ambition to produce a full production later in the year in London and across the UK.

If we beat our goal of £1,500 then we will put the additional funds towards creating a compelling brand and marketing campaign for the show as well as a more central London venue for our workshop performance.

In return for making this happen we are offering a range of perks from public thanks for your help on our website and through Twitter and Facebook to a chance for pizza and Prosecco with some of our wonderful creative team and cast of talented leading ladies, to a chance to attend the exclusive workshop performance to some quirkier perks too!

 

Everything's  coming up roses….!

By contributing to the workshop costs you will be helping bring this unique show to life, a show where three of the finest leading ladies of our time celebrate the finest leading ladies of years gone by.

The show will be a nod to a bygone era of star-studded concerts in venues like the Palladium and Talk of the Town - but featuring all new arrangements, the show will be distinctively contemporary too.

You'll also be helping two young producers bring quality theatrical productions to the theatre scene in London and across the UK.

As well as receiving the perks, we promise to keep in touch and bring you exclusive content direct from our fabulous cast.

Spread a little happiness!

We will be sending regular updates through Indiegogo, of course, but you can also keep in touch with us through Twitter, Facebook and our website.  Just click on the links below.

Finally we need your help in spreading the word: so using the SHARE buttons and send to your friends and family - and let's get this show on the road!

Thanks for your support!

Niall and Chris

story:
Hi! This is Dr. Gloria Morrow and Carl Gilliard, the producers of The Things That Make Men Cry.   

 

This is Part 2 of our first campaign entitled, The Things That Make Men Cry.  Please visit our first campaign on Indigogo to learn about the play and who we are. 

 

Thank you so much for your support.  We are excited to report that through online and offline donations, we are past the halfway mark.  We originally needed $35,000.00 and now we only need $10,000.00 to complete this project. 

 

The Casting Call is September 22, 2013, and The Things That Make Men Cry is scheduled to hit the stage, November 1-3, 2013 at the beautiful Barnsdall Gallery Theater in Los Angeles, CA.

PLEASE HELP US!  WE ARE ALMOST THERE!

story:
My Story 

In the professional ballet world you could say I am a very late starter.  I didn't start formal training until I was 16 years old! However, I don't let that stop me from achieving my dream of dancing professionally.  

After only two years of professional training I was accepted into the prestigious Kirov Academy of Ballet in Washington D.C. where I trained for the 2013-2014 school year.  

This year has been one of the hardest years in terms of achieving my goal of becoming a professional ballet dancer.  The cost of tuition while attending the Kirov Academy of Ballet has sapped my family's financial resources and made it very difficult for me to be able to attend Ballet Arizona's summer intensive and City Ballet of San Diego's summer intensive.  

In the short number of years that I have been training, I have proved that I have the dedication and am willing to put in the hard work it takes to make it in this competitive dance world. 


What I need to make it happen

In order for me to make it to Arizona and San Diego this summer I need $6,000USD.  This will cover the tuition for both intensives as well as travel fare, boarding, and supply me with enough pointe shoes to get through it! 

The Impact 

I can't even thoroughly put into words how much your help would mean to me.  I have worked so hard in order to get to the level of dancing I am at today and your contribution will bring me so much closer to becoming a professional ballet dancer. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

Some people just can’t contribute, and I understand!  

Please spread the word about my campaign by linking this page on Facebook, or any other social media website.  It would be greatly appreciated!
story_txt: My Story In the professional ballet world you could say I am a very late starter.  I didn't start formal training until I was 16 years old! However, I don't let that stop me from achieving my dream of dancing professionally.  After only two years of professional training I was accepted into the prestigious Kirov Academy of Ballet in Washington D.C. where I trained for the 2013-2014 school year.  This year has been one of the hardest years in terms of achieving my goal of becoming a professional ballet dancer.  The cost of tuition while attending the Kirov Academy of Ballet has sapped my family's financial resources and made it very difficult for me to be able to attend Ballet Arizona's summer intensive and City Ballet of San Diego's summer intensive.  In the short number of years that I have been training, I have proved that I have the dedication and am willing to put in the hard work it takes to make it in this competitive dance world. What I need to make it happenIn order for me to make it to Arizona and San Diego this summer I need $6,000USD.  This will cover the tuition for both intensives as well as travel fare, boarding, and supply me with enough pointe shoes to get through it! The Impact I can't even thoroughly put into words how much your help would mean to me.  I have worked so hard in order to get to the level of dancing I am at today and your contribution will bring me so much closer to becoming a professional ballet dancer. Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can’t contribute, and I understand!  Please spread the word about my campaign by linking this page on Facebook, or any other social media website.  It would be greatly appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

My husband and I are aspiring photographers.  We have been asked to be our friends photographers when they get married in Ireland this October.  Problem is, we don't have the money to go but would REALLY like to.  It would be an amazing opportunity for us.

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $3,000 for airfare and hotel stay.  We need to get tickets early so we can get better prices.

I know it's not much to offer, but anyone that donates more than $100 will get a CD with all the pictures we take that are non-wedding related.  Then you can be part of our trip you helped fund! 

The Impact

This would be a huge step for J.D.'s side of our photography since he's more of a landscape photographer.  It would also be great for me since I am a stay home mom that is really trying to make a career out of portrait and event photography.  Please help our little business grow.  This is more than a trip to Ireland, honestly.  It's a chance to expand our business.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you can't donate money.  Believe me, if anyone understands being poor it's me.  Whether you can or can't, we would greatly appreciate it if you could share our link and help spread the word about our wonderful journey!

story:
Hi, I'm Travis Simmons, also known as "The Big Funny." I'm a social commentary comedian. I hope the video above made you laugh. I submitted that same video when I entered the "The Big Sky International Comedy Competition"

This campaign is to raise money for my travel expenses for competing in "The Big Sky International Comedy Competition," where only 24 comedians from around the world have been selected to perform. I have been doing stand-up comedy for over 15 years but have not traveled as widely as I would like. I would love this opportunity to spread some of "The Big Funny" to the Big Sky Country (it just SOUNDS right, doesn't it?)

With your help, I'll have the opportunity to be seen by agents, managers, producers, club owners and casting directors (can't you see me now, "Harry and the Hendersons 2?")

I am asking for $650 for travel expenses. At the moment I'm typing this, a roundtrip plane ticket costs $450. It's probably already gone up. That's it, just a plane ticket. Coach. Hopefully exit row. 

PERKS

 - If you donate $5, you will receive a digital download of my CD, "Funnier Than You Think."

  - If you donate $20 or more, I will record a personalized phone message for you in the voice of Redd Foxx, James Earl Jones, Bill Cosby or Louis Armstrong. 

 - For $100 I promise NOT to do the voice of Redd Foxx, James Earl Jones, Bill Cosby or Louis Armstrong around you for an entire MONTH. 

If you can't give anything, obviously I get it. However, if you could spread the word or post this on your Facebook for me, I'd be very grateful. 

Travis Simmons AKA "The Big Funny"

story:
The Project

My Van Allen Belt is a one act play written and directed by Cal Arts alumnus, Sarah Louise Wilson. The play will have it's world premiere at the California Institute of the Arts Coffeehouse Theater in May. 

My Van Allen Belt is a beautifully composed play about courage, love, hope, letting go and living in the now. 

This is an interdisciplinary production that will include Cal Arts students such as: actors, live musicians, producers, managers, technical directors, lighting designers, sound designers, and a graphic designer. The only thing missing is YOU! 

While we are seeking support from school, this show is currently being funded entirely out-of-pocket. We live for our craft. Help us do what we love. 

Support

Help support the students of Cal Arts to mount a successful and stunning production with a monetary donation. What will your donation do? Great question! Your donation will cover the construction and materials for our unique set design, costumes, sound and instrument support for our musicians, one of a kind programs and posters designed by a graphic design student, props (practical props which need to be replaced for every show.) 

Your donation is an investment in the future life of this play. We hope to submit the play to festivals around the world---but we need you to help us first!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If a monetary donation is not right for you at this time, we are accepting in-kind donations. If you are interested in supporting with an in-kind donation please email mallorylopez@alum.calarts.edu

We are interested if you or your business would like to be a sponsor with a monetary donation, in-kind donation, or a trade out. Please email mallorylopez@alum.calarts.edu

story:
The Red Door Theatre Company Presents

The Last Flapper

by William Luce

A theatrical biography of the original flapper, Zelda Sayre Fitzgerald

Capital Fringe Festival, Washington DC, July 2012

Thursday 7/12 8:30pm

Saturday 7/14 Noon

Thursday 7/19 6:00pm

Tuesday 7/24 9:15pm (Special Event Afterwards to Celebrate Zeldaâ€™s Birthday â€“ Details TBA)

Saturday 7/28 3:30pm


Based on her letters and stories, this exciting play is the definitive portrait of Mrs. F. Scott Fitzgerald: the glamorous, fun loving, and tragic Zelda. As in "The Bell of Amherst", "Lucifer's Child", and "Bronte", Luce reveals the contradictions and mysteries of an extraordinary woman while fashioning a moving yet witty play. Set in an insane asylum on the last day of Zelda's life, the play unfolds as a hypnotic session. Zelda tells of her innocent rebellion as a southern belle, od her destructive marriage, and of her mental disintegration.


"A cry of the heart that relentlessly delivers the truth" - The New York Times.


On a personal note, discovering Zelda was a life altering experience. I discovered a woman so far ahead of her time, that her personal philosophies and view of life are still ground breaking for women 100 years later. She remains an enigma to those who have studied the 1920's and the American ex-patriat movement. Additionally, some believe that she was the actual author of many works attributed to her husband.


More of the world deserves to know this fascinating woman.


What we need and how you can help:


Producing a play takes a lot of collaboration and money. The Red Door Theatre Company has always been committed to creating excellent theatre with integrity on a small budget. However, even a small budget is still not nothing. Some of our expenses are: Festival participation fees, insurance, rehearsal space, marketing, staffing (director, stage manager, designers, etc), transportation, scenic expenses. We can do a lot with a little, as you'll notice our goal is pretty low. The more money we raise, the more we can invest in the process.


Other ways you can get involved:


Volunteers are always welcome to help with marketing and some technical preparation and on-site assistance. Additionally, as we discover items we need for sets, costumes and props, we will be putting out requests for donations or loans of those items. Visit the Red Door Web Site for more information. www.thereddoortheatre.com

story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page! Your support is greatly appreciated and will help me to successfully achieve one of my life long dreams...to create and perform in my very own dance show!

I have been involved in dance since I was a little girl, but began to realize the importance of dance in my life when I was in my teens. After high school, I continued my dance training at Ryerson University and absorbed as much as I could about this wonderful and expressive art form. I have had the pleasure to work with many choreographers, dance as an independent artist as well as a member of a few independent companies and collectives in Toronto.

I recently moved to Milton, a growing town, and found an amazing arts community here! I created a few projects that included not just dance, but multiple forms of art, and youth dancers, as Nutcase does as well. I believe that incorporating more then one form of art can help to expand your audiences experience and allow them to experience art at a deep level. This is what I hope to achieve through Nutcase.

Your support will help to provide adequate payment for all of those collaborators involved in Nutcase as well as additional needs such as costumes and advertising to name a few.

By supporting Nutcase you are helping to show your support for the arts and recognizing the importance of the arts in our community and in our lives.
 
This performance has been funded by the Ontario Arts Council, but we still need your help to meet our fundraising goals!

When is the Performance?

Glad you asked!

Please join us for the World Premiere on Saturday April 20th at 8pm at
The Milton Centre for the Arts in MinMaxx Hall. Ticket Information

What is Nutcase? Who is involved?

Again, I'm glad you asked! Nutcase is based on an original idea and concept created by Elizabeth Kmiec.

In a place where the future has already been chosen, one woman searches for meaning as she explores each day hoping to find her unique match. Experience this exciting journey through film and live elements including dance, music, and theatre. This is a mixed media performance you won't want to miss!

  • Concept, Choreography : Elizabeth Kmiec
  • Dance Artists: Elizabeth Kmiec, Mistyna Wilcock, Katie Evans, Jen Hum, Paul Charbonneau
  • Local Youth Dance Artists
  • Additional Choreography: Ryan Lee
  • Film Maker and Director: Marco P. Veltri
  • Composer: Ryner S
  • Live Musical Performances By: Ken Morse and Arun
  • Stage Manager: Melissa Fischer

What We Need & What You Get

If the fundraising goal is met, Nutcase will receive just over $1500 (after Indiegogo fees). These funds will help to support the following:

  • Adequately paying the dancers and other collaborators
  • Composition of original music
  • Post production editing of the Nutcase dance film used in the show
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Transportation expenses
  • Theatre space rental
  • Costume
  • Stage manager
  • Lighting design and additional requirements
  • Advertising and promotional materials
  • Archival video
There are many components that work together to create the finished product that you will see on the stage. If the funding amount is not met these elements will continue to receive support, but considerations based on budget would need to take place. All funds received go directly to supporting these collaborators and magnificent artists.
 
Check out our great perks for your donations at the right side of this page. Receive recognition, dance photos and more for your generous donations!

How Indiegogo Works

You can pledge any amount you would like, or choose an amount that offers a reward. At the end of our Indiegogo campaign, the credit cards of those who have pledged are charged and rewards are sent. If the goal is not met,  the funds are still received, but Indiegogo charges takes an additional 9% of funds raised. If the goal is exceeded or met, Indiegogo takes only 4%. Aside from these fees and a 3% credit card processing fee, all funds raised will be used directly in the production of Nutcase

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!
  • Forward our campaign link to others in your network who may be interested... arts enthusiasts, corporate donors, those interested in supporting dance and the arts. www.igg.me/at/nutcase
  • Come and see the show! Gather a group of friends and make it a night out. Come see the show at the Milton Centre for the Arts.
  • Spread the word! Tell everyone you know about Nutcase!
  • Like Nutcase on facebook

How to contact Elizabeth

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like more information about this campaign or the show : elizabethkmiec@hotmail.com or 647-462-1466

Thank You!

Thank you for taking the time to read through this information and to show your support for Nutcase!

story:
Hello old and new friends of Scapegoat Carnivale Theatre!

We have joined the Indiegogo bandwagon to bring you news of our latest show and to elicit your help with its funding!

Our project:

We are bringing Euripides' The Bacchae to Montreal's famous Centaur Theatre, as this year's selection for their Brave New Looks program. Our own Joseph Shragge and Andreas Apergis have done another translation direct from the ancient Greek, just as they did with our award-winning production of Medea in 2010. Apergis will be directing a fantastic cast and brilliant design team, along with a chorus of beautiful voices who will bring Dionysus' ecstatic worshippers to life.

We are so excited to be mounting this famous greek tragedy that is considered one of the best of its time, yet is also difficult and rarely staged. We have a deep appreciation for this remarkable story and for the power of the artisits we have gathered. Our team is intensely commited and extremely talented, and our take on this story is unique.

The design for our version of the Bacchae will be inspired by the Second Great Awakening, an ecstatic religious revival that took place in a field in Cane Ridge, Kentucky in 1801. We chose this period of bacchanalian excess, drawing the link between Dionysian religion and ecstatic North American Christianity.

As everyone in theatre knows, it's tough to get funding, especialy lately. We we need to raise approximately $6500 in order to mount this production, which is scheduled to open October 12, 2012 (closing October 20). It's an urgent situation we are in, so we are appealing to our friends, family, supporters, and to theatre lovers to help us create a piece of art.

A bit about who we are:

Scapegoat Carnivale Theatre is an independent Montreal-based theatre company. We are interested in theatre that mixes classical, popular and experimental forms, employs heightened or poetic language and is expressionistic, unsettling or unreal. Our company is made up of artists whose mission it is to experiment with new methods and collaborate with artists and performers from diverse artistic and cultural traditions.

For more about us and our past productions, please check out our website: www.scapegoatcarnivaletheatre.com

What we are asking for:

We need your contributions to make this production a reality, but we could also use your power to spread the good hellenic word. Like the frenzied female worshippers in the Bacchae, please go forth and tell everyone you know to check out our Indiegogo campaign and to come see the show!

A note about the donations:

As you can see, we have some fun perks to tempt you to donate. As an additional perk, we can offer a charitable reciept for your donations of $100 or more, thanks to fiscal sponsorship from the Conseil des arts de Montréal. In order to receive a tax receipt, you must send a donation cheque (made out to CAM) directly to us, and not click on the donation buttons on the right side of this screen. Once you have clicked the donate button and entered your credit card number, we can't undo it, so please be sure that if you do so you do not expect a tax receipt.

To make a tax-deductible donation of $100 or more, please contact us at info@scapegoatcarnivaletheatre.com.

To see a list of the donors who have sent us donations in the mail, please check our updates section! (If you don't want to be listed please let us know with the check you send).

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
