story:
Multi-disciplinary world premiere, You Need To Read Poetry! is a diverse cavalcade of over 40 American poets living and dead from 20th century to present--from Langston Hughes, Amiri Baraka, and Nikki Giovanni to Anne Waldman, Marge Piercy, Thom Gunn, Gary Soto and Lucia Perillo. Additionally, each performance includes a mini poetry slam or live reading, further highlighting a vibrant selection of local Bay Area poets.Curated and helmed by Artistic Director Scott Baker (himself a prize-winning, published poet), You Need To Read Poetry! opens at Bindlestiff Studio in San Francisco on November 30, 2012, running 12 shows through December 23rd, 2012.

Our ensemble (Shaye Acevedo, Rotimi Agbabiaka, Melvign Badiola, Geo Epsilanty, Valerie Fachman, Nazelah Jamison, Gloria McDonald, Gino Rose, and Carina Salazar) performs poetry in a wide variety of styles including storytelling, choral recitation, direct address, and dramatic scenes. We incorporate contact improvisation, interspersed with live and sound-tracked music, projected poems, documentary footage, and audience interactive segments like “the Explication Game” (dueling improvised explanations of classic and popular contemporary poems) and audience-created Exquisite Corpse poems.

Poetry allows us to share life’s most intimate moments (Childbirth, Love, Loss, Death, Illness) and its more public ones (War, Violence, Alienation, Celebrations) in ways ordinary language cannot capture.

So much life is condensed into the several stanzas of a short poem. We attempt here to create a physical and synesthetic melding of movement, gesture, image, sound, perhaps even taste and smell, with our chosen poems. We draw a poet’s lines of influence, showing how their language and the compositions change the way we see things, how poems influence reality and, of course, the opposite. We live now in a society of sound bites. A poem can take the same space as a sound bite, but contain exponentially more worlds. Our goal is to bring those worlds to the audience. Reconnecting people with the kind of poetic theatre that began with the Greeks, we’ll immerse them in an evening of language and movement, rekindling excitement to seek out more poetry to bring into their lives. 

Performers Under Stress developed this piece through a unique physical theatre workshop-into-rehearsal process. You Need to Read Poetry! forges a new way for the audience to experience the intersection of language and the human body, promising an evening of joyous, high-energy, intensely kinetic ensemble work. Multimedia elements entwine the language to the movements.

 

FUNDING: What is $2000 bucks worth? To a small independent theatre, it’s worth a lot.  

To keep our theatre space alone costs $500 every month. To pay an understudy, an assistant director, and a live musician honoraria for their excellent work in rehearsal and performance, is about $500 each. This is the tip of the iceberg: the director, costume/prop designer, and managing director donate their work and much of their personal income towards productions. Recipients of a $4K Theatre Bay Area grant, we netted $800 in an independent benefit that took 2 months to organize. $20 full price tickets, $10 seniors/students/TBA members, 65-seat house, no one turned away for lack of funds. We pay our poetry slam emcee, actors, lighting designer, stage manager, multimedia designer, sound operator, part time publicist, need to buy ads, and print posters/postcards/programs for the show. We have set, prop and costume needs.

And then there are all the poets. Representing the work of over 60 poets is not enough. We must compensate the living poets, whether for writing, reading aloud or slamming, and pay estates and agents of poets who have died.

And we’re just getting started. We hope to carry this work forward, to tour schools, colleges and libraries, igniting new passion for poetry--once we have recovered from the exhaustion of opening such an ambitious project.

 If we don’t get the full amount, who will suffer?

The artistic director, who works a full time old-school day job to fund this theatre and support his family, and his wife--who volunteers her time as administrator, performer, costumer and prop designer, housekeeper and mother--will feel the immediate financial pain.

Everyone else will still be paid (maybe not as much, which is sad, as they’re not getting enough anyway.) We just won’t be able to tour this. Worst case scenario: we may not be able to afford to produce another show. That has long term consequences for the local arts community which are difficult to compute, but real.

 

IMPACT: Why are we valuable to you, and to the world at large?

Why read poetry? As American literacy rates still declined in the past decade, we feel an obligation to produce theatrical events that bring literature to life. There is nothing like a great poem to distill a profound experience, to show a lifetime in a moment. A great poem creates a verbal/visual collage; it is the picture that paints a thousand words. We want to put poems in a physical and emotional context that reflects both the poet’s experience and era, and how those influenced where we are today. Without Langston Hughes, Gil Scott-Heron maybe never writes a poem. Without Gil Scott-Heron, Rap Music becomes something else. Without Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, T.S. Eliot and a myriad others never get a chance to publish; their poems are too different from the time. We don’t get the Imagists, who influenced the Surrealists, who influenced tons of rock musicians during the 60s.

Unique Perks: We'll love you for any help you give, but autographed posters, free tickets, DVD's, or a unique, special ode to you...how does that sound?

Our track record assures us some success:

Performers Under Stress devises new plays, combining physical theatre with original, rare, adapted, or compiled writings. We mentor and develop diverse writers and performing artists and reinvent classic works.

Inspired by the literature of Samuel Beckett, PUS was formed in Chicago by writer/performers Scott Baker and Charles Pike. Recipients of Joseph Jefferson citations for theater work, they produced over 9 world premieres and original adaptations from 1991-99, including Dead Soldier Walks Home, Baker’s adaptation of Robinson Jeffers’ epic anti-war poem, and Pound Bound, commissioned for Chicago’s 2nd Rhinoceros Festival. Wired into a phone booth-sized cage, Baker portrayed Ezra Pound, recounting anecdotes of his life and poetry he composed while incarcerated in WWII Italy for fascism. Resurrected 2006 in San Francisco with Valerie Fachman, PUS has a growing ensemble of artistic associates including Geo Epsilanty and Sylvia Kratins, and continues to be praised for bare-bones productions of Samuel Beckett plays and original works. Previous Bay Area productions include the critically lauded How To Love, Cancer Cells, Failure 2 Communicate, Mrs. Warren’s Profession, Sam I Am, Ghost Train Coming, tempestuous(ness) or HIStory Is Told by the Victor, and The Farmington Armada. Baker assembled a program about the life of poet Richard Hugo with late veteran stage/screen actor Turk Muller, which held a pilot performance in 2011 at SF’s Bird & Beckett Books and toured the Pacific Northwest, including Seattle’s Hugo House.

Read more about us at www.performersunderstress.com

 

Who out there loves great poetry? Who would like more of it? Send us a message, vote with your wallet: show us you care. It takes so little to help. Even $5 will make a difference. 400 people give that little, and we make our goal. If only 100 people give $20, we make our goal. But if you can’t afford $5, and want to help—get the word out! Tell your friends about this campaign, especially people in Northern CA or the Bay Area. Indiegogo has easy to use share tools, so please--share away!
story_txt:
Multi-disciplinary world premiere, You Need To Read Poetry! is a diverse cavalcade of over 40 American poets living and dead from 20th century to present--from Langston Hughes, Amiri Baraka, and Nikki Giovanni to Anne Waldman, Marge Piercy, Thom Gunn, Gary Soto and Lucia Perillo. Additionally, each performance includes a mini poetry slam or live reading, further highlighting a vibrant selection of local Bay Area poets.Curated and helmed by Artistic Director Scott Baker (himself a prize-winning, published poet), You Need To Read Poetry! opens at Bindlestiff Studio in San Francisco on November 30, 2012, running 12 shows through December 23rd, 2012.
Our ensemble (Shaye Acevedo, Rotimi Agbabiaka, Melvign Badiola, Geo Epsilanty, Valerie Fachman, Nazelah Jamison, Gloria McDonald, Gino Rose, and Carina Salazar) performs poetry in a wide variety of styles including storytelling, choral recitation, direct address, and dramatic scenes. We incorporate contact improvisation, interspersed with live and sound-tracked music, projected poems, documentary footage, and audience interactive segments like “the Explication Game” (dueling improvised explanations of classic and popular contemporary poems) and audience-created Exquisite Corpse poems.

story:
Kenneth Walker Dance Project (KWDP)

Kenneth Walker Dance Project is a contemporary ballet company dedicated to the expression of the modern condition through the lens of the classical vocabulary. KWDP has created a new work for each home season.  We're now turning to you to directly fund our latest work.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign will fund:

  • Rehearsal space
  • The commission for new music
  • New costumes
  • Social Media Marketing

The Impact

You will directly support the creation of new art and help the company continue to grow into your contemporary ballet company.  

  • KWDP is poised to become an important company in the region.  Having recently served as an adjunct professor in ballet for CSU, Dominguez Hills, Kenneth becomes more respected in the dance community. 

  • The more we raise the more we can do.
  • More money means more money for marketing, helping us grow the company audience.
  • More funds gives us more opportunity to retain our wonderful artists so that they can dance for us longer and you get to know them better.

Other Ways You Can Help

We recognize that not everyone is able to donate money.  There are other ways you can help.  You can spread the word about this campaign.  You can become our fan on Facebook (/KennethWalkerDanceProject) or follow us on Twitter (@KWDP).  Help us raise our profile so that we can reach more people.

story:
Be apart of something great !

PRIDE'S SEXY REVUE !

 

Greetings world and lovely humans. Pride and the Vanities pop music, performance  group has had the honor of playing many venues here in the U.S. and are excited about merging the group into a sexy revue.

I want to contribute to the world, living green and also helping others in need with our art. This show can and will be explosive with your contributions. 

The funding will be contributed to the full production of show. Join me for this epic adventure and project that will truly be prolific. Be apart of a legacy!

Music is power !

 

Thank You,

Mark H. Brooks, Esq.

"Space-bus Project" SM

story:
The Renassiance Dueling Play has received a spot in a major theatre festival (the Midtown International Theatre Festival) and we are in need of funding to cover the initial cost.

The show is a combining of a series of plays written by Michael Hagins that covers the history and legacy of dueling throughout the Renaissance period.  Maybe you've heard of them:

  • The Duelist Code (part of C.A.G.E. Theatre's Night of Solitary, the Strawberry One-Act Festival and John Chatterton's One-Act Festival)
  • The Cavalier's Wife (part of C.A.G.E. Theatre's Night of Solitary and John Chatterton's One-Act Festival)
  • Wenches and Ale (part of C.A.G.E. Theatre's Night of Solitary, Shakespeare Saturday's Short Play readings, and Cupcake Readings)
  • The Decapitation of Thomas Kent (part of C.A.G.E. Theatre's Night of Solitary and Shakespeare Saturday's Short Play readings)

Well, in a creative endeavor, I combined them into one full-length play of roughly 60-65 minutes, resulting in a comic journey throughout history tied together by an arrogant Spanish swordsman and his young, female assistant.

The money requested not only covers the entry fee into the festival ($998 to be exact) but covers rehearsal space, costume and weaponry repair, and the usual incidental costs that come with creating a show.  The show's budget is shockingly small, seeing as I own the costuming and weaponry, and the only set is a simple table and two chairs.  And if we don't get enough money in time for the festival, the money WILL go to putting up the show in its own space.  No matter what, the end goal is for the Renaissance Dueling Play to make its world premiere!

Please give whatever you can.  Even $1 would help!  (If all my Facebook friends gave me $1 I'd already be set!)  Not only would you make me happy but you'd make 12 artists would get to showcase their comic abilities and sword-fighting prowess to a large group of agents, managers, fellow artists and a whole array of new audience members!

We don't have a whole lot of time, so take a little time and donate a little something to the cause!

story:
"If you ask me what style I am using for this play I would say all and nothing. But to be more specific here's my recipe: one ounce of 'Pataphysics, two spoons of Artaud's brain, three glasses of Jarry's favorite absinthe with his gun in hand, one pound of veggie Dada meat, Three hairs of Adam Szymkowicz's mangina, a little juice of futurist nectar, one quantum physics cat on Stephen Hawkins' lap while both swimming inside a black hole and collecting data, and finally 10 pounds of Japanese porn animation. If you follow this recipe you will taste the magic of this piece. Seriously." 

-Daniel Irizarry interview with Jody Christopherson, Huffington Post

CLICK THE LINK TO READ THE FULL INTERVIEW

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jody-christopherson/daniel-irizarry-ubu-king_b_2192096.html

 

terraNOVA Collective, One-Eighth and IRT Theater are proud to announce the re-launch of UBU, the biggest grossing show of soloNOVA! Founded by Daniel Irizarry and Laura Butler Rivera, One-Eighth aims to bring out the physical extreme of the actor connected with the inner life of the character. Working with various artists from all parts of the world, One-Eighth was born of a hunger and a need, telling a story through the means of the actor, exploring the necessity of the human being, and examining the visceral connection of human nature. One-Eighth is a close up and an open shot to the micro and macro of Nature. Never in between.       

Written by acclaimed writer Adam Szymkowicz. The New York Times has called Adam Szymkowicz's plays "sweet, sexy, neurotic friendly.....fabulously weird and weirdly fabulous....disturbing but touching."
 
Directed and Performed by acclaimed artist Daniel Irizarry.
 
 "...a monster of mammoth size and ravenous appetite, sort of like a tasmanian devil on steroids, by way of Monty Python's Mr. Creosote..."- -nytheatre.com by Martin Denton
 

‘…Irizarry’s singular stage presence and the productions beautifully grotesque little world make this…expanding universe worth a good look.’  -New York Theatre Review by Olivia Jane Smith

 

UBU is scheduled to open in New York at the IRT Theatre and will run from December 4th-16th.

 
UBU, inspired by Ubu Roi,  is the King of the Great Expanding Universe who will allow a privileged few into his mansion to watch him eat steak. Along the way, he may play music, read you poetry and tell of his lost loves and purchased politicians - it all depends on the mood of the King. A kinetic romp through the absurdist world of the most powerful CEO in the universe.
 
UBU's creative team includes:  
 
Written by Adam Szymkowicz
Directed and Performed by Daniel Irizarry
Assistant Director  Laura Butler Rivera
Marketing/Associate Producer     Homa Hynes
UBU Servants     Laura Butler Rivera,
                      Shang-Ho Huang,
                      & Homa Hynes
Scenic Design        Mikiko Suzuki Macadams
Sound Design        Marcelo Anez
Lighting Design      Lucrecia Briceno

Puppets and Props     Frankenstudio
Costume Design     Edith Raw
Stage Manager     Zina Goodall
 

As we get closer to this much anticipated premiere we need YOUR support! 

 
Your support will provide the means necessary to partially cover the period of rehearsals and production expenses such as artist’s fees for their time and expertise, acquisition of scenic material, and transportation fees. And, if we reach our goal we can give %10 to the Hurricane Sandy relief efforts 
 
 
Your donation will:
 • Provide funding toward set and costume materials. 
 • Provide funding toward the transportation of materials/set.
 • Provide funding for the materials used in the construction of props and puppets.
 • Provide funding toward the Artist Stipend and crew for all the long hours of work and sweat that they put into this fantastic project.
 * With goal reached, provide help to the Hurricane Sandy survivors.
   

Thank you for your time and support. We could not make this happen without you! We are honored to have you in One-Eighth's sweaty family.

 
 
Do you want to donate but prefer to do so by mail?

It's still possible! You can send us a check and you will still receive UBU's "Ah thank you's". All checks should be made out to:
 
Pay to: terraNOVA Collective
Sent to:
100 Park Terrace West Apt. 3M 
New York, NY, 10034
Please write in the memo (Earmark):  UBU  
 
 Links:
 www.facebook.com/OneEighth
 www.terranovacollective.org
 http://irttheater.org/
 www.facebook.com/Daniel.Irizarry.Artist 
 www.daniel-irizarry.com
 

 

Please help spread the word.  Be sure to LIKE us on Facebook and Follow us on Twitter @OneEighth1

New York, NY, 10034

story:
Short Summary

Burlesque Classique is a modern-day traditional burlesque dance troupe directed by Lola Rose, who has the crazy idea that she would like to pay the dancers for their work. BC is presenting the Burlesque of Broadway for 7 shows at the Capital Fringe Festival.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $3000 to pay for the Capital Fringe costs and to pay the dancers. The Capital Fringe Festival costs are $900. The rest of the money goes to 8 dancers.  If  the entire goal is not raised, the dancers will be paid first.

There are some great perks for donating – acknowledgement in the program, signed photos, tickets to future shows!

The Impact

The dancers of Burlesque Classique show up to rehearsal each week after a long day of work only expecting to be paid a percentage of the tips collected at each show. We will not be collecting tips at the Fringe show. It would be great to be able to pay the dancers. They deserve it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t’ have any funds, that’s OK. There are other ways that you can help us:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Buy a ticket and come to the show.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Who I am, and What This Is About

My name is Bethany Adams and I've been dancing since the age of 3. I started my training at the local recreation center. It was affordable and welcoming. As a teenager, I studied ballet at a pre-professional school. I discovered that ballet was my passion. I received a college scholarship where I danced full-time and performed in numerous productions. I knew I wanted to teach ballet. When I graduated in 2008, I started teaching at different studios.

Since 2010, I have been teaching at the same recreation center where I got my start. I love teaching at recreation centers because they reach a community that may not otherwise have had the means to enroll in a professional school. As their teacher, I also believe that high teaching standards should not be sacrificed based on location. That is why I find great satisfaction in bringing quality training to this community.

What I Need aka Bottom Line

Circumstances over the years have led me to divide my time between teaching and working for an unrelated industry. My goal is to make a career transition back to what I love the most: teaching. However, in order for me to engage my students physically and artistically, I need to be a commited student myself. 

Bottom line: Ballet training is expensive. When I cannot afford to fully participate in my art form, I feel like I'm not giving my students my best. Your funds will be allocated into two categories.

1) My personal training which includes classes and workshops. Your donation will allow me to train full-time with the best ballet schools in the metroplex. 

2) A portion of the proceeds will go to a recital for my students in the summer of 2014. This includes costumes and production. All sponors are invited to attend. 

The funds raised in this campaign are to be used for the 2013-2014 school year.

What You Get

Donate $10 - Receive a personalized Thank You card for your support.

Donate $20 - Receive a personalized Thank You card, and be named as a sponsor in the recital program.

Donate $50 - Receive a personalized Thank You card, be named as a sponsor in the recital program, and get a t-shirt for the cause.

Donate $100 - Receive a personalized Thank You card, be named as a sponsor in the recital program, and have your choice of a t-shirt, or $20 gift card to Maggiano's Little Italy. 

The Impact

Your support means the world to me and my students. Ballet as an art form can seem intimidating. It has been my personal mission to break down this "fourth wall" that encourages elitist attitudes and instead, promote equal opportunity for all. Recreation centers don't generally have the funding to produce an annual recital. Your donation will give me the training I need to become a better dancer and teacher, and give my students the chance to live their dream of performing.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate, send this to your friends and family, or someone who you think might be able to help. Any efforts on your part are greatly appreciated!

Sincerely,

Bethany

story:
Hi,

 

My name is Alexander Anderson and I would like to ask for your help. I am trying to attend a summer intensive overeas with a compnay called Nederlands Dans Theater in Holland. I was fortunate enough to recieve a full scholarship as well as a guest home for the duration of the program. The only problem is that I do not have the funds to fly overseas. It would mean the world to be given the opportunity to work and explore a territory outside my own.

The program begins on August 5th and ends August 17th

Tuition is € 950,-

Housing is € 364,-

Luckly I do not have to provide any funds to attend the program. My only request is finanical assistance for the flight to and from Holland :)

 

Here is a letter that explains why I feel so greatly about this program:

 

          I am excited to be accepted to the Nederlands Dans Theater summer course for the second time because of how much I learned from the program last summer. My reason for financial need stems from my family’s inability to support me financially. After my mother’s passing in 2007, I was moved into a family and was under legal guardianship until the age of 18. After which, I was classified as an independent with no ties of financial support except for health insurance. I have been to the Netherlands Danse Theater summer course before and while being there, I have gained an entirely new experience that has shaped my dancing to an extensive degree.

           I decided to audition for the Nederlands Dans Theater summer course last year because I wanted to grow. Not just grow, but to expand into the type of sponge that absorbed anything that was thrown in my direction. I needed that challenge. There is so much to say about the way dance has been represented in The States that I needed this route to see me through. I feel that the main value of this program was contributed by the company members who were able to teach the repertory with such maturity and grace. This program was more valuable than any other because I got to see the company members take pride in why they dance and why they love the art form. They allowed the students to make choices and feel like as though we were part of the work. I felt as if the course made me feel whole inside. I’m not quite sure how to put it. Whenever I entered the dance studio, I was happy and complete in whatever moment that was provided. As the course took off, I took off with it. I tried to stay total in every moment in order to keep myself focused and ready for the next challenge. I feel as though I have developed artistically and personally throughout this program; so much that I can still recall on all of the feedback that was given to me.

           I would be more than grateful for your financial support this year as I have never felt this way about a summer program before. I have never experienced a program such as this before and I feel that I can only benefit even more by going this year as it will be my final summer as a student at The Juilliard School. Looking for opportunities and expanding my knowledge is a vital component for my growth as a dancer and by attending the Nederlands Dans Theater summer course; I will be challenging myself in a brand new direction. I cannot voice loud enough my excitement for wanting to attend this year. I feel that because I am moving into my senior year at Juilliard, I believe that my exposure to the kind of movement and maturity of this environment is vital to the potential opportunities that can come my way. I am more than confident in saying that my desperation for attending this program would merely give me the route to successfully drive towards a dream that will soon hopefully become a reality.

 Sincerely,

 

Alex 

 

Ever since I was 12, I have dreamed of being a professional dancer and choreographer. My training stems from a small hometown studio in Greenacres Florida, Alexander W. Dreyfoos Jr. High School in West Palm Beach, Florida and most recently The Juilliard School in New York City.

 

In the video displayed are my choreographic expreiences as well as my own dancing. I hope you enjoy. This art form means more to me than anyone will ever know. This opportunity will not only allow me to attend this program; it will allow a hard working dancer the opportunity to expand his knowledge as well as make connections to the professional dance world in Europe. If I do not meet my goal, then everything that is earned will go directly back to you. Please help me attend this incredible program!

story:
Short Summary

We have to move to a new studio space!  Caston Chamber Ballet Company and Caston's Ballet Academie have been blessed to be in a beautiful studio space with high ceilings, large sprung dance floors and floor-to-ceiling windows.  We have seen amazing growth in our dancers and created some beautiful new pieces here.  It has been our home for 5 and 1/2 years, but our landlord has other plans for this space so now it is on to a new adventure and we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

The quality of our dance instruction is a hallmark of Caston Chamber Ballet and Caston's Ballet Academie.  Our dancers are known for their beautiful lines, feet and technique.  Like any athlete or artist, dancers need the right materials to work with.  Having large, marley-covered sprung floors, studios with high ceilings and large mirrors, and lots of natural lighting means our dancers have the best opportunity to grow and develop their skills and abilities.  Our marley-covered sprung floors are critical to ensuring dancers' feet and legs are protected from impact injuries.  We are proud to be one of only a few studios in St. Louis providing this specialized flooring.  Having a large studio with high ceilings is key for teaching stage-preparation and spacing, and lets us offer in-studio performances.  Observation windows allow families to watch their children grow and improve in their dance skills, a feature that families tell us they treasure.  These are essential elements for our new studio home.  

Relocating a dance studio can be an arduous and costly task. For Castons it will involve:

  • Removing all marley surfaces, sprung floors, mirrors, barres, and observation windows and reinstalling them in the new studio.  Buying and installing additional materials to compensate for the larger studio floors.
  • Removing the laminate flooring in the foyer of the current studio and reinstalling it in the new space. The purchase and installation of more laminate flooring and carpet to accommodate a bigger space.
  • Painting the new studio walls.

The cost of the move and outfitting of the new studio is estimated between $5,000 and $8,000 to cover materials and essential moving-related expenses.  We will do most of the sweat-equity ourselves, along with friends, family, and our wonderful volunteers.

The Impact

Our organization's philosophy "Ballet for EveryBody" celebrates the belief that ballet encompasses an entire spectrum of performers and individuals.  An emphasis on each dancer's individual lifestyle, talents, and strengths ensures success and promotes self-confidence and personal growth within a positive environment.  Community outreach, with an emphasis on diversity among our dancers, our performances and our audiences, is central to who we are as a company and a school.

Caston's Ballet Academie was established in 2004 in Webster Groves, Missouri to provide exciting performance opportunities for dancers with a passion for ballet. Since our founding 13 years ago, our Company has doubled in size and increased in average age and skill level.  We have also established a successful Junior Company in recent years that is considered to be the best in St Louis! Just as we outgrew our original space in 2007, we now have the opportunity to move to a larger studio which will enable our continued growth and expansion in the St Louis community.  

Your support enables us to promote the art of ballet throughout St Louis, enriching the lives of all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support means the world to us and will help ensure our continued growth and service to our community through the beauty of dance.  

Please help us to get the word out about this campaign, the Company and the Ballet Academie

. Use the Indiegogo ‘Share This Campaign’ tool to reach out to family and friends who might be interested in supporting this effort.

story:
Three Peas Theatre Company 

Three Peas Theatre Company was set up in 2013 by Andrew Lynch and Mark McCabe. Andrew and Mark had been keen to write a play for some time, and death row is something which fascinated them both. They researched and discussed the topic for months and knew there was a story to be told. From this, Death Row Cowboy was born. 

Death Row Cowboy

Death Row Cowboy is a play about a young man called Carl Brant, and the people in his life who are affected by his actions. Directed by Charlie Bonner, this is a tale that deals with themes of discovering identity, coping with loneliness, fighting deep rooted regrets, and ultimately searching for redemption to influence the legacy we leave behind us.

DEATH ROW COWBOY - The Boy's School at Smock Alley Theatre - 27th Jan to 1st Feb 2014 (http://smockalley.com/) 

Starring:

  • Mick Fitzgerald as John Ritchie 
  • Andrew Lynch as Carl Brant
  • Jane McGrath as Hillary Reece 
  • Mark McCabe as Bobby Brewer
  • Written by Andrew Lynch and Mark McCabe
  • Directed by Charlie Bonner 
  • Production Manager Arber Sula 
  • Produced by Emma Coen 

Promo Video: Camera by Stuart Duff and Natasha Efole. Sound by Tim O'Connell.

Photography by Michal Baran (www.baranphotography.com)

Our needs and your wants:

In order to make Death Row Cowboy as great as it can be, Three Peas need your help. If we reach our target, the money donated will help us to cover theatre rental fees, rehearsal space, marketing and set materials. Death Row Cowboy is going to have some very exciting set pieces and lighting moments which we can only get with the help of you good people. We have some fantastic and original perks on offer for donations from €10 and above. 

Why Death Row Cowboy matters:

The opinions that people have on Death Row are divided and passionate. Death Row is something which is current, and the story told in Death Row Cowboy deals not only with that but with themes which are relevant to audiences members, both in Ireland and abroad. 

If you can't fund us..

We understand that not everyone can afford to donate - and that's fine! Instead, we ask that you tell everyone about us - share our Indiegogo page, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and of course, come see us in the Boy's School at Smock Alley this January! 

Tweet us: https://twitter.com/3peastheatre

story:
Short Summary

Miss Julia is an international collaboration between renowned Colombian film and television actor Jhon Alex Toro, Australian international theatre artist Tina Mitchell, Colombian actress Gina Jaimes, and Italian Stage Director Lorenzo Montanini. This new adaptation by SITI Company's J.Ed Araiza brings together 5 artists from 4 different countries! In August, we will gather in Bogota, Colombia at Casa Ensamble to present the first fully staged realization of this bold and exciting venture.

Set in Colombia on Midsummer Eve, Miss Julia and her servant Juan have an encounter that will change their lives forever. As Juan tries to rise from the depths of his servile existence, Miss Julia wants to escape the bonds which tie her to a meaningless upper-class existence. The result is a power play of love, lust and a clash of classes which becomes violent and seemingly out of control.

This bi-lingual production, performed in English and Spanish, will be a clash of cultures, a dance of death combining heightened physicality and rich naturalistic text. This unique take on Strindberg's text makes Miss Julia as profound today as it was 100 years ago.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this international collaboration a reality we need to raise funds for the artists airfares to Colombia and production expenses. We have a number of exciting perks including personal cast photographs signed by the cast, audition coaching, sunset sailing cruises on the Hudson river and much much more. 

The Impact

Our goal is to promote cultural exchange between Colombia, the US, Australia and Italy by presenting a classic piece of drama that is accessible to both Spanish and English speakers and to those who are not regular theatre goers. We also aim to attract the attention of international Festivals with the aim of touring the piece globally

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the means to make a contribution. Other invaluable ways in which people could help would be to share our campaign within your own social networks and if anyone living in Bogota has a spare room and can offer any of the international artists accommodation for their time in Colombia it would be a huge help! Thank you all so much.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Social Growl Dance is a Toronto based contemporary dance company led by Artistic Director Riley Sims. There are 6 dancers in the company: Austin Fagan, Charles-Alexis Desgagnes, Ana Groppler, Lee Bloom, Kay Kenney and Jolyane Langlois.

WHAT ARE WE RAISING FUNDS FOR?

Social Growl Dance is raising funds to support our first full-length production 'Are You Still Coming Tonight?'  which premieres this December 17th-20th 2014. 

WHAT DO THE FUNDS RAISED HELP PAY FOR?

Funds raised from this IndieGoGo campaign will go towards paying for:

  • The salary for all 6 company dancers including rehearsal and performance
  • Theatre Rental
  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Fee for Lighting Designer
  • Fee for Stage Manager
  • Fee for Composer
  • Elements of production including props, lighting rental, costumes etc
  • Advertising
WHAT IS THE SHOW ABOUT?

‘Are You Still Coming Tonight?’ focuses on the social dynamic of the company members and who the dancers really are. The work begins with the audience witnessing the Social Growl dancers getting together for a group dinner on stage. But what starts as a regular dinner party quickly unravels into a bizarre, yet strangely accurate, new world.


Thanks for taking the time to look at our campaign, we appreciate your support. Please considering donating to help us reach our goal!
story_txt:
WHO ARE WE?Social Growl Dance is a Toronto based contemporary dance company led by Artistic Director Riley Sims. There are 6 dancers in the company: Austin Fagan, Charles-Alexis Desgagnes, Ana Groppler, Lee Bloom, Kay Kenney and Jolyane Langlois.WHAT ARE WE RAISING FUNDS FOR?Social Growl Dance is raising funds to support our first full-length production 'Are You Still Coming Tonight?'  which premieres this December 17th-20th 2014. WHAT DO THE FUNDS RAISED HELP PAY FOR?Funds raised from this IndieGoGo campaign will go towards paying for:
The salary for all 6 company dancers including rehearsal and performance
Theatre Rental
Rehearsal Space Rental
Fee for Lighting Designer
Fee for Stage Manager
Fee for Composer
Elements of production including props, lighting rental, costumes etc
Advertising

story:
Help Indie Artists Go Go!

Welcome to BRIDGE (Building Relationships in Deliberate Group Ensemble), a program of foolsFURY Theater Company for early career theater artists. It's a platform for emerging professionals, a training ground for successful production skills, and an opportunity to premiere an original show.

All of us from BRIDGE need your generosity to make our debut possible! 

We are presenting Arriving Here Now: A Wandering Whimsy in the Fuschia Dell Gardens September 13th & 14th. Your tax-deductible donations will directly fund our apprenticeship and culminating performance as we present 3 FREE performances in Golden Gate Park. 

Why are the shows free? Because we believe accessible art is the heart of San Francisco and we want to share our theatrical creation with the community! Support emerging artists, contribute to the professional development of local youth, and make your mark by contributing to this Indie Go Go.

BRIDGE The Gap

We need $1,700 to make this all possible. Given that this program directly provides professional development to numerous young professionals and culminates in a site-specific public performance, our goal is modest.

We can do it all for less than $2,000 because we know how to manage our budgets. This apprenticeship program has taught us how to make a grand production with low-levels of funding. It's taught us to be business savvy and artistically ambitious. These funds will go directly to production costs including: props, costumes, performer honorariums, and permits for Golden Gate Park (they are expensive!). 

When you donate, not only do you get the satisfaction of supporting local cultural progenitors and their professional development, you will also receive tax-deductions and awesome perks!

When you contribute, you can attend a foolsFURY workshop from our Director Brian Livingston, get a shout out on social media, receive a Golden Ticket to our performance Arriving Here Now: A Wandering Whimsy, receive exclusive invitations to special events, get a hand-drawn BRIDGE tarot card, and have your psychic reading included in our show.

Our perks are all original, all local, and give you the chance to get into the ritual. Be part of our art and show your support.

    The Effect

    foolsFURY Theater Company has a long history of successful programs and BRIDGE is no different. foolsFURY is hot on the heels of producing The FURY Factory Festival of Ensemble Performance: a 15 day festival that featured 24 participating theater companies and shared over 40 performances with 1,500 people. Now, imagine what this powerhouse is doing to help all of us emerging artists take the stage!

    BRIDGE provides us with the support we need to develop both as artists and producers. BRIDGE immerses us in a professional environment full of mentors, advisors, and people who really care about our careers. But that's not all, BRIDGE offers locals and tourists the opportunity to enjoy free, local, and original theater. It's a circle of giving and we want you to join us.

      Watering The Roots

      We want to be open and honest with you: raising $1,700 will be no easy task for us. We are young and emerging artistic professionals without deep-pocketed networks to fund our show. But, what we lack in major donors, we make up for with community support. We know, as you read this, you are part of the grass roots that make up our meadow.

      We need your donation, even if it's $5, to meet our goal. Your support is vital to our success and we can't do it without you. 

      And you know what? We're more delicious than that potato salad Kickstarter and we won't make you dump ice on your head!

      Spreading The Word

      Not only do we need help funding our show, we need help spreading the word. The farther and wider we cast out net, the more support we get! Every donation makes the difference so please post our link on your Facebook, Tweet @ some friends who support the arts, email generous colleagues, or send your most-trusted carrier pigeons out with the URL.

      And in case you didn't know, Indie Go Go has awesome and easy share tools to make you an even better town crier in support of the arts. Support emerging artists, contribute to the professional development of local youth, and make your mark by contributing to this Indie Go Go.

      More About foolsFURY Theater Company

      The mission of foolsFURY is to revitalize the American theater by:

      • Creating ground-breaking visceral performances that inspire audiences and artists to reconsider and reconnect with the world around them,

      • Emphasizing qualities of the theater that can only be experienced live, and

      • Advancing artistic dialogue through training, research and presentation.

      FoolsFURY is a San Francisco based performance ensemble. Named the city’s “Best Theater Company” by the SF Weekly (2008), and awarded the SF Bay Guardian’s GOLDIE award for outstanding local theater group, we place a premium on the creation process, spending longer periods developing our work than is the norm in mainstream American theater. We invite the public (you!) to view the work at various stages of development, engaging our audience as partners in exploration as well as consumers of a final commodity.

      Our acclaimed productions include numerous original works and world premieres, as well as deconstructed classics. In recent years we have begun to focus on touring, in order to bring our work to a broader audience, give our creations a longer lifespan, and take a greater role in the national dialogue about the future of theater.

      Become a BRIDGE Apprentice Yourself

      (BRIDGE=Building Relationships In Deliberate Group Ensemble)

      The FURY Apprenticeship program was designed to bridge the journey from school to professional career in the theater. FoolsFURY identified focused, passionate, talented young artists in need of greater challenges and mentorship. This program provides hours of one-on-one encouragement and skill-building, creating a foundation for positive self-growth while creating a professional project from start to finish. Email deborahe@foolsfury.org for more information!
      [Photos By: Bilha Sperling, Design By: Alec White]

story:
"Brothers" probes questions of class, legacy, torture and American traditions older than the country itself as two freshmen clash over the revelation of a dark but time-honored hazing ritual at Faber College.



"Since 1873 there have been 82 recorded deaths due to the brutality and negligence associated with undergraduate hazing, with at least 1 having occurred every single year since 1997. Why does our society allow these same acts again and again in the context of 'tradition?' It is my hope in writing BROTHERS to illuminate a culture of brutality that permeates far beyond the college campus, into the vast tentacles of government, finance, and the foundations of America itself." 

-Playwright Jake Rosenberg

"Fraternity hazing is perceived as a 'present' topic in the media but really it's anything but that. It's a time-old tradition that has been problematic from the beginning. My vision for the play is to take this reality and combine it with a stylized world in which we strip it all down to the primal source of what brings people to participate in something as trapping and psychologically disturbing as fraternity hazing. I want people to question and challenge a legacy of torture that has passed under people's noses for so long because it's "embedded" in the fabric of American tradition. I believe this play has the capacity to wake people up and challenge them to challenge an absurd status quo."

-Director Sophia Cannata-Bowman



We're keeping our budget fairly modest, so every dollar is going to be vital to the success of the show -- and that's where YOU come in! We need your help to bring Brothers to life! Your donations will go towards production expenses, from sets to promotional materials, and, especially, to paying the wonderful actors and crew members that have been with us along the way. And, as a thank you, we want to give you all some really cool stuff in return! No donation is too small or too big - whatever you can give!

Here's what the budget breakdown looks like:

Set and props...................................................................................................... $450

Costumes .............................................................................................................$100

Promotion............................................................................................................ $500

Actor/crew compensation................................................................................. $450

Total: $1500


We are partnering with NYU campus organizations such as Project Pay Attention, the Inter-Greek Council, and Residence Life to spread the word out about Brothers, but we need YOU to make our dreams a reality!


Some rewards may take longer than others; however in the meantime, we will do our best to keep backers informed and up to date. You're part of this process now!

 Jake Rosenberg, Playwright 

 Sophia Cannata-Bowman, Director

 Kerry Candeloro, Producer


Show dates are November 7th (9pm), 8th (3pm), 14th (9pm), 15th (3pm), with dates being added all the time. Tickets are $20 cash only at the door. 

But free to reserve! Book your tickets NOW here: http://manhattanrep.com/ticket-reservations/

story:
Over the past year, we've been developing an original theater piece through a combination of research, Markov chains, scriptwriting, and improvisational structures. Our show premiered as a workshop at Dixon Place in June 2014 under the title "The Future is Mostly Blue." After a brief creative hiatus, the collaborative team is back in development for a full-length presentation at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer! We have a venue, we have a production team, and we have a brand-spankin' new theatre collective. Now we need YOUR help to get us the rest of the way there! Edinburgh is the oldest, largest, and inarguably the most exciting/terrifying fringe festival in the world. Having the chance to showcase on such a (metaphorically) large stage for a diverse group of international performers, producers, presenters, and programmers is an incredibly meaningful opportunity for an emerging company. 

So... what is this crazy production? 

FUTURE HONEY is a devised theatre project that investigates how humans are physically and emotionally shaped by the use of connection technologies. The show imagines a near-distant future through the use of dark humor, camp, game structures, and absurd silliness. Click here for more on the inspiration and creative process behind Future Honey.

THE STORY: In the world of the show, society has come to accept a universal "master" device. This wearable device curates an ideal user experience based on individual likes and dislikes, habits of consumption, daily routines, and recognition software. When a technological disruption incites a series of unpredictable regurgitated personal histories and memories, the lives of our three central characters are thrown into chaos. They embark upon a hero's journey, navigating a variety of obstacles, tasks, and levels in order to solve the ultimate puzzle. 

Production Team: Helen Anstis (Costume Designer), Rachel Berger (Performer), Brittany Costa (Co-Creator, Performer), Elle Malan (Production Artwork Designer), Morgan McGuire (Consulting Playwright), Jenny Reed (Co-Creator, Director), Samantha Sheppard (Co-Creator, Performer) & several other collaborating artists in progress.


What We Need! What You Get!

Moving forward, we intend to perform a limited NYC run as part of the 59E59 East to Edinburgh Festival in July 2015, and we'll move on to Edinburgh for the month of August. In order to bring our project to festivals both national and international, The Pack needs roughly $10,000. These expenses will go largely to venue rentals, application fees, travel costs, rehearsal spaces, and, ideally, to paying our extremely talented associated artists.

The Pack and friends have helped to create some rewards for your generous contribution, including limited-run drawings by our talented designer Elle Malan; a custom love letter; the opportunity to insert a secret word of your choice into our show; an original mixtape; and free tickets to our New York run. Nearly all of these perks are hand-made and come from the depths of our hearts – in thanks for enabling us to make art that we feel is socially relevant, engaging, and innovative.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Help our project be heard throughout your community, whether among other artists, coworkers, or friends.  

Have a reward you’d like to donate? An art piece to share? Let us know, and we will gladly find a home for it.
THANK YOU!

story:
Greetings, Sensible People & Fools!

We are the directors, cast and crew of the Chippewa Falls (Wisconsin) High School production of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Cinderella." 
Every year, we produce a musical that showcases the talents of our students. In the past two years alone, we've produced "Footloose" and "Annie Get Your Gun." 
This year, we've decided to bring this classic fairytale to life.  The kids are ready to entertain the community with delightful music, beautiful costumes and "MAGIC!"
However, this year, our usual sources of funding have fallen through and we cannot afford to put on the show we envisioned without some outside help.
Our show opens the evening of 2/13/15 and closes with a matinee on 2/15/15.

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $500 to help with costumes, set building, rentals and special effects. Actually, we could use more, but whatever we can raise will help us. All funds raised will go toward the production of the show.

Perks? A donation of any amount will get you a mention in the program. 

We now have a complete perks program. Please take a look and decide what level of support you'd like to provide.

Impact

Your donation will help these talented kids put on the best possible show.  It's that simple.

Thank you.

story:
About me and the project: 

My name is Hanna and I am a contemporary dance artist based in London, looking for support to start working on my new solo project:

‘Dusky, dreamy smell of dying moons and shadows’ (Working Title)

The 1920s: a decade of excess, drinks, drugs, short skirts and ‘sexual freedom’, a dramatic era of seeing and being seen. This time was, what appeared to be the decade of possibilities and dreams. It was the perfect breeding ground for a certain type of woman to develop: The Flapper. 

I have been given the opportunity to work on this new solo during a 10-week residency at Clarence Mews Studios over the next three months.  During this residency at Clarence Mews I hope to create the beginning for a solo performance project that aims to capture the spirit of the 1920s Flapper and translate it to contemporary age and society. In order to start working on this new exciting phase of my creative career I need your help. 




Funding received through the Indiegogo campaign will: 

  • help me to pay for 10-week residency at Clarence Mews Space,  which includes weekly rehearsal space, personal creative mentoring sessions with Caroline Salem as well as 5 meetings with other artists-in-residence and a final work-in- progress showing. 
  • help me to cover my travel expenses for the time of the residency as well as additional costs for the rehearsal process (such as props, costumes etc.) 

    Why should you support this project?: 

    I am a young emerging solo artist based in London, trying to establish myself as a performer and creator in the UK dance scene and this is the next step to make this happen!

    • I am in an independent artist who is not supported by any institutions yet. I am hoping that this new residency could be the next step towards to establishing my artistic work in the UK and Europe. 
    • This is only my second solo project, the first one ('My Heart became this Monster') was created in 2012 and has been received incredibly well. Having now received the opportunity of this residency gives me the trust in my creative vision and that I am ready to take the step to create a new solo work.

    Risks

    I am still in the very early stages of this new creative process, therefore the outcome for this solo project is remaining flexible at this stage. 

    Therefore, I decided that this fundraising is designed to support my research and initial rehearsal time only, so that I can start on shaping the outcome into a performance. 


    Other ways to support: 

    If you are unable to support financially, there are other ways to show your support, through sharing and spreading the love for this project. 

    Thank you! 

    Lots of Love and Kisses 

    Hanna

Having now received the opportunity of this residency gives me the trust in my creative vision and that I am ready to take the step to create a new solo work.

 I am still in the very early stages of this new creative process, therefore the outcome for this solo project is remaining flexible at this stage. 
Therefore, I decided that this fundraising is designed to support my research and initial rehearsal time only, so that I can start on shaping the outcome into a performance. 
  
Other ways to support:  If you are unable to support financially, there are other ways to show your support, through sharing and spreading the love for this project. 
Thank you! 

Lots of Love and Kisses Hanna

story:
Bringing Real Stories of Work and Life to the Stage

We are Melissa and Kate, and we tell real stories based on real events. In January 2015, we started The Perpetual Visitors Theatre Company LLC to do just that. We believe in the power of storytelling to foster connection and in the power of theatre to spark conversation.

We're fascinated by that fact that the first question we always seem to ask one another is, "What do you do?" Are our jobs all others see of us? We just completed 40 interviews with people from all walks of life for our company's first full-length play about how what we do for a living shapes the rest of our lives. We asked them what they do, how they are perceived because of it, and what they value most in their lives.

From these questions, people shared amazing stories -- about their dreams, about feeling invisible, about starting over, and about searching for employment and themselves. What began as a conversation about the work we do is woven into a larger story about economics, generation gaps, culture, identity, the definition of success, and ultimately what it means to both make a living and create a life. Click here to read more about this play.

We are eager to share these stories in Boston this October, but we can't do it alone. We are $1500 away from being able to produce a staged reading of our play, and we need your help to bring these stories to life.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1500 to help cover the cost of insurance and space rental for three performances this fall. Every dollar we get toward our goal helps to move these stories from the page to the stage! If we reach part but not all of our goal, we will still stage our show, but will limit the number of performances.

With a $10 donation, you'll get a big thank you (on Facebook, Twitter, or our favorite, via snail mail. Supporter's choice.) For $25, you'll be listed as a supporter in the show's program. With a $50 donation, you'll get a free ticket to the show in October. And for $100, you'll get a signed copy of the script. All donations -- of every amount -- help bring this play to life and start a conversation about who we are because of and beyond our jobs. #morethanwhatIdo

Our campaign ends June 19!

Become Part of Our Community

Above everything, we want to build a community -- of storytellers, of Visitors, and of neighbors. Connect with us on Facebook or Twitter, and sign up for our newsletter to receive info about upcoming performances, tickets and casting calls. We hope to see you in October for the show.

And please help spread the word about our Campaign using the Indiegogo share tools on this page!

story:
Can't Spell Right!

Hi there! My name is Mark, and I'm taking a play I wrote up to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival for the first time with my theatre company, Herald Theatre.

The play we're taking up is called 'Can't Spell Right', and it's about witches in love. 

Andrew and Lewis are two 20-year-old housemates. Only they're witches. Pretty powerful witches. But despite his magical talent, Andrew still has trouble wooing Nick. When he and Lewis try to summon Gazerath, the Spirit of Love to help Andrew win Nick's heart, they accidentally summon the flamboyant Gazra, the Spirit Queen of Sickness and Health. Andrew's plans to woo Nick go hilariously awry in this comedy of errors that features magic, spirits and a colourful cast. And like anything involving magic, absolutely anything can happen.

The theatre company and cast are student run, and while this may sound off putting, 'Can't Spell Right' is going to be our first step into the professional theatre world, and we want it to be the best it can possibly be. Your contributions to our campaign will be an incredible help.

What We Need & What You Get

The funding will go towards helping pay for our venue deposit and towards our advertising costs. We're paying our accommodation and travel expenses ourselves, along with using prop and costume resources that we have already found. The money we raise here will help us advertise our show, print out program copies, fliers and posters, and get in as large an audience as possible. It will also go to help paying the larger of two deposits our production is required to pay for by the hosting venue.

As an upcoming theatre company, we don't have many perks to offer our funders, but we can guarantee you credit in our programmes, signed copies of our posters and DVD copies of our filmed performance. For our larger contributors, we'll also change a character's name to one of your choosing, within reason.

We've picked the flexibility payment method, so even if we don't reach our target funds, we'll use as much money as possible towards paying our costs while still aim to reward our funders. 

Risks & Challenges

We understand that investing in an art is already a daunting business, especially with newcomers and students. However, we are all dedicated drama students who have a long history of performances and production roles under our belts in semi-professional settings. Between us, our production team has worked on over 20 shows, along with our actors having credits in multiple shows and performances over the years.

Our plan is based on finding cheap ways of achieving high-quality results, and not focusing on spending as much money as possible to become successful.

Thank you for reading this far. We hope you consider funding us. 

Mark.

story:
Mother Mary is a biography of a family adapting to change and loss. When Mary awakens from a coma after a debilitating accident, her husband and children must learn to take care of the woman who once took care of them. The dancers symbolize members of the family learning to function after the dissolution of their household. This dance is choreographed by Julie-Ann Gambino and her dancers: Hannah Cavallaro, Colleen Griffin, Yoshie Fujimoto Kateada, Maddie Matuska and Mia Simonovic. The music is composed by Christian Hasselberger AKA Alder.

We need your help to raise $3000, enough to pay the artists $10 an hour for the 50 hours of work they have contributed to make this possible. 

6 artists X 50 hours= 300 X $10 an hour= $3000

The premiere is Wednesday, April 13th followed by a show on Thursday, April 14th both at 8:00 PM at SafeHouseArts in San Francisco. With less than a month to the show, we need your help. Thank you!

story:
What is this "Hamlet" you speak of?

Hamlet is one of, if not the most beloved, critiqued, and discussed pieces of literature that exist in the English language. Director Penny Burgess has been enamored of the piece since high school, when it was the only assigned reading she read all the way through. Hamlet is a humorous, dramatic, and heart-wrenching exploration of the timeless themes of trust, madness, secrecy, and the dilemma of "to be or not to be", and we are proud to bring it to life on the stage where it belongs.

This group of young actors takes on Hamlet in a time where nothing is secret and everything is public, trust is a long-gone concept, and mental illness remains misunderstood by many. In this production we hope to remind the audience of the humanity and reality of these characters, and in turn, remind the audience of the shared experience of humanity between us all.

Our Cast: Ellie Aspinall, Maddy Boles, Corinne Britti, Ethan Jovanovic, Nell Kessler, Cameron Noble, Lexie Shoaibi, Laura Troshynski

Producer/Director: Penny Burgess
Stage Manager: Wren Sutterfield

Where's my money going?

All of our raised funds will be going towards making this production happen, the majority of which will be put towards the rental of a performance venue and rehearsal space, with a bit going towards props, costumes, and marketing. In general though we are trying to keep this as low-cost as possible!

What are these delightful perks?

Aren't they just delightful? I'm going to assume they're mostly self-explanatory, but the Drunk Final Dress will be on Thursday, April 28th in the evening. The cast will be a tad inebriated (I'll let them decide what "a tad" means for them); you do not have to be, but you are welcome to be! And by drunk we do not mean wasted, but if you want to have a couple drinks and yell at the actors, you would not be chided. Chid? Chidded?

I'm broke, what can I do to help?

We totally understand, and we would greatly appreciate your help! If you could share this on Facebook, Twitter, or wherever it is the kids these days post about their everyday lives, that would be fantastic! We'd also love to see you in the audience when we perform at the end of April.

story:
Who We Are

If you haven't seen us yet, you're in for a real treat! We're IRTE - the Improvisational Repertory Theatre Ensemble - an award-winning company of improvisational actors, producers, and directors who create a full season of original, character-driven, improvised comedy shows. 

2016 marks the fifth season for IRTE and we are excited to bring you 4 original and hilarious shows this season at our home in the heart of New York City, the Producer's Club.


The 2016 Ensemble

Robert Baumgardner, William Berg, Nannette Deasy, Jamie Maloney, Curt Dixon

What People Are Saying

IRTE has been well reviewed. Critics have had the following to say:

"Completely unique...I died of laughter... If you're looking for a good night of fun, definitely check out IRTE!" - Heather Boddy, THESPI-HONEST

"...surprise-a-minute..." - Jay Lloyd, CBS Philly, KYW News Radio

"...their fun was infectious." - Geri Silver, Theatre is Easy

"It's remarkable how this ensemble is able to take the random given circumstances and masterfully weave them into a narrative by the end of the show... All the cast members have stage presence and you enjoy watching their creativity and spontaneity at work." - Lillian Rodriguez, Film Annex


The Part You Can Play

Producing independent theater in New York City is neither cheap nor easy. At IRTE we work hard to make our season something special for all involved. In addition to developing, performing in and directing each show, our ensemble members also manage every other aspect of running a professional theater company, including video production, photography, promotions and marketing, handling our own budgeting and other operational tasks. 

Your donations help make all of this possible. IRTE is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of IRTE must be made payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


More On The Numbers

In 2015, our total expenses came to $7,413, which covered our regular season of 5 productions, each with 3 performances, plus additional productions at the Del Close Marathon and the Dream Up Festival here in New York City. This year our 4 original productions will enjoy 4 performances each, and we'll be adding even more productions at independent theater festivals both in New York and out of state.

More performances means more opportunities for audiences to enjoy what we do, and it also means more money going out for renting studio space for rehearsals ($170 for each production in 2015) and renting theater space and paying our tech crew for performances ($630 for each production in 2015). This does not include costs for costumes, props, and travel expenses - all of which are covered by the performers (us!).

Here's a snapshot of how we covered our expenses last year:   


11% of our expenses made up our shortfall.

We'd love to see our shortfall disappear!


Immediate And Long-Term Benefits

Since our inception in 2012, IRTE has received increased recognition from the downtown New York theater community and the national improvisation scene.  We love what we do. And we love to share what we do not only with an ever-growing audience, but also with our fellow artists. To that end we are delighted to share performance opportunities with other artists by hosting musical guests and inviting guest improvisers to join us for our shows. 

Your donations help us not only mount a successful new season but also enable us to continue to develop this artistic community as we move closer to our long-term mission of a fully sustainable professional improvisational theater company with a year-round season and a permanent home; thus bringing improvisation to a broader theater-going audience.

We are so grateful for the impact our donors had on our 2015 season and for everyone who came out to see our shows, and we can't wait to get even bigger and better as we create a completely new season in 2016!

Here's What You Get When You Give

The 2016 Season!
Visit our website for more info and to purchase tickets, season passes and more!


We're excited to bring you a complete season of new works in our signature IRTE style!

Join us at the Producer's Club in the heart of New York City's theater district with reasonable ticket prices and no two-drink minimums!

Donate now - no amount is too small - and be a part of it all!



Other Ways To Show Your Support

  • Spread the word...Share this campaign with others!
  • Come see our shows, we love our audience!
  • Donate your time - let us know if you'd like to work box office or tech for us!
  • Laugh at us (that's why we do what we do)!

story:
You can make a difference to dance!

Kenneth Walker Dance Project is local. The dancers are local. The founder and choreographer is local. This is a contemporary ballet company that you can call your own.

And for you, KWDP has embarked on an incredible journey, to create our largest and most ambitious work to date, a re-imagining of  Vivaldi's The Four Seasons.

This ballet is being created because of the incredible artists of KWDP. The company members get the remarkable experience of having a new work created on them. There is almost nothing more exciting for an artist!

KWDP can't wait to perform The Seasons for you this fall at our annual performance. Be a part of the process! By contributing, YOU are creating a new ballet!

The Impact

Our version will be the biggest ballet we've ever created.  This foray is our largest expenditure in time and energy in creating a work of art. When we complete the dance we will have completed a new way of visioning contemporary ballet.

Risks & Challenges

Our artists are being challenged with learning four times the amount of choreography we normally tackle and our designers will be creating four times the amount of lighting and costume designs for our new project. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your social network to help make this vision come true.  Buy a ticket early to help us sell-out this amazing venture. 
Tell a friend to join you at this performance.

When will you see this new work?

We can't wait to premiere it for you August 13 and 14 at the Martha Knoebel Dance Theater in Long Beach! Tickets go on sale soon!
