story:
Containertopia and the artists behind it

This apartment has everything! Song. Dance. Jokes. Zoning laws. Environmental collapse. Housing crises. Existential crises. A game show. A therapy session. All this in under 250 square feet.

America has a fever for tiny living. Whether out of economic necessity or cultural zeitgeist, the micro-apartment has captured the public imagination. Is it salvation or shtick? A new model for sustainability or crass profiteering?

CONTAINERTOPIA is a 21st-century take on vaudeville that looks at the ever-shrinking living spaces that New Yorkers submit themselves to. With synthesizer-heavy Weimar cabaret tunes, original music, and projection-based set design, our multimedia cabaret explores and exposes the popular trend of tiny living. What afforded to us is affordable?

We, Sam Day Harmet and Julia Frey, have collaborated on a number of projects while pursuing our Master of Fine Arts degrees in Performance and Interactive Media Arts (PIMA) at Brooklyn College.  We'll be performing Containertopia at the Jalopy Theater April 28th, 29th, and 30th with John Gasper and Alex Kramer.

Containertopia is produced as part of our thesis, and is also the first official project of Casual FreyDay, a producing partnership that pools our respective experience in music (Sam) and theater (Julia) to concoct works that bring new media technology into live performance. We plan to continue making more work together beyond these April performances.  In order to keep going, we need your help!

Our needs...

To get Containertopia onto the stage of the Jalopy Theater, we need your support. Here's a breakdown of the costs so you can see where your donation will go:

  • $600 - performers and staff
  • $500 - wood, hardware, and paint
  • $400 - QLab license rental
  • $350 - wireless microphones
  • $220 - printing and publicity
  • $200 - costumes
  • $180 - truck rental/transportation
  • $30 - rainstick (yup.)

The above list is simply for the initial production of Containertopia. We hope to continue producing work. If we surpass our fundraising goal of $2,500, the money would go to set and prop storage, transportation, and future rehearsal space.

...your perks!

As a thank you for your support of CONTAINERTOPIA, we are offering:

  • Early bird ticketing
  • Show Soundtrack
  • T-Shirts

​

Here's how you can make a difference...

You have been watching us for years as performers -- now help us as we make our own work from the ground up.

The Performance and Interactive Media Arts (PIMA) M.F.A. is an internationally celebrated program. It is also woefully underfunded. The budget we receive from Brooklyn College would not be enough for one month's rent, let alone enough to produce a professional performance in New York City. And as we are affiliated with an educational program, we are ineligible for state and local grants for the arts. So we need help from individual donors.

We are reaching out to our friends and colleagues who have watched us and worked with us over the years to support us as we produce our own original performance. Containertopia is not simply the culmination of our graduate education -- it's the next stage of our careers as creators and producers of innovative, interdisciplinary performance.

...and not all donations are monetary!

If you cannot donate your hard-earned dollars at this time, we completely understand. Here are other ways you can help:

  • Please invite your friends to the show! Email containertopia@gmail.com for information on group discounts.
  • Do you have a wireless microphone or a Chilean rainstick? How about a free pair of hands April 28-30? Email containertopia@gmail.com with information on what you can supply as an in-kind donation.
  • Spread the word on social media! Send our fundraiser video to people you know (https://vimeo.com/206751909), share our Facebook invites to the show, and visit our Tumblr for behind-the-scenes shenanigans (https://containertopia.tumblr.com)
story_txt:
Containertopia and the artists behind it
This apartment has everything! Song. Dance. Jokes. Zoning laws. Environmental collapse. Housing crises. Existential crises. A game show. A therapy session. All this in under 250 square feet.
America has a fever for tiny living. Whether out of economic necessity or cultural zeitgeist, the micro-apartment has captured the public imagination. Is it salvation or shtick? A new model for sustainability or crass profiteering?
CONTAINERTOPIA is a 21st-century take on vaudeville that looks at the ever-shrinking living spaces that New Yorkers submit themselves to. With synthesizer-heavy Weimar cabaret tunes, original music, and projection-based set design, our multimedia cabaret explores and exposes the popular trend of tiny living. What afforded to us is affordable?
We, Sam Day Harmet and Julia Frey, have collaborated on a number of projects while pursuing our Master of Fine Arts degrees in Performance and Interactive Media Arts (PIMA) at Brooklyn College.  We'll be performing Containertopia at the Jalopy Theater April 28th, 29th, and 30th with John Gasper and Alex Kramer.

Containertopia is produced as part of our thesis, and is also the first official project of Casual FreyDay, a producing partnership that pools our respective experience in music (Sam) and theater (Julia) to concoct works that bring new media technology into live performance. We plan to continue making more work together beyond these April performances.  In order to keep going, we need your help!
Our needs...

To get Containertopia onto the stage of the Jalopy Theater, we need your support. Here's a breakdown of the costs so you can see where your donation will go:

$600 - performers and staff
$500 - wood, hardware, and paint
$400 - QLab license rental
$350 - wireless microphones
$220 - printing and publicity
$200 - costumes
$180 - truck rental/transportation
$30 - rainstick (yup.)

The above list is simply for the initial production of Containertopia. We hope to continue producing work. If we surpass our fundraising goal of $2,500, the money would go to set and prop storage, transportation, and future rehearsal space.

...your perks!
As a thank you for your support of CONTAINERTOPIA, we are offering:

Early bird ticketing
Show Soundtrack
T-Shirts

​
Here's how you can make a difference...
You have been watching us for years as performers -- now help us as we make our own work from the ground up.
The Performance and Interactive Media Arts (PIMA) M.F.A. is an internationally celebrated program. It is also woefully underfunded. The budget we receive from Brooklyn College would not be enough for one month's rent, let alone enough to produce a professional performance in New York City. And as we are affiliated with an educational program, we are ineligible for state and local grants for the arts. So we need help from individual donors.
We are reaching out to our friends and colleagues who have watched us and worked with us over the years to support us as we produce our own original performance. Containertopia is not simply the culmination of our graduate education -- it's the next stage of our careers as creators and producers of innovative, interdisciplinary performance.
...and not all donations are monetary!
If you cannot donate your hard-earned dollars at this time, we completely understand. Here are other ways you can help:

Please invite your friends to the show! Email containertopia@gmail.com for information on group discounts.
Do you have a wireless microphone or a Chilean rainstick? How about a free pair of hands April 28-30? Email containertopia@gmail.com with information on what you can supply as an in-kind donation.
Spread the word on social media! Send our fundraiser video to people you know (https://vimeo.com/206751909), share our Facebook invites to the show, and visit our Tumblr for behind-the-scenes shenanigans (https://containertopia.tumblr.com)

story:
The INCONGRUENCE Story

THE PLAY

A transgender entertainer named Tammy  takes the audience on a journey into a looking glass of  gender identity. Incongruence: A {trans} Gender Looking Glass, is about the other, or the misfit, whether seen or sensed,  that is reflected in anyone’s mirror.  Tammy's imaginative looking glass memoir weaves itself thru transgender related stories that are provocative, emotionally witty and gritty.  

Public interest in transgender has grown and, as it has been recently noted on the cover of Time Magazine with Laverne Cox,  we are at a "Transgender Tipping Point" in terms of social consciousness .  Our play offers  a wonderful  opportunity to help build awareness for the issues relating to gender identity and gender non-conformity.  It  presents a compelling look into the lives of transgender women and men from a non-satirical point of view and, perhaps,  a shockingly relatable experience for anyone new to the topic and its exploration. 

THE PLAY'S HISTORY

Incongruence was written by first time playwright, Carla Pridgen.  It premiered in Asheville, NC at 35Below (ACT) and was produced by  Different Strokes Performing Arts Collective,  Directed  by C.J Breland.  Stephanie Hickling Beckman is the company's Artistic Director.   

The individual stories in the play were taken from over twenty-five interviews of a diverse cross-section of transgender experience, including parents, siblings, partners, friends — and of course out of  the playwright's  transgender life experience.  These stories were fictionalized and in many cases blended to make a play of interwoven plot lines developed from a treasury of transgender memoir.  

THE PLAY TODAY

Following the play’s world premiere, June 2013,  Ms. Pridgen assigned the rights to Incongruence  to her son, Will Pridgen. (It will not surprise you that Will calls his father, Carla, "Dad"-- publicly.  Carla is cool with that! Well, this will not surprise you AFTER you get to know them!)  As an activist adult child of a transgender parent, Will took his play to New York and to his good friends, Audrey and Bobby Alford, with IVY Theatre Company.  After reading Incongruence,  Mrs. Alford, Founding Member of the company and now Director of Incongruence  said, "This play has potential!"  With good guidance from Audrey, Carla has rewritten the play, and  Mr. Pridgen and Mr. Alford are now co-producing: Incongruence: A {trans} Gender Looking Glass.  

Ivy Theatre Company has begun a new annual venture with the inaugual production of the Trellis Project.   The good folk at Ivy describe it nicely as "a page to stage partnership giving badass playwrights the structure to climb beyond the antiquated hierarchy of commercialism to change the conversation."  We are honored and pleased to be one of the two plays,  with badass, et.al., to be first on The Trellis that is Ivy Theatre! 

To extend this metaphor, this fall  the branches of Incongruence  grew onto the trellis when The 4th Street Theatre, the black box theatre of The New York Theatre Workshop was booked,  the show was cast and production team formed. Carla went to the first rehearsal to meet the cast as a whole, and some individually.  She was there  to hear the play read,  to share the story of the play's development  and something of her journey too.  She did not feel a stranger, not in the least.
THE CAST & COMPANY OF INCONGRUENCE (BA)

Director – Audrey Alford
Ensemble:
Katie Braden
Eddie Capuano
Jesse Geguzis
Kitty Mortland
Jack Sochet*
CeCe Suazo-Augustus
Samantha Elizabeth Turlington
Siobhan Weiss*

Stage Manager – Jordan Bean
Assistant Director – Olivia Clement
Costume Designer – Tristan Raines
Set Designer – Bradley Wehrle
Lighting Designer – Susannah Brown
Sound Designer – Jacob Subotnick


INCONGRUENCE LOOKING FORWARD

Of the play’s first production, key words from the Asheville Citizen-Times review were:  

powerful…  lyrical…  passionate… forceful and moving…  sensitive… veritable showcase of varieties. 

We believe  Incongruence will be those things again and  more refined by the New York experience.  It will not be without light moments and good comedy.  It will be an emotional roller coaster of entertainment.  We certainly  believe it is a fresh approach to an issue of human diversity too often  made trivial and  sensationalized.   There is something for anyone brave enough to pay attention and peer into the looking glass that is, INCONGRUENCE.  


Taking the MIS out of the FIT!  

Where do you fit into this story?   

In  the New York production  nearly 40% of the expense will go to performance space (We are so fortunate... IVY has its own rehearsal space!), approximately 12% will go to actors and 18% for production and design staff. The remaining 30% not only provides the set, costumes and props, but pays for all marketing and  press, including web and funding services.  

The team for this campaign with Cast and Company asks for and appreciates your financial  support: small or large or something in between.

 WHAT'S FITTING SO FAR!

  • A generous donor has stepped up and promised to match every dollar given, dollar-for-dollar, up to $2500. This will double the first $2500 dollars given! So that is potentially half the campaign right from the start! Now that's a fit!
  • We boldly (if not humbly) ask other potential donors of exemplary means to follow the afore mentioned  be... fitting example.
  • Of course please note the PERKS to the right of your screen. Any of these make your fit?
  • One way you can certainly help is spread the word.  That would be very fitting indeed.  FaceBook, Twitter, emails... be bold, go old school and do the town crier bit...  "Oh Yea, Oh Yea!" (Talk about misfit!)  A better fit is found using the Indiegogo share tools! Oh yeah!
  • Your imagination. Let us know your ideas. We'll be adding them right here.

 What's Next? 

Please check back with us often and at least weekly for video updates and news. You never know what or who might turn up!

story:
Summary
Preston J. Arrow-weed has written a dozen plays with Native American themes; most have been produced on stage.  This project will record readings of five of these plays and make them available for radio, web, and MP3 formatting.  More and more Native communities are listening to radio for information, news and entertainment.  Relevant broadcasting is very important for many rural Native American communities.  These plays bring relevant stories to entertain and provoke discussions of relevant topics such as drug and alcohol abuse to Native American communities.  History from the Native American perspective is rare in this country and these plays provide that view.  On stage these plays have been a hit with all audiences. These plays will be of interest to the general public as well.  Funding for this project will provide funds for sound studio and sound engineers to produce a professional product. Funding will be used to pay college student readers in theater classes and Native American readers as well. 
If you like and enjoy entertainment from Native America, please share this appeal with all your friends and acquaintances.  We will use all the help we can get.

story:
Macbeth

Directed and Produced by David Shopland
10th February - 1st March, LOST Theatre, London
4th - 7th March, Rondo Theatre, Bath
CLICK HERE FOR MORE DETAILS

The Project

This production of Macbeth has been gestating slowly for the best part of 2014. Starting life as an idea between its director and lead actor, the project has now grown into an ambitious and exciting exploration of one of Shakespeare's most complex works. 

For centuries, The Scottish Play has proved to be one of the most popular of Shakespeare’s tragedies. A cautionary tale of ambition and madness, Macbeth is a story filled with sex, magic, violence and death that has set alight the imaginations of millions of theatregoers across the globe. The classic story of free will versus fate has been played out in many different concepts, but this production aims to take the text back to its roots in a minimal and brutal adaptation.

We are aiming to create a sparse and gripping view of the play through the eyes of a grieving couple. This is not a story about war and witches, but the heartbreaking destruction of a marriage. It is a 400 year old domestic drama that highlights the same base emotions we all feel throughout our lives. This play's horror lies in its humanity.

The show opens at the LOST Theatre in Stockwell, South West London; running from 10th February - 1st March 2015. The show will then transfer to The Rondo Theatre in Bath for an additional week from 4th - 7th March.

David Shopland - Producer/Director

David studied at the prestigious Rose Bruford School of Theatre and Performance, gaining a First Class BA Honours in American Theatre Arts. Whilst in training, David pursued his passion for directing even further, and was lucky enough to direct several shows in both London and the United States.

As Creative Director Blind Tiger, David has directed a sold out production of A Life in Monochrome at Ovalhouse Theatre in January 2012, which then subsequently transferred to The Space Arts Centre the following July. David also directed Blind Tiger's Cinderella: The Anti Panto at The Leicester Square Theatre in December of 2012 and The Little Mermaid at Riverside Studios over the Christmas period of 2013 - 14. 

As a freelance director, David directed 20 teenagers in Julius Caesar and a collection of David Mamet one-acts for Rose Bruford's International Summer School in August 2012. At the beginning of 2013, David became involved in directing and producing an inaugural New Writing portion of the Bath Fringe Festival, entitled 20:20 Vision. Most recently, David  also directed the world premier of An Idle World at Trafalgar Studios in the West End in July 2013.


How You Can Help

As this production is being produced on a miniscule budget without any public funding, we are relying on private donations and local fundraising to make the production the best it possibly can be. 

"I have implemented public crowdfunding campaigns for the majority of my productions, and always feel incredibly overwhelmed by the positive responses from friends, family and theatre fanatics in helping create a production from scratch. I am a big believer in collaboration through art, and greatly appreciate this platform exists; allowing anyone to be able to watch how their contributions directly impact the creation of new work in the theatre" 

- David Shopland (Sole Producer/Director)

The £500 were are aiming to raise will go directly towards securing the location for our intensive 12 day rehearsal process. We are additionally trying to raise another £1000 from other sources to cover our production costs (set, costume, props) and marketing expenses.

Spread The Word

We completely appreciate that many people who may want to help us may not be financially able to. We would be grateful if you could spread the word about this production of Macbeth via any and all social media platforms and through word of mouth. 

Thank you for your time and contributions, and we look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
About Poor Richard's Players

OUR MISSION:  Challenge the artist. Challenge the audience.

For the last 5 years, Poor Richard's Players has been producing important, challenging, fun, and award winning theatre throughout Las Vegas.  We were voted the "Best" at the Las Vegas Fringe Festival three years in a row.  At the inaugural Valley Theatre Awards, we won Best Production, Best Director, Best Actor, and Best Sound Design for our production of RED by John Logan.  Some of our other accomplishments include "Best of 2013" by Las Vegas Weekly, "Best of 2012" by CityLife Magazine, multiple nominations from the Review Journal's Best of Las Vegas, and Downtown Zen said, "Poor Richard's Players is the future."  Well, the future looks bright for us as we move on to our next big challenge.  A challenge that we want you to be a part of.  It is time for us to open our own theatre!

It is difficult being a gypsy theatre company, moving from venue to venue, not knowing where our next show will be, and producing theatre in other companies' venues comes with its own obstacles.  We want to produce bigger and better shows deserving of our audience.  With a little help from you, we can make that happen.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $15,000 towards converting and opening Poor Richard's Playhouse, our new venue.  Every little bit helps toward theater staples such as chairs, drapery, audio/visual equipment, and future show production costs.  This will ensure that our shows are offering the very best in Theatre technology. We hope to open by August 2015.

We are offering great perks for the Theatre-going audience, including tickets to our Opening Season shows that will feature some of the best productions by Poor Richard's Players:  5 Lesbians Eating a Quiche, The Bible: The Complete Word of God (Abridged), and Dick Johnson: Private Eye.  For those that are feeling more generous, we are also offering a permanent fixture in our facility to commemorate your contribution to PRP.

The Impact

The local Theatre community is growing strong.  Poor Richard's Players has played a part in that growth and we want to keep providing the quality live Theatre experience that Las Vegas has come to expect from its producers.  Poor Richard's Playhouse will also host other Theatre and arts companies, as well as feature classes and workshops in a variety of performing arts including acting, writing, improv and musical improv, and more.
Also, as the hosts of The LVTAP Show (a local theatre podcast), The PRP Team will be implementing a fully functional recording studio to suit both the needs of the podcast as well as the sound design and studio recording needs of the theatre community.

Risks & Challenges

There is no proper reward without a little risk.  We cannot open Poor Richard's Playhouse without the support of friends, family, and the Theatre community.  If we don't make our goal, we may not be able open on our expected start date.  It will take a lot more than just our own family and friends to support this campaign.  But we are determined to make this a reality and we know we can do it with everyone's help.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word.  Share this link on social media and continue growing Las Vegas as a Theatre destination.  And be on the look out for Poor Richard's Players productions, including our show at this year's Vegas Fringe Festival!

Poor Richard's Players is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

  Other Ways You Can HelpPlease spread the word.  Share this link on social media and continue growing Las Vegas as a Theatre destination.  And be on the look out for Poor Richard's Players productions, including our show at this year's Vegas Fringe Festival!Poor Richard's Players is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization.

story:
The Max Factor Factor

We're making no bones about this Indiegogo campaign:  we're trying to pack the houses for the first two weekends, and so we're offering great perks for contributors.  Get a load of this:  Donate $24, get a free ticket! (regular price: $34)...!  Donate $96, get four free tickets worth $136 -- hotcha!  It's like a free $40; PLUS seeing a great show.

See, we're cocky that word of mouth is going to be fantastic, so we're trying to get folks talking about the show as soon as we can.

This Indiegogo campaign is about PRE-SALES.  Full-priced tickets go on sale to the public June 26th, and our great deals end -- after the Indiegogo campaign ends, our $34 tickets are going to cost...$34.

This campaign is offering perks for only the previews and first TWO weekends.  If you're not available to see the show until the third weekend, well, feel free to make a donation through Indiegogo, of course -- but we'd probably advise you instead just to visit our website www.nmi.org, and click "send me a reminder when tickets are available for the final three weeks of performances."

What the musical is about

It’s 1936; the golden age of Hollywood, and two rival movie studios are in a heated battle for survival when their opposing leading men,  Lance Grant and Hoyt Baxter, fall in love.  Reminiscent of screwball comedies of the past, this tuneful new musical tells the story of two movie stars who suddenly find themselves having to navigate a dizzying world of artifice, backstabbing, lavender weddings, double-crossing starlets, and a moral crusader from the Legion of Rectitude, making it increasingly more difficult to hold on to the one real thing each has ever found.

Written by Adrian Bewley (Book), Joe Blodgett (Music), and Chana Wise (Lyrics), it’s being produced by New Musicals, Inc, the brand-new production wing of the Academy for New Musical Theatre, in association with Celebration Theatre.

The show runs for five weeks only, this August, at the NoHo Arts Center.

If you buy your ticket in advance, as part of our pre-sales campaign, you’ll save almost 30%!  For instance, save $20 on a pair of $34 tickets!

Who are we?

"The Max Factor Factor" was developed by the New Musicals Initiative for Celebration Theatre over the past couple of seasons and now that Celebration has moved out of its theatre, we're stepping in to produce this wonderful new musical this summer at the NoHo Arts Center in North Hollywood, CA. And Celebration's own Michael Shepperd is at the helm as director!

PRODUCTION DATES:

August 1-31st. 2014

Friday & Saturday evenings at 8pm

Sunday matinees at 3pm

at the Noho Arts Center

11136 Magnolia Blvd.

North Hollywood, California

air-conditioned and plush

               

The $1500 goal

We're hoping to sell 500 tickets in the first two weekends, which would translate into FAR more than our $1500 goal.  But not to worry, even after we've made our goal, you'll still be able to get your tickets for $24 instead of $34.

WHY THIS MUSICAL?

We love this musical.  It's fun, tuneful, fast-paced (VERY fast-paced in spots!), and it has a warm message of hope handed down to us from silenced movie actors in the 1930's. 

We've workshopped this musical from its very earliest days, when it was only an idea in the minds of the producers at the Celebration Theatre, through the enthusiastic and thorough first draft, to the heart-stopping, spontaneous performance during Stages Musical Theatre Festival in 2013, to its current state of musical theatre perfection. The Max Factor Factor is a loving testament to the American Musical artform, and perfect fare for a midsummer evening in Los Angeles.

Come join us early.  And save a bunch of cash while you're at it.

story:
Hello!

{Your Name Here} is proud to present a workshop production of Gray written and directed by Daniel Talbott. This workshop will star Chris Bellant, Will Pullen, and Samantha Soule.

After receiving a small public reading in November, Daniel and his cast will be developing the piece even further with a fully realized workshop this January.

{Your Name Here} is a Queer Theater Company based here in New York that seeks to create and support art that empowers, inspires, investigates, and celebrates Queer identity.


Where the Money Goes

We are seeking help from you for the cost of space, period costumes, set and props and a small stipend to pay our amazing actors and stage manager. With your help, we can make a period specific workshop in the Susan Batson Space.

 
The Impact

As long-time supporters of Talbott’s work, we at {Your Name Here} are very excited to bring his new piece Gray to audiences in January. This play follows three people at the turn of the century as they struggle to survive in Monterey, California, amidst strident poverty, loss, and unrequited love. This play is brutal, beautiful and honest, and truly anyone who wishes to support something different and edgy should get behind {Your Name Here} in supporting this piece.

 
Your Help

Anything you can spare will help to bring this beautiful project to fruition. If you cannot contribute, you can still help by sharing our campaign on social media. Thank you for your support in developing new work.

Happy Holidays!


-The {Your Name Here} family

story:
Short Summary  

La Paloma Prisoner is a new play by playwright Raquel Almazan, directed by Charlotte Brathwaite which will premiere at the Pershing Square Signature Center in April 2015 as part of Columbia University School of the Arts  2014-2015 Columbia Stages Season.

La Paloma Prisoner is a multi-disciplinary play about the reclamation of identity by incarcerated women in the Colombian prison system.  The plot follows an incarcerated killer nicknamed “La Paloma” who transcendentally soars beyond physical and societal barriers to avenge the raped women of Bogota.  Based on the true story of a group of female inmates selected every year as beauty queen contestants at the Buen Pastor prison, this new play interweaves the ritualistic journey of a “parade of prisoners” with Colombia’s social, political, and spiritual history. 

Your generous contribution will directly fund this ambitious and socially relevant undertaking.  All money from this campaign will be used to purchase production materials and offer a modest stipend to the incredibly talented artists that have dedicated their craft to fully realizing this dramatically poetic undertaking.  Simply put, every single dollar donated directly impacts and enhances our ability to present a polished and professional premiere workshop production.


What We Need & What You Get 

To realize the vision for the play, our goal is to raise $2000 by April 1, 2015.

In thanks for your generosity, we are excited to offer you the following perks:

$10 - Receive a personal “Shout out” on our Facebook page and our gratitude for life.

$25 – Your name listed in the program as a benefactor of La Paloma Prisoner.

$50 – Receive a signed copy of the program by the playwright.  Plus the aforementioned perks!

$100 -- Receive two complimentary tickets to the performance of your choice of La Paloma Prisoner at Signature Theatre.

$250 – Receive a Limited edition La Paloma Prisoner show poster signed by the company. Plus the aforementioned perks!

$500 -- An invite to opening night party with dinner/drinks and artistic team!  Plus the aforementioned perks!

$1000 – Receive a copy of the unpublished script, signed by the playwright, and four complimentary tickets to a performance of your choice.  Plus the aforementioned perks!


The Impact 

The realization of this interdisciplinary staging; combining the alchemy of butoh dance, inspired ritual movements, and lyrical bi-lingual text will tackle the taboo issues of mass incarceration in prison complexes, patriarchal violence, and the haunting media presence of rape culture.  The play will be presented as part of the New Plays Now festival taking place at the Pershing Square Signature Center in New York City April 2015.  But in order to achieve the vision of this play from the page to the stage we need your support!

Raquel has been working with women in prison as an arts facilitator and as an activist organizer for issues of incarceration for ten years. In 2010 she attended the beauty pageant in Bogota, Colombia at the Buen Pastor Prison, where participants shared their process and narratives. This new project (Several years of development La Paloma Prisoner) provides a space for dialogue, exchange, and future actions in the current landscape of mass incarceration. 

Thank you for caring about continuing the conversation of this marginalized and oppressed culture.  And most of all, thank you for supporting this exciting original and challenging new work!

Besos,

La Familia de La Paloma Prisoner 


Come see the show!  

La Paloma Prisoner will be performed at the Pershing Square Signature Center in Manhattan for three limited performances.  We will send out a link soon for reserving tickets:

Performance times are:

APRIL – Friday 24th @ 2pm

APRIL – Friday 24th @ 8pm

APRIL – Saturday 25th @ 2:30pm

story:
To our dearest family and friends,

Justin, Amanda & Sharon have been invited through the University of Hawaii at Mānoa's Theatre program to participate in the American College Theater Festival (ACTF) in February 2015. They have been nominated to audition for the Irene Ryan Acting Scholarship. "The Irene Ryan Acting Scholarships provide recognition, honor, and financial assistance to outstanding student performers wishing to pursue further education. The Irene Ryan Foundation awards sixteen regional and two national scholarships annually."

It is a great honor to have been chosen from a pool of two extremely talented casts. We do not see our nomination as something to be taken lightly. It is our dream to attend the festival and represent the strengths of our beloved theatre department, school and island. "The Acting program at UHM allows the serious acting student to study forms and methods from the broadest array available at any university. Nowhere else can actors get the breadth and depth of theatrical experience found in the Acting program at UHM."

However, due to the nature of being college students, we are finding it difficult to gather together funds for our plane tickets. The amount listed includes our 3 plane tickets as well as 3 additional ones for our scene partners. Any help you feel you are capable of giving would be beyond appreciated. Even if you feel unable to make a monetary contribution, your help spreading the word by sharing this campaign is huge.

We could not be here if it were not for the support of our loved ones. Please forgive us for asking for your support once more.

With much aloha to all and mahalo plenty,

Justin, Amanda & Sharon

ACTF Region 8 Website:

http://kcactf-8.org

Irene Ryan Acting Scholarship Website:

http://kcactf.org/KCACTF.ORG_NATIONAL/Irene_Ryans.html

Department of Theatre and Dance at UH Mānoa, Kennedy Theatre Website:

http://hawaii.edu/kennedy/

story:
God Complex Theatre is committed to delivering innovative theatre through stories that explore the darker side of humanity and give us permission to forgive ourselves.  As we eavesdrop on the daily lives of characters who struggle with their human failings, we cannot help but laugh, although it may be somewhat taboo to do so. In the end, the greatest celebration of all is that we are all human.

Under the artistic direction of Victoria Wells-Smith, God Complex Theatre humbly requests your financial donations to support company operations.  Donations in any amount will be gratefully appreciated.  As they say in the theatre business, “there are no small roles!”

Any contributions of $250 and over will receive digital video recognition at the first show being staged by God Complex Theatre. 

The inaugural production, Tickle My Bedroom Fish, is a one-act play that premieres at the Barbara Barrett Theatre at the Arts and Culture Centre in St John’s, Newfoundland, on February 10, 2015 and runs until February 15 for an 8-show run.

story:
A Wrinkle in Time

Over 50 years after it was originally published, Madeleine L'Engle's classic story of magic and self-discovery has proven to endure the test of time. Lipstick Theatre is proud to present John Glore's adaptation of A Wrinkle in Time this winter on Northwestern University's campus site-specifically in the Seabury Great Room. We are interested in taking this space, which has never been used in a theatrical setting, and transforming it into someplace extraordinary that enhances our story.

Our Team

Produced by Elizabeth Wigley and Directed by Bex Ehrmann

Designers: Tatyana Aravena, Ryan Anderson, Emily Koller, James Wang, Cecilia Pappalardo, Zachary Barr, Katelyn Buchta, Abby Durgan, and Greer DuBios

Marketing Team: Lauren Stremmel, Yagmur Tok, Collin Rice, Nathan Lamp

Cast: Amanda Landis, Kali Skatchke, Daniel Stompor, Abby Weissman, Nat Kier, Rachel Meloan

What We Need

Making this show come to life will take a lot of work- your donation will go towards a number of design and marketing efforts including:

  • Lights and a projector
  • Sound equipment
  • A four-posted structure
  • A webbed canopy to project on
  • Costumes and props, some everyday and some fantastical
  • Flyers and programs
  • Promotional photographs
  • And more!

But WHY?

This story is universal, everyone has some relationship with it- we want to explore how we can cater to a specifically college-aged audience. At it's heart, this is a story about figuring out who you are, where you fit in the world, and learning how to trust yourself, and that's an important story for everyone to hear. We're working in conjunction with the L'Engle estate, the Northwestern Alumni Association (L'Engle's husband, Hugh Franklin, was an NU alumni!), and YOU in order to make it happen.

If you can't donate, there are plenty of other ways to help us out! Share this campaign with your friends and family- and come see the show!

Seabury Great Room

600 Haven St., Evanston, IL 60208

Thursday, February 27th at 8 PM

Friday, February 28th at 8 PM and 11 PM

Saturday, March 1st at 8 PM and 11 PM

story:
Deena Levy (www.deenalevy.com) is the artistic director and master teacher of Deena Levy Theatre Studio - where she has been teaching and directing actors how to “unlock the secrets” for 23 years.

Introducing:

The Deena Levy Theatre Studio

“The person you truly are is a thousand times more interesting than any character you could ever play.” - Constantin Stanislavski


The Deena Levy Theatre Studio is known for giving some of the best performance showcases in New York City, hands-down. Some of the actors who have studied at DLTS are Channing Tatum (Foxcatcher, 21 Jump Street), Juliana Margulies (The Good Wife), Kim Dickens (Gone Girl, Treme), Mark Valley (Crisis, Body of Proof).

Over the last 15 years DLTS has produced four themed original plays that celebrate the actor as writer/performer:

Child’s Play, Small Circle of Friends (Kim Dickens/Mark Valley), You/Actor (documentary aired on Bravo & film festivals), New York/Solo (a highly acclaimed ode to 9/11).


Why “My Technology?” 

“My technology” is a funny production that is dangerously relevant. We are not going to spend all of our time lambasting the evils of Facebook addiction, or the fact that the quick fix of Internet porn is threatening to destroy true intimacy and make it a thing of the past. There are two sides to every story and this will glorify technology and its virtues - just a little.

Today, everything is technology, but something is lost. The theme is about getting back to who we are as human beings through ten very personal, poignant and sexy pieces.

"Technology is so amazing, it’s ruining my life.”

What?


The design of the piece is an interactive multi media production that combines entertaining, raw, and truthful stories and original music with some hardcore technological surprises to illustrate the point.

The aim is to raise $15,000+.

We are humbly grateful for any amount of money you can contribute to our production. Of course we are determined to reach our goal and beyond as the cost of production in New York City is growing. Each and every penny will be accounted for as the production expands.  

  • Theatre rental
  • Theatre insurance
  • Rehearsal space
  • Lighting, sound and set design
  • Set and props
  • Light and sound technicians
  • Computer projections and Screen
  • Advertising
  • Flyers and programs, marketing materials
  • Original music
  • Photography
  • Technology!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask your friends and family to get the word out and make some noise.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

The Deena Levy Theatre Studio is known for giving some of the best
performance showcases in New
York City, hands-down. Some of the actors who have studied at DLTS are Channing Tatum (Foxcatcher,
21 Jump Street), Juliana Margulies (The Good Wife), Kim Dickens (Gone Girl,
Treme), Mark Valley (Crisis, Body of Proof).
Over the
last 15 years DLTS has
produced four themed original plays that celebrate the actor as
writer/performer:
Child’s
Play, Small Circle of
Friends (Kim Dickens/Mark Valley), You/Actor
(documentary aired on Bravo & film festivals), New York/Solo (a highly acclaimed ode to 9/11).



Why “My Technology?” 
“My technology” is a funny production
that is dangerously relevant. We
are not going to spend all of our time lambasting the evils of Facebook
addiction, or the fact
that the quick fix of Internet porn is threatening to destroy true intimacy and make it a thing of the past. There are two sides to every story and this will glorify technology and its
virtues - just a little.
Today,
everything is technology, but something is lost. The theme is about getting back to who we are as human
beings through ten very
personal, poignant and sexy pieces.
"Technology is so amazing, it’s
ruining my life.”
What?







The
design of the piece is an interactive
multi media production that combines entertaining, raw, and truthful
stories and original music with
some hardcore technological surprises to illustrate the point.
The aim is to raise $15,000+.
We are
humbly grateful for any amount of money you can contribute to our production. Of course we are determined to reach our goal and beyond as the cost of production in New York City is growing. Each and every penny will be accounted for as the production expands.  



Theatre rental


Theatre insurance


Rehearsal space


Lighting, sound and set design


Set and props


Light and sound technicians


Computer projections and Screen


Advertising


Flyers and programs, marketing materials


Original music


Photography


Technology!


























Other Ways You Can Help
 Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Ask your friends and family to get the word out and make some noise. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Samantha has been performing for 15 years starting off as little Orphan Annie to performing for Royalty to working abroad to achieving a degree in musical theatre to now pursuing her dream of attending the prestigious Royal Conservatoire of Scotland this year. 


This one year course will lead to an abundance of opportunities as well as life-long experience within the perfroming arts industry.
The course is self funded and I require as much extra help as possible so I'm reaching out to the generosity of friends, family, colleagues, acquaintances and strangers. There isn't enough time in the world to express just how much I'd appreciate the support. 
The course costs £11,382 and I'm looking for £2000 to help me get closer to my target. Anything that you have to offer would help me go a long way. 
You can check out my Facebook page and website for more info and updates.

Thanks in advance! :) Xx

story:
Who We Are and What We Do

For the past fourteen years, Thunderbird Theatre has been producing original comedy in the Bay Area. We’re proud of our unique tradition of not only producing original long-form comedy, but of welcoming all who want to participate.

Why We Need Your Help

Because we believe everyone should be able to enjoy theater and comedy, we are committed to keeping ticket prices low. While we enjoy consistently great turnout for our shows, production costs continue to rise.

Each show costs approximately $5000 to produce. Your donations will go towards helping us with our largest expenses:

  • Costumes and Props
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Performance Venue Rental

Please help us continue to produce this work safely and with the quality we would like to continue.

“The Scotland Company”, written by local San Francisco student, Jake Rosenberg, will run October 12th – 27th, 2012 at The EXIT Theatre in San Francisco.

story:
To our supporters:

 

Theater Reconstruction Ensemble has grown tremendously as a company over the past year and a half. In the fall of 2010, we began our journey as a group of theater artists wanting to explore works of the past in new and invigorating ways. Through several workshops, we formed a common language with which we could communicate to ourselves and to our audiences our own personal interpretations of canonical texts that move and inspire us, and that we feel a need to reconnect with as modern artists.

 

In the spring of 2011, we put this newly formed language to use in the mounting of our first full production â€“ Ibsenâ€™s A Dollâ€™s House. In only four performances at The Access Theater Gallery in Lower Manhattan, we managed to move and inspire hundreds of audience members that have since become our most loyal fans. And through the success of A Dollâ€™s House we were given the opportunity to produce our second endeavor â€“ Marloweâ€™s Doctor Faustus â€“ in the fall of 2011 at The Brick in Williamsburg, Brooklyn as part of their curated season. Our second outing proved to be an even greater success, allowing us to continue to grow as artists and as an ensemble. With sold-out performances and rave reviews under our belt, we closed Doctor Faustus feeling a greater sense of unity and artistic satisfaction than ever before.

 

And now we are in the midst of rehearsals for our most ambitious project to date â€“ a mash-up of Chekhovâ€™s Three Sisters and The Seagull written by company member Jaclyn Backhaus appropriately entitled The Three Seagulls, or MASHAMASHAMASHA! being presented at HERE Arts Center in March of 2012. HERE is one of the most prestigious experimental theater venues in the city, and is recognized internationally as a hub for emerging and established theater and performance artists, and we are honored to be a part of their curated season. With a cast of twenty-four actors tackling two of the greatest and most challenging theatrical works ever written, The Three Seagulls promises to be our most ambitious experiment to date.

 

But we need your help to make this show as powerful and innovative as we all believe it can be. Through fundraising campaigns, box office sales, and grants we are financially in the clear for all of our space rentals, including rehearsal space and the venue itself. But we are left with very little for our production costs â€“ including set and prop materials, costume materials, lighting equipment, etc... Our goal is to raise $1000 in the next week to help ensure that our production is as beautiful and inventive as we all know it can be.

 

Weâ€™re now turning to you, our family and supporters, to help us realize this truly epic experiment of ours. Please make a donation. Even the smallest amount goes a long way. Your support now ensures that our company will continue to grow and produce works that inspire others for years to come.

 

And best of all your gift is tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)3 charity.

 

As always, we dedicate our work to you, our fans and supporters.

 

Much love and many thanks!

 

John Kurzynowski

Artistic Director

 

Theater Reconstruction Ensemble

Kate Marvin, Associate Artistic Director

Sydney Matthews, Producing Manager

Celeste Arias, Jaclyn Backhaus, Matt Carr, Stacy Jordan, Anastasia

Olowin, Jon Riddleberger, Eugene Michael Santiago, Ensemble

story:
SEEKING FUNDS TO STUDY IN ITALY

Hello my name is Corky Dominguez this summer 2012 I have the unique opportunity to study theater in Italy, in the Veneto region and more specifically within the historic city centre of Padua. For me, the opportunity to do any study abroad seems so far fetched. I work part time as a theatre teacher and as an independent theatre artist looking for work wherever I can. With these economic times being what they are, it is a constant struggle, challenge and I barley get by. But, being where I am in my life and career I have a strong conviction, a desire, and a gut feeling that “The Body Of Mask” program in Italy is exactly what I need to strengthen my knowledge and understanding of the world of masks as a theatre director, theatre artist and theatre educator. I am starting this campaign to raise the necessary funds to make this trip happen.

 

THE PROGRAM

The dates are July 22 - August 5, 2012. This is an advance hands-on theatre program, that addresses performers, theater teachers, directors, playwrights, designers, choreographers, and musicians wanting to expand their creative tools or wishing to further their experience with physical theater approaches to artistic creation. This journey is not a method, but more importantly a provocation that gives meaning to an individual’s artistic path; it is not just an approach to training actors, but of educating theatre artists with very diverse skill sets.


The program’s approach works toward the teaching of the theater arts as a communal and collaborative experience where each collaborator participates in many aspects of theatre: playwriting, directing, performing, and design. At the same time, the program offers a unique physical experience that challenges the participants to develop their body as a complete instrument. There will be a daily training regimen focused on: voice, spatial awareness, engagement in improvisation, levels of playing and the development of strong working relationships with the audience and the creative ensemble.


By experimenting and creating theater in new ways, participants will gain new tools to use in their own teaching and directing work: from text-based stage work and approaches to film performance, to original theater creation.

 

 

PERSONAL INTEREST AND GOALS

I am extremely interested in my continued experiences with masks in the theatrical field. I had basic training with mask workshops in my studies several years back. I’ve been afforded the opportunity to take what I’ve learned from those workshops along with my background in movement to explore the process of basic neutral mask work. As a play director I have incorporated masks in several productions I’ve directed as well as in my work as a solo performer. I’ve also built and created masks using plaster strips and paper products.

 

My goal is to bring back to my local and artistic communities the knowledge and information learned by teaching workshops to youth and adults. In addition, I am working with playwright, Josefina Lopez, on a theatre piece I will be directing at the end of this year at CASA 0101 Theater located in a predominately Latino community just east of downtown LA. The title of the play is “Piñata Dreams” about a young boy and his connection with his family and their business of making piñatas. Within the play there is the character of the grandmother who makes and creates “alebrijes”. Alebrijes are multi-colored, almost psychedelic colored creatures that are magical and surreal. I think masks will lend itself perfectly in this play. So the plan is to incorporate my basic mask knowledge along with what I will be learning and experiencing from this summer’s program towards this production.

 

PLEASE SUPPORT BY MAKING A FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTION

For some reason masks fell onto my lap and I have since embraced this art form, it has become my passion. I know without a doubt that my experience in Italy will be most inspirational, give me additional tools, will open my eyes, and give me a solid foundation to continue building my work with masks. I will only benefit from a program like this while working and learning from the skilled instructors, and on top of all this, to be able to experience the rich history, tradition and culture of masks and Italy. This will most definitely be a dream come true.

 

If you have the means to contributed and donate funds know that your support will be put to good use and will be extremely appreciated. Spread the word let others know about my campaign.

 

Thank you for your time and generosity!

Corky Dominguez

story:
Our Story

My name is Coronde' Ware and I am producer/actor/playwright.  Back in 2009 there was a conversation between me, my wife, and my brother.  We all love music and my wife loves dance.  So we came up with the idea of a play that tells a story through song, but it is expressed through dance.  This lead to the production, "I Tune into Love".  I feel we are creating a new genre here, and I call it a "dancical" production.  In October 2009, we had our premiere and we got rave reviews from our audience.  The most amazing comment was from a couple that stated, "this is something I have never seen, and this belongs on Broadway".  We're planning on making this production bigger and better, and we need your help to make this a success.  Our next production will be in October 2011.


The Impact

We're looking to raise $10,000 for the production of "I Tune into Love".  All the money donated will go towards paying for rehearsal space, the venue, the dancers, costumes, and marketing.  In the past productions we paid for all the production costs out of pocket.  In order for us to stay within our budget we had to ask people for a lot of favors, and individuals took lower pay for the production to go on.  We would like to change that this time and pay everyone what they are worth. If we do not reach out goal of $10,000 we will continue to press on and still have the show in October of this year.


Also we have some perks so please check them out!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like this production to be a success, but you don't have the funds to donate, it's okay.  Just tell everyone you know about the production.  Spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, My Space, and blogs.  Also you can check us out on our web page of www.oneproduction.org.

story:
ENGLISH TEXT FIRST / SPANISH FOLLOWS *** INGLES PRIMERO / ESPAÑOL SIGUE

 

Here I am!

 

Hello everybody! My name is Miguel. I am a 28 year old dancer and choreographer born in Mexico.

Through dance and movement I have found my own voice as a person and as an artist and I have been able to understand the world.

 

I was recently informed that I have been selected out of 1023 dancers by the Jardin d'Europe/danceWEB Scholarship Programme to take part of a 5 week residency in Vienna (Austria), during ImPulsTanz: International Dance Festival. The danceWEB residency allows 65 professional dancers and choreographers from all over the world to further their training as they continue to develop important networks with renowned artists and are mentored by two of the most influential figures in contemporary dance today.

 

The residency is a great platform for young, vibrant dance artists to continue developing their careers. Part of the danceWEB Scholarship Programme's mission is to include the artist's community in a cultural environment, inviting that community to participate in cultural affairs by supporting the artists and thus being able to help further the development of culture and arts in their own country of residence.

 

Being able to attend danceWEB is very important to me since I believe it holds incredible knowledge and learning. I feel that I will be exposed to new and different people, sharing ways of moving, ways of viewing the world, the way in which we listen, the way in which we move in order to be able to make a tiny shift and change in the world. I believe I would come out of the danceWEB Scholarship Programme with new life injected in me, filled with ideas and hopefully having discovered a new path through which I can continue exploring movement and life, in order to be able to keep doing my dance/performance work.

 

Your help will allow me not only to attend and grow as an artist and as a person, it will give me the opportunity to represent and share a small bit of what Mexican contemporary dance is. I must add that I am one of the only two Mexican dancers to have been selected this year. I believe that finally Mexican contemporary dance is able to be seen abroad, and that Latin artists have a much greater opportunity to participate in a multicultural exchange of movement and ideologies. With your help I will have the opportunity to become a better, fuller, richer dance artist and person.

 

 

Talking $$$

 

The danceWEB Scholarship Programme pays for 2/3 of the full tuition, which is around 6,400 Euros / 8,300 US Dollars. I need to cover the other 1/3 of the tuition, which is 2,150 Euros / 2,800 US Dollars.

I also need to cover my plane tickets from Mexico to Europe and back as well as the expenses for food and other transportation within Vienna.

I have been saving money for this and I have also been applying for grants from my own government and other arts organizations in my country so I can cover part of the tuition fee and the some other expenses. However, I still don't know if they will be able to support me with the money.

With your support I will be able to complete the amount needed so that I can attend danceWEB this summer!!! Any amount helps!!! It can start from 1 dollar and go anywhere, it's up to you!

 

You will be able to help me continue developing my work as a dancer and as a choreographer, getting connected with incredible and important artists from all over the world and take part of this life-changing experience.

 

Thank you so much for reading and for taking the time to watch the video.

If you can't support monetarily, please feel free to spread the word about this campaign to anyone you know and think would be interested in helping me out.

 

Once again, thank you so much!!!

 

 

 

 

ESPAÑOL

 

 

¡Aquí estoy!

 

¡Hola a todos! Mi nombre es Miguel. Soy un bailarín y coreógrafo de 28 años nacido en México.

Por medio de la danza y del movimiento he podido encontrar mi propia voz como persona y como artista y soy capaz de entender al mundo.

 

Recientemente me informaron que de entre 1023 bailarines y coreógrafos profesionales de todo el mundo fui seleccionado por Jardin d'Europe/danceWEB Scholarship Programme para asistir a una residencia de 5 semanas en Viena (Austria, dentro del marco de ImPulsTanz: Festival Internacional de Danza. La residencia de danceWEB ofrece a 65 bailarines y coreógrafos profesionales continuar su entrenamiento al tiempo que desarrollan importantes redes y tienen la mentoría de dos de las figuras más influyentes en la danza contemporánea actual.

 

La residencia es una gran plataforma para jóvenes y vibrantes artistas de la danza para continuar desarrollando sus carreras. Parte de la misión de danceWEB Scholarship Programme es incluir a la comunidad del artista en un ambiente cultural, invitando a dicha comunidad a participar en asuntos culturales por medio de su apoyo a los mismos artistas, volviéndose así capaz de ayudar al desarrollo de la cultura y las artes en su país de residencia.

 

Poder asistir a danceWEB es muy importante para mí ya que creo que ofrece un gran conocimiento y aprendizaje. Siento que estaré expuesto a nuevas y diferentes personas, compartiendo maneras de moverse, maneras de ver el mundo, maneras en las que escuchamos, en las que nos movemos para así ser capaces de hacer un pequeño cambio en el mundo. Creo que al finalizar danceWEB Scholarship Programme saldría con nueva vida inyectada en mí, lleno de ideas y habiendo descubierto un nuevo camino por medio del cual puedo continuar explorando movimiento y vida, de modo que podría seguir realizando mi trabajo de danza, como coreógrafo y como intérprete.

 

Tu ayuda me permitirá no solamente asistir y crecer como artista y persona, sino que tambie´n me dará la oportunidad de representar y compartir una pequeña parte de lo que la danza contemporánea mexicana es. Debo añadir que soy uno de los dos únicos bailarines mexicanos seleccionados en este año. Me parece que finalmente la danza contemporánea mexicana está teniendo la oportunidad de viajar y que los artistas latinoamericanos tienen una mayor participación en un intercambio multicultural de movimiento e ideologías. Con tu ayuda podré convertirme en una mejor persona y artista.

 

 

En cuanto al dinero...

El danceWEB Scholarship Programme me otorga 2/3 de la cuota de la colegiatura, la cual es de 6,400 Euros / 112,000 Pesos.

Necesito cubrir el otro 1/3 de la colegiatura, el cual es de 2,150 Euros / 37,600 Pesos.

Así mismo, necesito cubrir el costo del boleto redondo de avión, de México a Europa y de regreso; así como los gastos de alimentación y de transporte dentro de Viena.

He estado ahorrando para esto y también me encuentro aplicando a apoyos por parte de mi gobierno y de otras organizaciones culturales en mi país, de modo que pueda cubrir estos costos. Sin embargo, aún no sé si ellos me podrán otorgar los medios monetarios necesarios.

¡Con tu ayuda podré completar la cantidad necesaria para poder asistir a danceWEB este verano! ¡Cualquier cantidad es de gran ayuda! Puede empezar desde 1 dólar hasta donde sea, ¡tú decides!

 

Serás capaz de ayudarme a seguir desarrollando mi trabajo como bailarín y coreógrafo, conectándome así con increíbles e importantes artistas de todo el mundo, tomando parte de esta experiencia que podría cambiar mi vida.

 

Muchas gracias por leer y por tomar el tiempo de ver el video.

Si no puedes ayudar monetariamente, por favor ayúdame difundiendo esta página a todos aquellos que conozcas y que creas puedan estar interesados en ayudarme.

 

Nuevamente, ¡¡¡muchas gracias!!!
story_txt:
ENGLISH TEXT FIRST / SPANISH FOLLOWS *** INGLES PRIMERO / ESPAÑOL SIGUE
 
Here I am!
 
Hello everybody! My name is Miguel. I am a 28 year old dancer and choreographer born in Mexico.
Through dance and movement I have found my own voice as a person and as an artist and I have been able to understand the world.
 
I was recently informed that I have been selected out of 1023 dancers by the Jardin d'Europe/danceWEB Scholarship Programme to take part of a 5 week residency in Vienna (Austria), during ImPulsTanz: International Dance Festival. The danceWEB residency allows 65 professional dancers and choreographers from all over the world to further their training as they continue to develop important networks with renowned artists and are mentored by two of the most influential figures in contemporary dance today.
 
The residency is a great platform for young, vibrant dance artists to continue developing their careers. Part of the danceWEB Scholarship Programme's mission is to include the artist's community in a cultural environment, inviting that community to participate in cultural affairs by supporting the artists and thus being able to help further the development of culture and arts in their own country of residence. 
 
Being able to attend danceWEB is very important to me since I believe it holds incredible knowledge and learning. I feel that I will be exposed to new and different people, sharing ways of moving, ways of viewing the world, the way in which we listen, the way in which we move in order to be able to make a tiny shift and change in the world. I believe I would come out of the danceWEB Scholarship Programme with new life injected in me, filled with ideas and hopefully having discovered a new path through which I can continue exploring movement and life, in order to be able to keep doing my dance/performance work.
 
Your help will allow me not only to attend and grow as an artist and as a person, it will give me the opportunity to represent and share a small bit of what Mexican contemporary dance is. I must add that I am one of the only two Mexican dancers to have been selected this year. I believe that finally Mexican contemporary dance is able to be seen abroad, and that Latin artists have a much greater opportunity to participate in a multicultural exchange of movement and ideologies. With your help I will have the opportunity to become a better, fuller, richer dance artist and person.
 
 
Talking $$$
 
The danceWEB Scholarship Programme pays for 2/3 of the full tuition, which is around 6,400 Euros / 8,300 US Dollars. I need to cover the other 1/3 of the tuition, which is 2,150 Euros / 2,800 US Dollars.
I also need to cover my plane tickets from Mexico to Europe and back as well as the expenses for food and other transportation within Vienna.
I have been saving money for this and I have also been applying for grants from my own government and other arts organizations in my country so I can cover part of the tuition fee and the some other expenses. However, I still don't know if they will be able to support me with the money.
With your support I will be able to complete the amount needed so that I can attend danceWEB this summer!!! Any amount helps!!! It can start from 1 dollar and go anywhere, it's up to you!
 
You will be able to help me continue developing my work as a dancer and as a choreographer, getting connected with incredible and important artists from all over the world and take part of this life-changing experience.
 
Thank you so much for reading and for taking the time to watch the video.
If you can't support monetarily, please feel free to spread the word about this campaign to anyone you know and think would be interested in helping me out.
 
Once again, thank you so much!!!
 
 
 
 
ESPAÑOL
 
 
¡Aquí estoy!
 
¡Hola a todos! Mi nombre es Miguel. Soy un bailarín y coreógrafo de 28 años nacido en México.
Por medio de la danza y del movimiento he podido encontrar mi propia voz como persona y como artista y soy capaz de entender al mundo.
 
Recientemente me informaron que de entre 1023 bailarines y coreógrafos profesionales de todo el mundo fui seleccionado por Jardin d'Europe/danceWEB Scholarship Programme para asistir a una residencia de 5 semanas en Viena (Austria, dentro del marco de ImPulsTanz: Festival Internacional de Danza. La residencia de danceWEB ofrece a 65 bailarines y coreógrafos profesionales continuar su entrenamiento al tiempo que desarrollan importantes redes y tienen la mentoría de dos de las figuras más influyentes en la danza contemporánea actual.
 
La residencia es una gran plataforma para jóvenes y vibrantes artistas de la danza para continuar desarrollando sus carreras. Parte de la misión de danceWEB Scholarship Programme es incluir a la comunidad del artista en un ambiente cultural, invitando a dicha comunidad a participar en asuntos culturales por medio de su apoyo a los mismos artistas, volviéndose así capaz de ayudar al desarrollo de la cultura y las artes en su país de residencia.
 
Poder asistir a danceWEB es muy importante para mí ya que creo que ofrece un gran conocimiento y aprendizaje. Siento que estaré expuesto a nuevas y diferentes personas, compartiendo maneras de moverse, maneras de ver el mundo, maneras en las que escuchamos, en las que nos movemos para así ser capaces de hacer un pequeño cambio en el mundo. Creo que al finalizar danceWEB Scholarship Programme saldría con nueva vida inyectada en mí, lleno de ideas y habiendo descubierto un nuevo camino por medio del cual puedo continuar explorando movimiento y vida, de modo que podría seguir realizando mi trabajo de danza, como coreógrafo y como intérprete.
 
Tu ayuda me permitirá no solamente asistir y crecer como artista y persona, sino que tambie´n me dará la oportunidad de representar y compartir una pequeña parte de lo que la danza contemporánea mexicana es. Debo añadir que soy uno de los dos únicos bailarines mexicanos seleccionados en este año. Me parece que finalmente la danza contemporánea mexicana está teniendo la oportunidad de viajar y que los artistas latinoamericanos tienen una mayor participación en un intercambio multicultural de movimiento e ideologías. Con tu ayuda podré convertirme en una mejor persona y artista.
 
 
En cuanto al dinero...
El danceWEB Scholarship Programme me otorga 2/3 de la cuota de la colegiatura, la cual es de 6,400 Euros / 112,000 Pesos.
Necesito cubrir el otro 1/3 de la colegiatura, el cual es de 2,150 Euros / 37,600 Pesos.
Así mismo, necesito cubrir el costo del boleto redondo de avión, de México a Europa y de regreso; así como los gastos de alimentación y de transporte dentro de Viena.
He estado ahorrando para esto y también me encuentro aplicando a apoyos por parte de mi gobierno y de otras organizaciones culturales en mi país, de modo que pueda cubrir estos costos. Sin embargo, aún no sé si ellos me podrán otorgar los medios monetarios necesarios.
¡Con tu ayuda podré completar la cantidad necesaria para poder asistir a danceWEB este verano! ¡Cualquier cantidad es de gran ayuda! Puede empezar desde 1 dólar hasta donde sea, ¡tú decides!
 
Serás capaz de ayudarme a seguir desarrollando mi trabajo como bailarín y coreógrafo, conectándome así con increíbles e importantes artistas de todo el mundo, tomando parte de esta experiencia que podría cambiar mi vida.
 
Muchas gracias por leer y por tomar el tiempo de ver el video.
Si no puedes ayudar monetariamente, por favor ayúdame difundiendo esta página a todos aquellos que conozcas y que creas puedan estar interesados en ayudarme.
 
Nuevamente, ¡¡¡muchas gracias!!!

story:
Short Summary

  • This is Not a Pipe Dream is a play for young audiences based on the childhood of surrealist artist René Magritte. This inspiring show takes its viewers on a touching and whimsical journey through art, theatre, and life.  
  • Northwestern University's Purple Crayon Players is so excited to bring this wonderful play to campus this November!
  • Written by Barry Kornhauser, Produced by Sally Lindel, Directed by Meg Lowey

The Story

This is Not a Pipe Dream is based on the life and work of surrealist artist Rene Magritte, and is a whimsical celebration of art, imagination, and the mysteries of life. The play follows the young Magritte, a boy who wants to be an artist against his father's will, as he learns to express himself and question the world around him. In the spirit of his artwork, this story brings magic, slapstick comedy, and Magritte’s own beloved images to the stage as it tumbles through his life. This is Not a Pipe Dream is about finding your own unique mode of expression and finding joy and beauty in the unknown.

Purple Crayon Players

The Purple Crayon Players is a student-run theatre company on the Northwestern University campus committed to creating high quality productions, events, and educational materials regarding all aspects of theatre for young audiences. Purple Crayon Players believes that audience of all ages can appreciate, be inspired by, and grow through exposure to this unique art form.

Furthermore, we understand the importance of training the future leaders of the TYA field, and strive to provide Northwestern University students with opportunities to direct, produce, design, perform, teach, and explore new ways of expanding the field both on campus and at large.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your help to bring this production to life!  Student theatre is a big undertaking, and without your help it would not be possible--thank you!
  • Check out the "Perks" section to learn more about the different levels of giving. Also, you can give any amount that works for you!  You don't have to stick to the three levels we've highlighted.

The Impact

Directly, your donation will go toward:

  • Building a beautiful set complete with magical trap doors that reveal art in many exciting and unique ways
  • Costumes that bring René Magritte's world and art to life
  • Lighting the show through whimsical and enchanting theatre lights
  • Finding and creating props that bring the surrealist ideas of Magritte's work into 3D being

Indirectly, your donation will go toward:

  • Bringing Evanston and Chicagoland-area children to the Northwestern campus to learn about art, theatre, and following their dreams!
  • Practical (and fun!) theatrical experience for college students
  • Teaching the production team, cast, and audience about surrealist art and René Magritte

The Cast and Production Team

  • The Cast:
    • René: Alex Bird
    • The Interlocutor: Phoebe González
    • Mother: Joanna Blieden
    • Father: David Kern
    • Georgette/Teacher: Sarah Cartwright
  • Producer: Sally Lindel
    • Assistant Producer: Emily Martin
  • Director: Meg Lowey
    • Assistant Director: Samantha Spoll
  • Stage Manager: Marylynne Anderson-Cooper
    • Assistant Stage Manager: Nikolaj Sorensen
  • Movement/Clowning Coach: Maddy Low
  • Dramaturg: Lindsay Amer
  • French Consultant: Graham Duff
  • Set Design: Josh Gordon
    • Associate Set Designer/Build Manager: Sean Buckley
    • Assistant Set Designer: Lya Ferreyra
    • Scenic Painter: Jeff Sachs
  • Lighting Design: Gracie Schwartzenberger & Aaron Lorenz
    • Master Electrician: Aaron Lorenz
  • Sound Design: Grover Hollway
    • Assistant Sound Designer: Kathy Hong
  • Costume Design: Maia Safani
  • Props Design: Nikki Rosengren & Hannah Verdon
  • Fundraising Team: Sally Lindel, Emily Martin
  • Publicity Director: Aparna Ramachandran
    • Publicity Team: Liz Deadrick
    • Graphics Designer: Jordan Johnson
    • Promotion & Production Photography: Rafi Letzter

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come see our production!
    • Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University
    • November 15th at 7 pm
    • November 16th at 7 and 10 pm
    • November 17th at 2 and 7 pm
    • $5 for NU students/$10 general admission
    • Children under 18 FREE
  • Tell your friends about us!

Questions?  Email sallylindel2015@u.northwestern.edu.

story:
We are a newly formed nonprofit theatre company.  We are currently working on putting up a full production of "Léocadia" by the French playwright, Jean Anouilh, in the Fall of 2012 at the Hudson Guild Theatre in New York City.

Our theatre company aims to present plays that have a message for all audiences. We embrace multi-ethnic diversity in our productions, and we would like to share the magic of theatre and reach out to the local schools by admitting students/teachers to previews for free, and keep up the cultural theatre tradition.

We are seeking donations for our first production "Léocadia" by the French playwright, Jean Anouilh at the Hudson Guild Theatre in New York City for a two week run in the fall of 2012.

Please note that the actors give their free time to rehearse and perform. Most two week productions are double this amount we are seeking but the theatre company volunteers are giving their free time to kick off "La Belle Époque Theatre Company's" first major production.

 

All the following expenses are an approximate estimate.

 

What We Need 

We are looking to gather 10,000 dollars to cover the expenses of the Theatre Company's first year production. 

 

LÉOCADIA (New York Production)

Theatre rental/rehearsal space rental/insurance:  $7500

Scenery/lights/costumes/props/advertising:  $2500

All other additional expenses with regards to publicist/actors/director/production crew/stage manager have been reduced by volunteers giving their free time and energy.  

We just need an additional $10,000 to cover the remaining expenses. 

Thank you!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word, through this page and facebook.

story:
I am Tessa, 16 year old from Louisville, KY and I have been accepted into the Broadway Theatre Project.
“broadwaytheatreproject.com”

Broadway Theatre Project is a three-week intensive performing arts education program for high school and college students. BTP is a prestigious apprenticeship program where I will have the opportunity to study with those who have worked in the business that I want to pursue my career in. I couldn’t be happier about being accepted and want, more than anything, the chance to attend this summer! BTP is in Tampa, FL and I am raising funds to pay for my flight and tuition, including room and board for my three week stay. I would appreciate any and all donations from any and all of you!
___________________________________________________________________
Here is a copy of my acceptance letter:

Dear Tessa,

Playbill magazine refers to Broadway Theatre Project as, “The world’s most prestigious musical theatre arts education program for high school and college students.” It is my pleasure to inform you that you have been selected to attend the 2010 session of this renowned training intensive. You will be joining the ranks of past BTP students who have performed in over 70 shows on Broadway, many film and TV projects and countless national and world tours. Your apprenticeship with BTP will be an essential step towards your future as an artist in the performance industry as you come into contact with some of the most accomplished people in the performing arts world.

If you choose to attend BTP, you will have the unique opportunity to study with some of the most accomplished producers, casting directors, directors, choreographers and working artists in the performing arts world. Broadway Theatre Project also hosts information sessions with some of the most renowned musical theatre university programs in the country. You are about to enjoy a once in a lifetime experience!

The Broadway Theatre Project 2010 dates are July 11th to August 1st, 2010.
Congratulations. We look forward to working with you this summer!

Sincerely,

Kim Slade
Program Director
