story:
My Story

My name is Trent Wilkie and I'm an independent theatre producer in Edmonton, Alberta. Currently, I'm a producer/writer/performer for an upcoming production called Book On Tape. It will be directed by Taylor Chadwick, produced/sound designed by Brian Bergum and Starring Joleen Ballendine as well as myself. I'm writing it, acting in it, producing it and basically thinking about it on a stomach churningly consistent level. It will be running October 6 to 15 at the TransAlta Arts Barns. I love what I do.

I have written for CBC Radio's "The Irrelevant Show", and while performing with Mostly Water Theatre, had work spotlighted on The Huffington Post, Gawker and Funny or Die. Also, I'm a freelance writer and professional canoe guide and have paddled in almost every province in Canada. 

This will be the third full-length play that I have written in under a year. Gargamel was shown at the Varscona Theatre in February/March of this year, as well, Aachen was written and performed at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival. Both were embraced by audiences and the media alike. VUE magazine said Gargamel was  "Profound" and the Edmonton Journals stated that in Aachen, "Wilkie’s timing is perfect, his lines are fresh, inventive and hilarious". There goes my humility.


What We Need & The Impact It Will Have


I'm hoping to raise $500. It will be spread out amongst marketing, set design/construction, video editing, costumes and props. Compound this with time missed from work and it makes a two-week performance very expensive. This show is coming out of my pocket and will go up no matter what so every little bit will help.

Your donation will help Book On Tape be affordable. How many people will see it? I have no idea; that is out of my control. But with your help, it will be the best it can be and I will be able to pay the cast and crew what they deserve from what we make from the show. Well, I’d have to win the lottery to pay them what they deserve, but it will help immensely and aid  in continuing to create fun and relevant productions in the future. 

Basically, I want to continue to create at an affordable pace and theatre, like a good date, ain't cheap.

 

Other Ways You Can Assist

Every little bit helps. If you can't donate money, just pass on the word. If you don't want to pass on the word, come see the show. If you don't want to come see the show, donate money or pass on the word, at least give me a high five. Those things don't grow on trees you know.

In all sincerity, what ever you can offer will help. Passing this information through Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, Google +, Tumblr…whatever social media outlet you use...even email can make a difference. Yes, good ol’ fashioned turn of the century email.


Thank you for your time.

story:
Zugzwang

Chi siamo

Artisti Aquilani onlus nasce nel 2009 per unire artisti capaci di indagare la realtà attraverso le arti performative e di unire la passione alla professione. In questi anni la ricerca dei contenuti e quella formale sono andate di pari passo, realizzando progetti sociali e artistici  che hanno coinvolto sia il nostro territorio sia territori oltreconfine.

Siamo fieri costruttori autofinanziati del primo spazio teatrale, rinato a L’Aquila dopo il terremoto - La casa del Teatro - che teniamo in vita attraverso rassegne, festival, corsi, conferenze, seminari.
Il nostro lavoro è interamente autoprodotto. Non siamo sostenuti da alcun Ente o Ministero e riusciamo a sopravvivere grazie al sostegno del pubblico oltre che alla nostra tenacia.
Le nostre peculiarità sono la versatilità - un mix di tecniche e tradizioni artistiche (dal clown alla danza classica Indiana) - e il bisogno di far dialogare la formazione permanente e il lavoro con la vita e la storia.

http://www.artistiaquilani.it/

Zugzwang

In tedesco significa "obbligato a muovere". Negli scacchi si riferisce alla situazione in cui un giocatore si trova in difficoltà perché qualsiasi mossa faccia, è costretto a subire lo scacco matto oppure una grossa perdita di materiale.

Zugzwang è uno spettacolo in cui quattro personaggi alla deriva, esibendosi in una serie di attrazioni, si raccontano attraverso diversi linguaggi  - la danza, la musica, il comico, il teatro di figura -  nel contesto decadente e ironico di un dark cabaret. E’ l’allegoria di una realtà che racchiude in sé la scandalosa necessità di stupire per esistere, in un’accozzaglia di performance che servono solo a sopravvivere con fatica. 

C’è una dimensione unica, una sorta di posto segreto che vive intorno al teatro ed è inafferrabile come la risposta a una domanda senza senso. È proprio lì che ci porta Zugzwang: siamo spettatori di eventi che solitamente sono negati ai nostri occhi. Per una volta ci è concesso il privilegio di guardare oltre e incontrare frammenti di un esistere che c’è, è concreto ma visibile solo nelle conseguenze del suo essere.

L’Attesa, il Potere, la Vita e la Morte danzano sullo sfondo decadente e impolverato di un Teatro deserto. Ed in questo luogo incontriamo quel che resta. Quel che resta dopo le luci della ribalta, dopo gli applausi, dopo il sipario.

Obbligati a muoversi sulla scacchiera dell’esistenza pur sapendo che ogni passo conduce ad una inevitabile sconfitta. Quel che conta è esserci e restare legati anche ad un solo filo, invisibile forse, ma ancora capace di sostenere il volo.

Perché il crowdfunding

Abbiamo scelto il crowdfunding  perché è una pratica di micro-finanziamento che parte dal basso (come il nostro teatro) e che mobilita le persone oltrepassando le barriere tradizionali dell'investimento finanziario. 

5 buoni motivi per sostenere Zugzwang

1.  Per rispondere creativamente al cambiamento che sta avvenendo nel mondo culturale italiano.

2.  Perchè avete sempre pensato che il teatro e la musica siano una cosa meravigliosa ma non avete mai potuto dedicarvi a questa passione e per poter dire agli altri e a voi stessi : questo l’ho fatto anche io!

3.  Perchè pensate sia una modalità intelligente, efficace e innovativa per promuovere la cultura

4.  Perchè vi piace dare fiducia ai giovani e credete che con la cultura si può mangiare ma anche vivere meglio per sè e per gli altri.

5.  Per avere su questa terra sei persone che vi saranno grate per sempre e parleranno sempre bene di voi!

A cosa serve il vostro contributo

L'intera produzione verrà sostenuta da voi.

Ci aiuterete a sostenere le spese di: promozione dello spettacolo, costi di gestione della sala prove, scenotecnica, confezione dei costumi, organizzazione e distribuzione.

Se vi piace il progetto potete sostenerci in qualunque forma e in qualunque modo, contattateci su artistiaquilani@gmail.com.
story_txt:
Zugzwang

Chi siamoArtisti Aquilani onlus nasce nel 2009 per unire artisti capaci di indagare la realtà attraverso le arti performative
e di unire la passione alla professione. In questi anni la ricerca dei contenuti e quella formale sono andate di pari passo,
realizzando progetti sociali e artistici  che hanno coinvolto sia il
nostro territorio sia territori
oltreconfine.Siamo fieri costruttori
autofinanziati del primo spazio teatrale, rinato a L’Aquila dopo il terremoto
- La casa del Teatro - che teniamo
in vita attraverso rassegne, festival, corsi, conferenze, seminari.Il nostro
lavoro è interamente autoprodotto.
Non siamo sostenuti da alcun Ente o Ministero e riusciamo a sopravvivere grazie
al sostegno del pubblico oltre che alla nostra tenacia.Le nostre
peculiarità sono la versatilità - un
mix di tecniche e tradizioni artistiche (dal clown alla danza classica Indiana)
- e il bisogno di far dialogare la formazione permanente e il lavoro con la vita e la storia.http://www.artistiaquilani.it/

ZugzwangIn tedesco
significa "obbligato a muovere". Negli scacchi si riferisce alla
situazione in cui un giocatore si trova in difficoltà perché qualsiasi mossa
faccia, è costretto a subire lo scacco matto oppure una grossa perdita di
materiale.
Zugzwang è uno spettacolo in cui quattro personaggi alla
deriva, esibendosi in una serie di attrazioni, si raccontano attraverso diversi
linguaggi  - la danza, la musica, il
comico, il teatro di figura -  nel
contesto decadente e ironico di un dark cabaret. E’ l’allegoria di una realtà che
racchiude in sé la scandalosa necessità di stupire per esistere, in
un’accozzaglia di performance che servono solo a sopravvivere con
fatica. 
C’è
una dimensione unica, una sorta di posto segreto che vive intorno al teatro ed
è inafferrabile come la risposta a una domanda senza senso. È proprio lì che ci
porta Zugzwang: siamo spettatori di
eventi che solitamente sono negati ai nostri occhi. Per una volta ci è concesso
il privilegio di guardare oltre e incontrare frammenti di un esistere che c’è,
è concreto ma visibile solo nelle conseguenze del suo essere.

il Potere, la Vita e la Morte danzano sullo sfondo decadente e impolverato di
un Teatro deserto. Ed in questo luogo incontriamo quel che resta. Quel che
resta dopo le luci della ribalta, dopo gli applausi, dopo il sipario.
Obbligati
a muoversi sulla scacchiera dell’esistenza pur sapendo che ogni passo conduce
ad una inevitabile sconfitta. Quel che conta è esserci e restare legati anche ad un solo filo,
invisibile forse, ma ancora capace di sostenere il volo.

Perché il crowdfunding
Abbiamo scelto il crowdfunding  perché è una pratica di
micro-finanziamento che parte dal basso (come il nostro teatro) e che mobilita
le persone oltrepassando le barriere tradizionali dell'investimento
finanziario.

1.  Per rispondere creativamente al cambiamento che
sta avvenendo nel mondo culturale italiano.
2.  Perchè avete sempre pensato che il teatro e la
musica siano una cosa meravigliosa ma non avete mai potuto dedicarvi a questa
passione e per poter dire agli altri e a voi stessi : questo l’ho fatto anche
io!
3.  Perchè pensate sia una modalità intelligente,
efficace e innovativa per promuovere la cultura
4.  Perchè vi piace dare fiducia ai giovani e
credete che con la cultura si può mangiare ma anche vivere meglio per sè e per
gli altri.
5.  Per avere su questa terra sei persone che vi
saranno grate per sempre e parleranno sempre bene di voi!

A cosa serve il vostro contributo
L'intera produzione verrà sostenuta da voi.Ci aiuterete a sostenere le spese di: promozione dello spettacolo, costi di gestione della sala prove, scenotecnica, confezione dei costumi, organizzazione e distribuzione.
Se vi piace il progetto potete sostenerci in qualunque forma e in
qualunque modo, contattateci su artistiaquilani@gmail.com.

story:
Dear Community,

I'm Liz Boubion, a Choreographer, Movement Therapist and the Artistic Director of the Piñata Dance Collective, whose multi-disciplinary performances explore identity, impermanence and sustainability through symbolic deconstructions of the Piñata ritual. 

I have been accepted to a reputable month-long artist residency called "360 Xochi Quetzal" in Chapala, Jalisco, Mexico this coming May 2014.  It is typically given to writers and visual artists and I am their very first choreographer chosen among 160 applicants internationally!

This is a huge honor and so exciting for me because it will be the first time I will be able to visit Mexico, the country belonging to half of my ethnic heritage. This is the beginning of my cultural exchange with Mexica artists and healers in Mexico and a chance to deepen my relationship to myself through "Ancestral Land Sensing". My plan is to dance, play my flute and commune in Chapala and Guadalajara for 3 weeks, and then dance and explore in Mexico City for a week.

With your help, I will:

  • Expand the Piñata Dance Collective internationally

  • I will research and document site specific dances in pre-hispanic locations, and

  • Continue to develop my artistry which builds community, educates and innovates.

  • Pay the 9 artists performing for my residency benefit concert on Sunday, May 4th, 4pm.  An informal showing of Piñata Dances.

What I am asking for:

360 Xochi Quetzal is generously providing me free lodging and a food stipend in Chapala, MX and I am hoping to raise $3600 for the following items:

$700- Pay Artists who are generously donating their time to my project. Please come to my upcoming Mexico residency "Send Off” - an informal Piñata Celebration and Benefit Concert with 9 incredible dancers and musicians! Sunday, May 4, 4pm @ Shawl Anderson Dance Center, Berkeley.

$550- My flight expenses to Guadalajara and to Mexico City.

$1750-A new company Computer, Ipad and tripod to document my work and give PDC the upgrade we desperately need.

$600- Take dance classes for a month, buses, museums and pay for lodging for 9 days in Mexico City in June.

Thank you for your generosity* Any amount will help! And please come see me off on May 4!  Tickets are $5- $50 sliding scale... 

Some more background on my work- see below...

Photo credit: Su Pang

I have primarily been a solo dance artist since my Dance degree in 1993 specializing in dance improvisation and spoken word as well as offering workshops in the Tamalpa Life-Art Process since 2006.  However, what began during my MFA program at CIIS 3 years ago has evolved to several ensemble Piñata Dance Rituals in theaters, galleries, outdoor landscapes, dance festivals, and workshops in the San Francisco Bay Area.  I have worked with with over 25 dancers, musicians, sculptors, ceremonialists and film directors on this theme combining contemporary, classical and indigenous backgrounds into one tapestry. For the last 12 years, I have held one foot in motherhood, one foot in dance, and I teach Modern Dance Technique at Shawl Anderson Dance Center, Motivational Movement for Seniors 3 days a week, and I see private clients. see www.lizboubion.org

Why is the Piñata so interesting? Where did it come from? How does it reflect life?

The Piñata holds ancient and contemporary implications of celebration, loss and regeneration for Latina/o culture and the world at large.  Originally, before it was the paper mache sculpture filled with candy that children smash open with a blindfold and stick, the Piñata was birthed in China as a New Year celebration and a ritual for planting. During his travels in China, Marco Polo gathered it up and brought it back to Italy where it was appropriated to Catholicism representing 7 deadly sins. From Italy it swung to the Spaniards who colonized Mexico.  The Aztecs had their own ritual during the winter solstice that included the breaking open of a clay pot filled with water as a prayer for the return of the Sun God, “Huitzilopochtli”-which translates as “Hummingbird on the Left”. In essence, it was a prayer for sustainability which is relevant for our precarious world today.  Now, La Piñata is used for many occasions including birthday parties which personalizes the game, singing “Dale Dale Dale, no pierdas el tino, porque si lo pierdes, pierdes el camino…”(Hit it Hit it Hit it, don’t lose your aim, if you lose it, you lose your way”). La piñata is a survivor and a symbol for creativity that confronts centuries of pain and confusion to release old paradigms and bring communities together through the beauty of art and re-story telling. Also, the Piñata is not limited to paper mache Sponge Bobs and Explora Doras. It is a ritual for growth and can be an embodied meditation on regeneration.

The work I am showing on May 4th, is a work in progress for a future full-length production called “Piñatas Spaghetti and Lace”. It’s very exciting because I am collaborating with traditional Chinese dancers, an Aztec dancer, plus 6 contemporary dancers and musicians who will take the audience on a visual and musical journey through the history of La Piñata.  We will also give the audience an option to participate in a blindfolded exploration and other interesting surprises at Shawl Anderson. In addition, I will be choreographing part of Piñata with dance students at Cal State University East Bay this Spring. After I return from Mexico, I have a few images of various piñatas in my head to paint and I plan to incorporate an aerial piece in a future production.  I am presently seeking a venue and funding to hire a production manager to produce the full-length show and will continue to offer Piñata Breakthrough performance labs “What do you want to breakthrough in your life right now?  What will you sacrifice to get to the goodies on the inside? In 2015, I plan to curate a show with the theme of Piñata that celebrates other choreographers of the Latina/o diaspora.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help financially, please come to the showing on May 4th and support our work!  Volunteers are needed... for example, I need a house manager!:-)

I am also seeking a grant writer and production manager for future productions if you would like to offer your assistance to a choreographer who has no "earth" in her chart. I suppose you could say, I am astrologically deprived.

***Also please use the Indiegogo Share tools and encourage others who may be interested in supporting the Piñata Dance Collective and my 360 Xochi Quetzal Residency. 

Muchisimas Gracias y Amor Grande,

Chuparosa (“Hummingbird”- what my grandmother called me)

Piñata 2012- Sculpted by Liz Boubion and Meryl Juniper

Clay and feathers.

story:
The PLAYground, produced by Purple Crayon Players, is an annual festival of new plays for young audiences. It consists of a three-week play development process which culminates in a day-long festival of staged readings of three new professionally-written plays for young audiences. Our festival is recognized by the American Alliance of Theatre Education as a Tier 2 Theatre in Our Schools event!

This year, the plays are:

ANNIE JUMP AND THE LIBRARY OF HEAVEN by Reina Hardy
Directed by Maddie Napel

MAKING MOCHI ON THE MOON by Wendy Gourley
Directed by Pam Kranyak

WHAT REMAINS by Max Bush
Directed by Katherine Seldin

The staged readings are occurring in the Community Meeting Room at the main branch of the Evanston Public Library, the perfect place for local families with children to access these new works.

Purple Crayon Players is a nationally recognized, award-winning theatre company comprised of Northwestern University students committed to producing professionally written plays for young audiences. The group seeks to create thought-provoking, smart and entertaining theatre for young audiences as well as to provide opportunities for young people to further engage with theatre and understand themselves through workshops and other events. We believe theatre for young audiences is theatre for all audiences, and invite you to help us create this amazing opportunity for new work to shine.

story:
Malevolence is King's Players' 3rd entry into the DC Fringe Festival.  We began with an original comedy, In the Company of de Sade, which raised a few eyebrows and caused some... other reactions.  Last year, we continued to push the envelope further with Mme. Macbeth, a version of the play with all genders switched.  Some people got it, some people didn't.  With Malevolence, we once again tackle an original play, this time an uncompromising drama inspired by local, actual events.  A teacher finds himself at the center of a nightmare after he is accused of inappropriate conduct with a student.  

Your contribution will help pay for advertising, rehearsal space, and (most importantly) actors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you can contribute or not, please help us:

  • get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • use the Indiegogo share tools!
#malevolence
#capfringe2014
#totalperv

story:
SPUNKandCOmpany Dance needs your help to stay alive!

Donate to our annual fund today: all donations will go 100% towards production costs, dancer pay and rehearsal costs for the year.

 

SPUNK's mission? We make dances from scratch and exist to push the artistic boundaries of dance in the Boston area. The company, led by Jillian  Grunnah and Tara McCrystal, is composed of seven dancers/choreographers who lend not only their technical skill, but also their creative input and energy to every dance. We are a non-profit 501©3 arts organization that believes in the human body as a powerful story teller. A blend of traditional and contemporary dance techniques, our dancing is athletic, theatrical and provocative. Our choreography attempts to both delight and provoke thought from the viewer. Often magnifying social issues and human relationships, the company works together to make art that is fresh, vivacious, sometimes deep and always fun. 

 

Why give to SPUNK? You can trust that your donations will impact social change through live, thought-provoking, dynamic performance.

 

Want to learn more about us? that's great!

In winter of 2014, over the course of one month, we will be in Residency at the Boston Center for the Arts. The month will be spent creating new work focused on modern day consumerism and modern society's need for instant gratification, through movement and technology. We will be teaching public workshops for children and adults and the month will culminate in a performance produced by the Boston Center for the Arts.

In summer of 2013 we produced an all SPUNK evening of live performance, 'Seven on 7', at the Boston University Dance Theater. The evening of new and recent works focused on themes ranging from the thought processes and relationships of women, the ever-changing and unpredictable seasons of our lives and the ignorance of global warfare.

In spring 2013, over a three month period, we were an Artist in Residency at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA, to develop new work and culminated in a produced shared show.

 In fall of 2012 we launched a successful Kickstarter campaign, raising $6000 to produce a multidisciplinary arts Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Benefit, and to honor the life of singer/songwriter Eric Lowen. All proceeds were donated in full to the ALS Foundation of Massachusetts.

In summer 2012 we produced '1x7', an evening of new and recent works at the Julie Ince Thompson Theater at the Dance Complex in Cambridge, MA. A fan favorite work from the evening focused on bullying.

In fall of 2011 we premiered our first evening of work, 'Eleven', at the Julie Ince Thompson Theater at the Dance Complex in Cambridge, MA.

In winter 2010-2011 we were an Artist in Residence at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA, to develop new work and culminated in a produced shared show.

In fall 2010, SPUNKandCOmpany Dance was born.

 

Who are the dance makers of SPUNK? Women who are passionate about collaboration, education, creativity and movement. We include dance teachers, choreographers, a movement therapist, pilates teachers, a physical therapist, and yoga teachers. We bring our experience, an open mind and compassion into the studio every day. And, we laugh a lot.

 

 

What if you want to contribute but can't? you can help us by spreading the word and making some noise about our campaign.

 

 

thank you for taking the time to read. be healthy, happy and SPUNKy. 

 check out our website

story:
The Play: HerSheMe was inspired by the poem, 'Troubled Woman'  written by Langston Hughes with an Illustration by Anne Grifalconi depicting a woman bowed over with her shadow cast behind her. It is an experimental performance art piece based on what it means to be a woman. The play will explore how one exists in a world not easily understood or bearable yet always hopeful. The play will ask questions about the fragility, femininity and masculinity of woman-hood. Through movement the play will delve into the female psyche, showing no matter what we must bear we always stay in continuum. It has been created with 4 women dressed in timeless garments, allowing for movement and expression. A Cellist will provide a necessary layer as it is the closest sound to the male human voice.  

 How we plan to pull it off:  We believe that nothing bad comes from hard-work and so we will continue to clean houses, run errands, conduct interview research, and with full energy and love do any tasks that comes our way to continue to support a project we believe in and love.  We know that putting up a Theatre show is not easy nor cheap but we do find that anything can be done when one is passionate and hungry enough to see it through. 

It Takes A Village:  Theatre Roscius is a company founded on the idea that stories must be shared.  We believe that it begins in our individual communities- when we all gather and participate to explore the many facets of being human we ultimately reveal our similarities-more importantly we are able to bring what can easily be mistaken as strangers together into a room to find they have always known one another. We know for sure we cannot do this alone; with your support and contribution Theatre Roscius shall be able to perform HerSheMe until the end of August.

Director

Memory Willis

Movement Coordinator

Constance Strickland

Text Coordinator

Josefine Petersen

Stage Manager

Lydia Toler

The Players:

Bijou Torres

Gabi Habush

Constance Strickland

& featuring Cellist Isaac Takeuchi

Performance Dates/Time: June 15th-10pm, June 16th-5:15pm. June 23rd-5:15pm, June 29th-7pm at The Complex Theatre Space at  6470 Santa Monica Blvd Hollywood, CA 90038

Sample of Work: This is a 3 minute sample of Chapter 3-Mourning.

http://vimeo.com/62404649

Trailer

http://vimeo.com/62404648

story:
Ben & Rita

a romantic-comedy
by Wendy-Marie Martin

Sometimes fate lives right next door.

Rita's desperate need for attention has driven away everyone she's ever known. Ben never got close enough to anyone to scare them off in the first place. In fact, he hasn't left his apartment in ten years. But When Rita's recently widowed daughter, Eve, and teenage child, Sammy, come to live with Rita, the walls are broken down, literally. As Rita & Ben's worlds collide, they are faced with a choice. Continue to live in fear or take a chance on love?

Production Info

Ben & Rita is slated for a February 2014 production on the Waldron Stage at Mill Mountain Theater in Roanoke, Virgina. This is a co-production between Hollins Playwright's Lab and Mill Mountain Theater and will be directed by Chicago's one-and-only Ms. Cheryl Snodgrass. PLUS my AMAZING husband, Arne, is designing the set!

Since these guys are taking a chance on me and my work, I have made it my goal to raise a portion of the production costs myself. I figure if I can get 200 people to donate $10, we can hit this goal in 30 days.

I know it's not always easy to help out but I sure would appreciate the support if you can!

Why Should You Donate?

Because the world needs more plays that fill your heart and make the room gush "awwww" at the end, and Ben & Rita does just that. 

And we all know the right director makes all the difference in the world, so I'd like to start by raising funds to cover expenses to bring in our PHENOMENAL director. YOUR DONATION WILL HELP COVER OUR DIRECTOR'S STIPEND AND HOUSING.

This is my way of putting the wheel in motion and making my career as a playwright happen. And someday, when my plays are being produced around the world and I'm accepting a Pulitzer, you can say you helped me get there!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're just too strapped to help out, I totally understand. Maybe you have friends or family on your FaceBook that wouldn't mind chipping in, so please share this with as many people as you can. Thank you!!!

story:
Short Summary

After our succesful debut last year, Tall Ship Adventures is seeking to establish a professional regional theatre aboard The Tall Ship Windy. Theatre on a pirate ship is no small task. You contributions will:
  • Help us promote our show.
  • Support our cast financially.
  • Ensure that we can maintain our goal of being "Finally something that rivals Chicago Shakespeare". -Chris Jones (Chicago Tribune)

What We Need & What You Get

Our theatre space is a pirate ship that actually sails so your donations will:

  • Create weather adaptive costumes.
  • Spread the word about our unique theatre.
  • Augment our cast salaries. (Our actors do get paid to perform but this will help provide stipends for the rehersal process.)
  • Help purchase this year's new props that need to be bought and built.
  • Make you part of the process! Our perks are amazing! A ghost story CD, a cast album, the ever-curious Pirate-Gram, a handmade Cutlass from Rogue Steel and more!

Our goal is actually about 1/3 of our needs. We sure hope we get it! But even if we don't, all contributions will keep our show, our theatre and our ship finacially afloat.

The Impact

Let us take you back in time--twelve years ago our Producer (Orion Couling) and his sister (one of our Co-Directors Emma Couling) came up with a crazy idea to build sustainable theatre on an actual sailing vessel. Growing up with fantasies of searching for treasure with Jim Hawkins and defying all odds with Charlotte Doyle they held fast to their dream. Now it's become a reality. Help us keep it that way!

Our production team has literally 40+ shows beneath thier collective pirate boots including Treasure Island-Lake Superior Theatre, Romeo vs Juliette (Pirate vs Ninja)- Pretty Windy, and last years sold out and critically acclaimed debut of this very show!

Other Ways You Can Help

So you can't donate--we understand, but maybe you know someone who can! Spread the word! Those CDs make great gifts!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word! Also, we are taking donations of props (old sea chests, barrels, replica pistols and such). Contact Orion at treasureisland8@gmail.com to arrange a donation in that manner

story:
We Are The Unexpected Laboratory

Hi I’m Joe Hill. About a year ago Travis Coe and I decided that it was time to start creating projects that meant more to us than what we were doing at school. We started The Unexpected Laboratory. While both studying Directing, Travis at Columbia College in Chicago and me at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, we have managed to create projects beyond what we had ever expected. Members of our company have creating shows in Cincinnati, a show in Chicago and our newest member Shaun Sutton sent a show to the Onyxfest in Indiana. Antigone is the biggest project The Unexpected Laboratory has planned. We are performing in Boulder Colorado in a beautiful space in The Dairy Center for the Arts called The East Theatre. This project will be the culmination of over a year of planning and it is time to truly make the push to make it a reality!

The house has 100 sharp red seats and a long catwalk over the stage. We envision a classical Greek Antigone where the Greek Chorus is a documentary film maker, the sooth sayer is a jive speaker jazz man, the king is a media giant, and the rest of the world lives in poverty and drug abuse. We need television screens to show the press conferences when Creon gives them, we need dirt to coat the stage when you see the reality of the poverty stricken streets that are often ignored by the cameras, we need costumes for the actors to wear that accurately show what kind of world they live in and we need spray paint for the graffiti that will cover the walls of our set.

If you don’t want to donate to our show we understand but there are other ways you can help our campaign! Social Media will ultimately be our best friend. Please share our page on your Facebook and Twitter. Just share us as much as you can and spread the word. Also, if you would like to help the production first hand or even be part of the cast contact either Joe Hill or Travis Coe for details.


joehill.unexpectedlab@gmail.com

traviscoe.unexpectedlab@gmail.com

 

ANTIGONE SHOW DATES AND INFORMATION

August 15-18th

The Dairy Center for the Arts- East Theatre

2590 Walnut St  Boulder, CO 80302

story:
What if Shakespeare had written Pulp Fiction?

Pulp Shakespeare imagines what it may have been like had the 1994 cult film Pulp Fiction been written by William Shakespeare, and presented as classical theatre. Set in Elizabethan England, this wildly entertaining parody weaves the story of a pair of murderers, their boss’ alluring wife, and a desperate knight.  While paying homage to the films witty dialogue and colorful characters, the production is firmly grounded in the language and rhetoric of Shakespeare’s time.

After being selected as a “Best of Fest” winner at the 2011 Hollywood Fringe Fest, our critically acclaimed play went on to three extensions in Hollywood, garnering two LA Weekly Award nominations in the process (Best Comedic Ensemble; Best Adaptation). And now we have been selected to participate in the 16th annual New York International Fringe Fest!

 

Help Us Get There!

13 actors! Elizabethan Era Costumes!! Broad Swords & Crossbows!!! And a set!!!! All of which have to get to New York from Los Angeles...

Being accepted into FringeNYC is an incredible opportunity that we are grateful for, and one that we hope leads to furthering our production (perhaps on tour to a theatre near you!). However, it's also an expensive opportunity that we would very much appreciate your help in realizing!

We need to raise between $10-$15K to make this trip happen. Your generous donations will go to the following:

  • Airfare for our cast of thirteen
  • Lodging
  • Costume/Set/Prop rentals
  • Insurance
  • Stage Manager and Booth Operator fees
  • New York City publicist
  • Printing costs
  • And of course the occasional meal...

We have a lot of great perks for those who donate!

  • T-shirts
  • Posters
  • Our Soundtrack
  • Speech and Movement classes taught by our own cast memebers
  • And much more!

click for larger view

 

Word of mouth is invaluable. Please share this campaign page with all of your friends!

And for those of you who live in the New York City area, tickets for our FringNYC shows go on sale July 20th! Get them while you can! Web Link: FringeNYC

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

I grew up in three different countries, but since I remember I have been surrounded by art. My grandma was a songwriter and a singer as well as my mom and aunties. 

The idea of saying things through music and images was something that always caught my attention. My sisters and I used to make telenovelas, and for some reason I always ended being the director or the producer of the homemade novela.

Somehow I got involved in the production business at a very young age, and the idea of becoming a director was getting stronger. Unfortunately life took a different direction and I had to wait for the opportunity to arise.

Bit by bit the pieces fell in place and Burley Man came to me in a peculiar way.  

I was working in a play at a New York festival. Upon visiting with Ken Terrell, the director of the play, he told me about a script that he had for many years but to date he had not yet accomplished putting it on stage. He provided me with a copy of the script.  I read it and immediately fell in love with it. I wanted to direct more than ever.

For some time, the director and I discussed the possibility of putting on a production of the play. Unfortunately, Terrell passed away before we could make the dream come true.

In Terrell’s honor, I have decided to produce and direct the play.

Students, volunteers, and creative art designers, enthusiastically share my desire to make this play come to life and most important they are helping me to make my dream of being a director come true.

What We Need & What You Get

Funds raised are purely for production, not personal costs! We're aiming to raise $5,000.00 here on Indiegogo, we'll be depending on ticket sales to cover the remaining $3100,00 of our total production budget!

* The Complex Theatre rental cost

* The in-house production team (light and sound technicians, ushers, house manager, etc.)

* Paying our Artistic Team (costume designer, set designer, choreographer, music, etc)

* Transporting our set/costumes 

* Costume and prop Fees (dry-cleaning, mending/building) 

* Promotional Costs (poster/program printing, newspaper/radio ads)

* Cast (Joanna, Madge, Reverend, Jesse, Brian and Edward) 

The Impact

It would not only change the course of my life towards my dream, it would also be distinctly notable and will establish a precedent in the theatre arena. We are all committed to assure that this production will deliberately remain a team project, and every single step of the process has been or will be completed while providing the collaborators, cast, and crew members, with a voice to contribute to this multi-dimensional and diverse production.

This production is a very exciting experiment combining all the arts to create and share a portrayal of a distinct time place, and colorful characters.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on any of our social networks and help us sread the word.

story:
'The Gigli Concert' by Tom Murphy, produced by O'Punksky's Theatre for Darlinghurst Theatre Company, April 2014

Some 24 years ago three best friends formed a theatre company: O'Punksky's Theatre.  With many boards having been tread over the ensuing years, these three are still friends and still thespians. That is no mean feat. 'The Gigli Concert' has become their signature piece and this will be its fourth and final production.

Why do it again?

Because it's just so good. And beautiful. And transcendent. And it's the story of modern man.

'...an operatic drama complete with deaths and arias, a version of Faust in which against all the laws of reality this down at heel alchemist finds the philosopher's stone of despair that enables him to transmute the leaden metal of his life into a moment of pure, glittering possibility...'

'The Gigli Concert' deals with seven days in the relationship between Dynamatologist JPW King, a quack self-help therapist living in Dublin but born and brought up in England, and the mysterious Irishman who would 'give his life' to sing like Italian opera singer Beniamino Gigli for 'one short, sweet hour'.

With, well, quite a lot of life experience now under their belts, John, Patrick and Maeliosa, the O'Punks, are ready to pour their lives into this story.


We're unfunded and starting from scratch; we need $5000...

Our production will be paid for by bums on seats, but:

  • We can't predict the future, and
  • The funds don't come to us until after the show, so...


What will $5000 do?

It means...

  • John can stop going to meetings and get on with researching Faust
  • Erin can stop scouring council clean-ups and get on with scheduling rehearsals
  • Patrick can stop juggling figures and get on with learning lines
  • Gordon can stop getting quotes and just design a beautiful set
  • Vaike can sleep at night
  • We might get an extra slice of pizza each at the bump-in!


Other Ways You Can Help...

Can't donate?

  • Pass this campaign on to others who could donate...
  • Get the word out about the show
  • Buy your tickets in advance - give us some confidence
  • Buy tickets for early in the season - the final weeks always go well but we need early audience
  • Make a group booking, or at least bring a friend! (It's a great date night show)

story:
Hello, we are the Centre of Movement School of Performing Arts!

Recently celebrating our 35th anniversary in the small town of Gorham, Maine. The Centre is primarily a dance school, but is also active in other performing arts such as theater and voice.  The school has a reputation for quality dance education  for which we are grateful.   The Centre was the former Grange Hall for the town of Gorham in the late 1800's.  Like the purpose of the Grange Hall, which was to band families together, the Centre of Movement does the same thing- brings families together. The Centre offers classes to students of all ages and abilities. We are proud of all of our students; many have moved on and are teaching, choreographing and performing all over the world.  

The Town of Gorham has adopted many new ordinances over that years that need to be adhered to. This is what brings us to our current predicament. The Centre is in need of a sprinkler system, an alarm system that is linked directly to our local fire department, and crash doors per the Town. We want to bring the building up to code for the safety of all of our students and others who visit the Centre. However, estimates gathered for the items mentioned are upwards of $80,000. The Centre simply cannot afford that.  At the advice of a local townsperson, we are turning to crowdfunding to assist us. We need your help. The future of the Centre of Movement is uncertain if the building cannot be brought up to code.

Now that you've read about who we are and our situation, we sincerely hope that you can help. However we understand that not everyone is able to contribute to our cause financially. If you are unable to help monetarily, we would appreciate that you would pass this page along to someone who may be able to. We appreciate the time you have taken to read our story, and we thank you for sharing this page with your friends and contacts. Many parts work together for the good of the whole- your support is greatly appreciated. Quick Links: Testimonials | More Videos
story_txt:
Hello, we are the Centre of Movement School of Performing Arts!


Recently celebrating our 35th anniversary in the small town of Gorham, Maine. The Centre is primarily a dance school, but is also active in other performing arts such as theater and voice.  The school has a reputation for quality dance education  for which we are grateful.   The Centre was the former Grange Hall for the town of Gorham in the late 1800's.  Like the purpose of the Grange Hall, which was to band families together, the Centre of Movement does the same thing- brings families together. The Centre offers classes to students of all ages and abilities. We are proud of all of our students; many have moved on and are teaching, choreographing and performing all over the world.  
The Town of Gorham has adopted many new ordinances over that years that need to be adhered to. This is what brings us to our current predicament. The Centre is in need of a sprinkler system, an alarm system that is linked directly to our local fire department, and crash doors per the Town. We want to bring the building up to code for the safety of all of our students and others who visit the Centre. However, estimates gathered for the items mentioned are upwards of $80,000. The Centre simply cannot afford that.  At the advice of a local townsperson, we are turning to crowdfunding to assist us. We need your help. The future of the Centre of Movement is uncertain if the building cannot be brought up to code.
Now that you've read about who we are and our situation, we sincerely hope that you can help. However we understand that not everyone is able to contribute to our cause financially. If you are unable to help monetarily, we would appreciate that you would pass this page along to someone who may be able to. We appreciate the time you have taken to read our story, and we thank you for sharing this page with your friends and contacts. Many parts work together for the good of the whole- your support is greatly appreciated. Quick Links: Testimonials | More Videos

story:
Berliner Luft! It's In The Air!

In a new cabaret play about Weimar Berlin, including the French, British and American influences on this time, we follow the story of two New York City burlesque performers as they tire of America and follow their dreams of dancing and adventure to Europe, naturally ending up in Berlin in the 1920s. All told through song, dance, story telling (and a little bit of striptease). Along the way they perform traditional vaudeville burlesque, tableaux vivant, can-can, charleston and experience true 20s Berlin, both glamorous and gritty. There are appearances by stars of the time including the Mata Hari, Claire Waldorf, Marlene Dietrich, Anita Berber, and even Maria from the film Metropolis. The play ends with an audience sing-a-long to Berliner Luft, leaving everyone in high spirits and loving the city. 

Immoral Babylon Productions is writing, producing and performing the play. We are a theatrical collective, an international team of acclaimed female performing artists based in Berlin. We are interdisciplinary, bringing to the stage singing, dancing, acting, comedy, and striptease, with the goal of telling the stories of memorable and influential women of our past. 

The show is approximately 90 minutes with two 45 minute sets.The first half is the journey to Berlin and the second half is in Berlin. The show will be performed in English, German and French, with subtitles where appropriate.

How You Can Help 

The play is written and we are currently in rehearsals putting the acts together. We need to fund the production for the first performances.  We are planning a preview performance in September 2014, and the Premiere in November 2014 with the goal to do at least a 6 night run after the premiere. 

In July 2013 we had a successful fundraising show "The Mad Money Honey Show" which raised the initial funds needed to start the project. We now need to raise 3000€ for:

  • Costumes, props, sets, video projection, music (1500€)
  • Venue and equipment rental (1000€)
  • Publicity (300€)
  • Other expenses (200€)

If we do not reach our funding goal we will try and supplement this funding with other funding opportunities and prioritise our expenses. If necessary, we will produce a smaller scale version of the play for our initial production, the show will go on! 

If we exceed our funding goal, then we will be able to increase the quality of the costumes, props and sets, and provide additional performances!!!

What We Can Offer

To show our appreciation of your contributions we are offering several perks ranging from personalized Thank Yous, opportunities to mingle with our cast, all the way up to Executive Producer Credits!

You can also choose to remain mysterious and donate any amount anonymously.

Every donation at every level is truly appreciated and useful. Thank you so much for your support! 

Our Goal

We are focused on female empowerment; the cultural and societal impact of earlier eras; innovative theatre performances; historically researched and inspired performance; and the development of eroticism, on stage and off, throughout history that led the way for feminism in Art and Culture today.

Many people have forgotten the cultural legacy and social mentality left behind by the Weimar Republic era in our contemporary art and societal behaviour. We want to explore the women of this time. Who they were? How did they get there? Where we can see their footprints in today's art and society? We seek to answer these questions in our play. 

We are bringing these historical women to life by portraying their stories and focusing on their eroticism and pioneering acts. Our play relates their stories to sexuality in the performative arts around the world from the 2nd half of the 19th century until the end of the Weimar Republic (1933), a period in time that opened the door for the liberation of the body and democratization of sexuality.

We debuted one of the dance pieces, The Can-Can, from the play at the Berlin Burlesque Festival, in September 2013.

Photo by John Paul Bichard

Four multi talented women, Lucky LU, Syren Joey, Champagne Sparkles and Little Miss Piss make up the heart of IBP. We have expertise not only in stage performance but also production, directing, design, script writing, translation, musical direction and dance choreography; we collaboratively research, write, design, produce and perform our projects. We have over 20 years of professional experience producing and creating shows overseas, 10 years of professional wig and make-up design, 10 years of writing and directing plays and starring in productions and years of technical training and performance.


Together with your help we can bring this play to life! We want to share the excitement and awe of the entertainment and women that influenced generations to come!

Even if you cannot donate, please share this with your friends and family!
Every euro and every share counts!


Special Thanks To:
Lasha Rostobaia - Costumes & Props
Gito Lima - Graphic Design
black on grey - Video
Purple Elephant Media - Video
John Paul Bichard - Photo

story:
What Is The Weather Project?

The Weather Project is a year-long art and science community engagement project, culminating this summer (August 9th) with a spectacular outdoor musical play, art exhibition, and weather-climate-energy expo at the Yulan Ball Field in Yulan, NY!

The seed of the project was planted in the winter of 2012, when NACL Artistic Director Tannis Kowalchuk, a native of Winnipeg, felt an odd sensation from the absence of snow upon the western Catskill landscape. "It was weird. I wanted to know why. I never really thought about the weather until it wasn't there; and then I started reading about what's going on with the climate--I became obsessed with climate science, weather data--and umbrellas. Everybody talked about how weird the weather had been, and of course the talk of climate change had been going on for years, but I felt unclear about what I could do, and just like Mark Twain (or whoever said it) said: "Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody ever does anything about it." But when I started digging around I found that some people, like the Sullivan Alliance for Sustainable Development (SASD), were quite actively engaged in the matter, and that local town boards in Sullivan County, NY were considering climate measures at their meetings. I met with our Town of Highland Supervisor and a co-director of SASD about creating an event that would bring more people into the conversation--and The Weather Project was born."

We were awarded a "creative placemaking" grant from the National Endowment for the Arts which laid the foundation for this huge community endeavor involving seven local arts, environmental, and civic organizations, one Yulan resident who happens to be a climate scientist for NASA, 25 professional artists, and over 35 individual community members from all walks of life who will participate in the play--not to mention the participants and attendees of our climate symposium and other Weather Project events over the past year.

When It Rains, It Pours

That's what we're hoping for here—a deluge of support! An amazing amount of energy and time have been committed to this project by the various participants, and now we turn to you, our friends around the country and the world to join with us and help us into the final stretch to make sure The Weather Project's message can engage and galvanize as many people as possible. Because, as our scientist collaborator, Elaine Matthews, puts it in plain English: "We are already committed to climate change. If we were to turn off all the greenhouse emissions in the whole world today, the Earth would continue to warm for another 60 years." Scientific data shows it is happening. Models predict that the effects in some parts of the world will be catastrophic. Are we going to just continue on and hope for the best? Should we change the course we're on? Can we? How can we move from "it's a hopeless cause" to "what can I do to help?" These are the important questions of The Weather Project.


What We Need

We currently need to raise another $15,000 to successfully mount the production we have envisioned and have been preparing for over a year. With your help we hope to raise a portion of that amount through this Indiegogo campaign. These funds will help us pay for critical expenses including advertising in local media outlets, promotional materials, and signage. Your donation will help pay for costumes, staging, microphone rentals, and technical support, and will also help us create a professional video documentary of the performance to serve as a model for others who wish to energize and mobilize their communities, and to extend the reach of our message to those who can't be with us on August 9th.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount you can contribute is welcome, but there are also other ways you can support our efforts:

  • Bring your family and neighbors to The Weather Project Community Play & Expo on August 9th.
  • Please help us spread the word across the web by sharing this campaign with others who care. Use the handy Indiegogo share tools!


Who We Are

NACL stands for North American Cultural Laboratory, an ensemble theatre company formed in 1997 by Canadian actress Tannis Kowalchuk and American director Brad Krumholz. Since 2000 the company has served Upper Delaware Valley residents in New York and Pennsylvania an eclectic bill of arts programming from its Catskill base in Highland Lake, New York.

Our community partners in The Weather Project include: The Town of Highland, NY, Sullivan Alliance for Sustainable Development, Delaware Valley Arts Alliance, Catskill Art Society, Western Sullivan Public Library, Eldred Central School, The Homestead School, Delaware Highlands Conservancy / Eagle Institute, Catskill Mountainkeeper.

story:
Incineration Congregation at Burning Man's Conclave

Every year at Burning Man, fire groups from around the world perform their own choreographed ceremonial dance in celebration and in dedication to the honor of the "Man", prior to it be burned to the ground.   This is the largest convergence of fire performers in the world.  

Incineration Congregation has been given the opportunity to create a dedicated group of fire spinners from the Boston area to perform at the 2014 fire conclave.  Currently, our conclave consists of over thirty individual that are fire performers, drummers, choreographers, fire safeties, and videographers. We will be the first Boston based fire conclave to perform at Burning man since 2008.  

By supporting Incineration Congregation, you will help bring Boston's conclave back to Burning Man for the first time in over six years.  So please help us bring our gift of fire back to the playa. 

We are fully committed to bringing Boston back!

We are asking $3000 from the community to purchase:

  • Fuel to burn while fire dancing during rehearsal and our final performance on playa.
  • Shipping cost for fire conclave equipment from Boston to Black Rock City, Nevada
  • Fund the creation of new and interesting fire props for our performance
  • Dedicated matching costumes to wear during the performance.
  • Safety equipment such as buckets, fire blankets, fire extinguishers, protective tarps, fueling stations and more.

PROJECTED EXPENSES

  • Safety Equipment - $300
  • Prop Construction - $550
  • Fuel Expenses -  $550
  • Costuming -  $1000
  • Transportation -  $450
  • Rehearsal Space - $350

TOTAL:                    $3000

Help spread the word about the Incineration Congregation Online

Can’t contribute right now? That doesn't mean you can’t help out:

  • Repost this Indigogo fundraiser on Facebook, Google + and other social networking sites to help spread the word.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Spread the word to other members of the fire community and burning man community.

story:
Short Summary

We are Julia Siedlanowska and Kara Nolte: the directors of Shakespeare Unchained. We have a mutual love for the ridiculously serious and theatrically rhythmic. Our paths first crossed while studying theatre at Douglas College and have just begun producing, directing and creating our first show together.

The inaugural incarnation of Shakespeare Unchained is set to premiere in June 2014. We are seeking funds to pay all the people involved in creating the show. That means the directors (us), performers, photographer, sound designer and marketing. We need to be able to put our ideas into action and get this party off the ground!

Shakespeare Unchained breaks down the text of classic Shakespeare plays and interprets it through the actions of the performers' voices and bodies. We will use techniques from contemporary, classical dance and physical theatre and all will be accompanied by an original sound score.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2184 to get the first phase of development going. Here is where the money will go if we make our goal:

Indie GoGo's Cut of 4%: $84

Performers fees (approximately eight rehearsals of three hours each = 18 hours per performer, plus one evening of performing. Equals about $11/hour) $250 honorarium x four performers = $1000

Directors/Choreographers fees (approximately five hours per week of researching, promoting, and completing administrative tasks, preparing rehearsals, plus 100 plus hours of rehearsal time Equals about $2/hour) $400 honorarium x 2 directors/choreographers = $800

Rehearsal space: Generously donated by Black Suns Studio and Douglas College

Sound Designer Honorarium: $100

Photographer Honorarium: $100

Advertising: $100

We have some pretty rad perks for our generous donors:

Personal online thank you on Julia and Kara's Social Media pages, the Shakespeare Unchained Blog and the Shakespeare Unchained FB Page! Shout out!

Early bird emailed preview of characters interpreted for show and backgrounds on the play! Get the text breakdown behind the movement!

Handmade, signed Shakespeare themed cards from directors! You will want to frame these!

One hour personalized dance or acting class by one of the directors! We would love to get into the studio with you!

Exclusive invite to last rehearsal before show and cast wrap party! Get to know our performers and share your feedback with them once you've seen the show!

If we don't reach our entire goal, we will split the money using the same breakdown of resources we have set in our goal. Everyone involved will be compensated as fairly as we can manage.

The Impact

We want to create exciting work for our communities to enjoy. Shakespeare is recognizable and filled with dramatic, entertaining characters. We want to show people another interpretation of these classic characters.

The potential we see in maximizing the audience's enjoyment by blending dance and theatre is endless. Bringing these two ways of interpreting character together makes the experience more accessible, more fun and more versatile. A show of this sort could be performed anywhere! We see it going into schools, senior's centres, festivals, and coffee shops. This is a high impact idea for our community!

Both of us have experience with similar projects:

  • Kara co-directs a dance entertainment company called DK Dance Entertainment that brings dance into weddings, corporate events and parties

  • Julia adapted, translated and directed “Jack and Maggie,” (performed at the BC Children’s hospital) an adaptation of an old Polish folk-tale. Currently she is touring “Jack and Maggie” to community centres and schools

  • Kara has collaborated on projects that were presented at the BC Buds Festival, the In the House Festival, the Young Playwright’s Festival at the Cultch, Performance Incubator, Across Oceans (Toronto), Schaffhauser Kulturfest (Switzerland) and with Rococo Cabaret

  • Julia recently collaborated with Rebel Haunt Theatre’s director Sarah Dixon on a micro-epic theatre piece entitled “The Kiss,” which was the opening act for the Port Moody Arts Festival

Our full biographies, performer information and more can be found at our Shakespeare Unchained Blog and Facebook Page:

www.shakespeareunchained.wordpress.com

www.facebook.com/ShakespeareUnchained

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many aspects to this campaign. We don't just want to raise funds, we want to create a community around us! Here are other ways you can be involved besides monetary donations:

  1. Social Media: Interact with us on Facebook, Like us, Share our posts. Follow our Blog and share on your Social Media Pages. Comment on our posts, share your thoughts with us!

  2. Share with your friends, family, co-workers, health care practitioners, teachers, students, barista, cab driver, cable guy...the list goes one. Seriously this is all about word of mouth. Send an email, a text, let someone know who you know would dig what we are doing.

  3. Contribute a perk. Do you have an awesome jewelery business? Are you a super talented chef? Run a landscaping company? Incredibly skilled at knitting? We would love to offer you some cross promotion and have a product or service of yours offered as a perk! That way you get business and we get to show off our legit supporters.

  4. Contribute your skill. Are you looking for a volunteer marketing or advertising opportunity? Have some social media skills you would like to practice and a way to boost your resume? What about costume design? If you are newly graduated or looking for a way to keep your skills fresh we could use your specialized training and ideas. We would be thrilled to have you!

  5. Lastly please use the Indiegogo share tools to get our campaign out there!

Thank you for your time and consideration! You all rock!

directors! We would love to get into the studio with you!
Exclusive invite to last rehearsal before show and cast wrap
party! Get to know our performers and share your feedback with them
once you've seen the show!
If we don't reach our entire goal, we will split the money using
the same breakdown of resources we have set in our goal. Everyone
involved will be compensated as fairly as we can manage.
The Impact
We want to create exciting work for our communities to enjoy.
Shakespeare is recognizable and filled with dramatic, entertaining
characters. We want to show people another interpretation of these
classic characters.
The potential we see in maximizing the audience's enjoyment by
blending dance and theatre is endless. Bringing these two ways of
interpreting character together makes the experience more accessible,
more fun and more versatile. A show of this sort could be performed
anywhere! We see it going into schools, senior's centres, festivals,
and coffee shops. This is a high impact idea for our community!
Both of us have experience with similar projects:


Kara co-directs a dance
	entertainment company called DK Dance Entertainment that brings
	dance into weddings, corporate events and parties


Julia adapted, translated and
	directed “Jack and Maggie,” (performed at the BC Children’s
	hospital) an adaptation of an old Polish folk-tale. Currently
	she is touring “Jack and Maggie” to community centres and
	schools


Kara has collaborated on projects
	that were presented at the BC Buds Festival, the In the House
	Festival, the Young Playwright’s Festival at the Cultch,
	Performance Incubator, Across Oceans (Toronto), Schaffhauser
	Kulturfest (Switzerland) and with Rococo Cabaret


Julia recently collaborated with Rebel Haunt Theatre’s
	director Sarah Dixon on a micro-epic theatre piece entitled “The
	Kiss,” which was the opening act for the Port Moody Arts Festival

Our full biographies, performer information and more can be found
at our Shakespeare Unchained Blog and Facebook Page:
www.shakespeareunchained.wordpress.com
www.facebook.com/ShakespeareUnchained
Other Ways You Can Help
There are so many aspects to this campaign. We don't just want to
raise funds, we want to create a community around us! Here are other
ways you can be involved besides monetary donations:


Social Media: Interact with us on
	Facebook,
	Like us, Share our posts. Follow our Blog
	and share on your Social Media Pages. Comment on our posts, share
	your thoughts with us!


Share with your friends, family,
	co-workers, health care practitioners, teachers, students, barista,
	cab driver, cable guy...the list goes one. Seriously this is all
	about word of mouth. Send an email, a text, let someone know who you
	know would dig what we are doing.


Contribute a perk. Do you have an
	awesome jewelery business? Are you a super talented chef? Run a
	landscaping company? Incredibly skilled at knitting? We would love
	to offer you some cross promotion and have a product or service of
	yours offered as a perk! That way you get business and we get to
	show off our legit supporters.


Contribute your skill. Are you
	looking for a volunteer marketing or advertising opportunity? Have
	some social media skills you would like to practice and a way to
	boost your resume? What about costume design? If you are newly
	graduated or looking for a way to keep your skills fresh we could
	use your specialized training and ideas. We would be thrilled to
	have you!


Lastly please use the Indiegogo share tools to get our
	campaign out there!

Thank you for your time and consideration! You all rock!

story:
Sometimes, the greatest injustice is the justice system itself. . .

Life Without Parole, a new stage play by Warren Doody, is inspired by Dr. Elizabeth Dermody Leonard’s Convicted Survivors: The Imprisonment of Battered Women Who Kill. This play draws from the actual words of real women incarcerated at the California Institution for Women at Chino for killing their abusive partners. These domestic violence survivors are serving extended or life sentences for defending themselves or their children against a domestic attacker. This play takes you "behind the barbed wire" exposing how these real women bond together and through exploring their pasts are able to survive when orange becomes their new black & blue. 


This powerful play has been selected from thousands of international applicants to be presented in the 2014 New York Fringe Festival by Working Artists Theatre Project (WAT Project) in association with Karah Gravatt. 

Our production will be produced in loving memory of Dr. Elizabeth Leonard 1948-2014 who inspired so many to make a difference with her powerful work.

WAT Project is an accomplished not-for-profit theatre company with a nine-year history and we're passionate about producing theatre that raises awareness, educates, and creates a burning call to action to make a difference. 


Why YOUR Help is Super Important?

Producing Life WIthout Parole at the New York Fringe Festival isn't cheap. We'll need over $6000 to share these stories and further educate audiences about domestic violence survivors in our justice system. Whether we reach our goal or not EVERY generous dollar will pay for production, marketing, & outreach efforts to create a strong platform for future productions:

  • Festival application fee (a whopping $700 this year!)
  • Rehearsal Space (space to create in NYC is always a huge expense)
  • Cast & crew stipends (an Equity cast of 8 actors will total $2800)
  • Marketing materials (Press Releases, Press Packets, & Posters cost $ too)
  • Advertising Space ( 1 reputable ad alone can cost $1000)
  • Costumes & Props
  • Lighting 
  • Insurance (another big cost at an estimated $500)
  • Archival photography and video
  • Website Costs
  • Community outreach and support of other Domestic Violence Initiatives
  
The Impact of Your Donation

At its core, Life Without Parole is much more than a play, it is a glaring call to action for people to face the complex issues of domestic violence that are so often ignored. Your donation toward producing Life Without Parole will have a direct impact in supporting the cause. Through producing this play, it is our goal to create strong partnerships with prominent Domestic Violence organizations in order to create a strong platform to further promote awareness about the domestic violence issues that afflict millions of men, women, and children worldwide. Through sharing a percentage of our box office with organizations such as Safe Horizons, Women's Prison Association, and others our reach will go far beyond the shows production. 

Your donation will also facilitate our post show audience discussion forums where audiences will have the immediate opportunity to connect with information about these organizations and discuss their experience with the play.

Join our LWP Community, grab yourself one of our amazing perks, and make a direct difference today.


So who are we really? 

Working Artists Theatre Project (PRODUCER)

CONNECT | CREATE | CULTIVATE

a 501(c) 3 not-for-profit organization, offers artistic growth opportunities for industry professionals through the development of innovative and intelligent productions. Founded by Broadway professionals, WAT PROJECT serves as a forum tailored for working and emerging artists to expand their experience to encompass a variety of theatrical fields and careers. The company is dedicated to showcasing talent, facilitating the artist’s evolution, providing career transition opportunities, and building genuine relationships within the New York artistic community. www.WATProject.com

Karah Gravatt (PRODUCER)

has appeared in a variety of theatre, film and television productions in both New York City and Southern California, and she has received training with Stella Adler, Upright Cizens Brigade and Manhattan Theater Company. In 2009, she played the role of Barbara in Life Without Parole with a cast that spent a year touring the play at various universities and venues, a series of productions that culminated in its inclusion at the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival, as well as a performance at the California Institution for Women at Chino in front of the very women whose words inspired the writing of the script. In addition to her work promoting Life Without Parole, Karah continues to develop her theatrical skill set. She has taken an active interest in the business side of the theatre world, while remaining committed to the rigors of the stage as an actress. www.KarahGravatt.net

Jessica Dermody (DIRECTOR & CONSULTING PRODUCER)

is a multi-passionate entertainment industry professional, making a living while being creative in New York City. She's been working professionally since childhood and has both a formal education and decades of practical experience on stage and behind the scenes in theatre, live concert events, industrials, print, film, and television. Producer of the critically acclaimed Broadway runs of Superior Donuts, Green Day's American Idiot (nominations for both a Drama Desk and TONY Award for Best Musical) and the 10th Anniversary, 9/11 Benefit production of 110 Stories. Associate Producer of the award winning independent feature film, "Construction". Co-Founder and Executive Managing Artistic Director of Working Artists Theatre Project since 2005. Selected Directing:Life Without Parole (sold our run at MRT),WELCOME TO THE JUNGLE! (Ars Nova, Official selection of ANT Fest 2013) Fruits Unheard Of (U.S. Premiere), Open Call! (chashama/NEA), Clown (World Premiere), Tall Tales from the Little Black Book (U.S. Premiere), Mercury (U.S. Premiere) Proud graduate of Florida State University, School of Theatre. www.JessicaDermody.com                                                                 

Warren Doody (PLAYWRIGHT)

is Professor of English at Vanguard University, where he has taught for the last fifteen years. The writer of numerous plays, screenplays, and short stories, he has won multiple awards for his work. His most recent work includes the West Coast premieres of “Enlightenment.com” at American Coast Theatre Company, and “Development” at Vanguard University. His play, “Life Without Parole,” has received productions in Canada and the United States, and it was a finalist for the 2009 Kennedy Center American College Regional Theatre Festival.

Dr. Elizabeth Leonard (INSPIRATION)

 The late Professor Emerita of Sociology at Vanguard University where her course offerings included Family Violence, Sociology of Women, Introduction to Sociology, Criminology, and Sociology of Corrections. She received her Ph.D. in 1997 from the University of California, Riverside. Her book “Convicted Survivors: The Imprisonment of Battered Women Who Kill” (State University of NY 2002) is being used by legislators, law professors, and advocates for convicted battered women. Dr. Leonard’s research provided the basis for the play by Warren Doody, Life Without Parole. She is the featured expert and consultant on the film documentary, Sin by Silence, by Olivia Klaus Quiet Little Place Productions (2007).

Olivia Klaus (CONSULTING PRODUCER/DOCUMENTARIAN)

is an award-winning documentary filmmaker who passionately believes in the power of visual stories to create positive social change. Her various roles in production have helped create projects that have dealt with such issues as human rights, incarceration, poverty, and domestic violence.  Her work has been seen on various networks like CNN, HLN, Discovery, Showtime, MTV, and The History Channel. She was listed by Pixel Project as one of the “2010 Top 16 Influential Leaders in the Movement to End Violence Against Women”.

For More Information about us please visit:              www.lifewithoutparoleplay.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate in cash? No sweat! We'll take your "word of mouth" donation any day. Spreading word about our campaign is just as good as money in the bank to us. So shout it from the roof tops, tweet, post, and tell your friends, family, and every stranger you meet. It helps us out big time & we sure do appreciate it!

Our Website: www.LifeWithoutParolePlay.com

Facebook: www.facebook.com/lifewithoutparoleplay

Twitter: @LWPNYC

Or check out the share features right here in Indie Go Go!

In loving memory of Dr. Elizabeth Dermody Leonard 1948-2014

story:
We are so excited to make this project happen. We are here asking for half of our overall budget. Our current goal will go towards our theatre rental for a 4 week, 15 performances rental! Here is what we'll be able to cover according to the amount we reach:

 $12,000

 Venue Rental

 $15, 000

+ Rehearsal Space + Props +Lights + Costumes

 $20,000

 + Artist Fees (Actors, Director, Designers, Stage Manager, Playwright...)

 $24,000

 + Marketing/Publicity + Insurance

We are a fiscally sponsored project, which means your donations will be tax deductible (US). As all non-profits here, we rely on 80% of our donations to come from private donors, yes you! :) Which is why you are so important to us, we really need your support.

3rd KULTURE KIDS

3rd Kulture Kids is a theatre and film production company based in NYC dedicated to the lost citizens of the World. Our mission is to produce new/contemporary work created by multicultural artists, spreading their unique and varied perspective on life. 3k² will generate a range of entertainment, reflective of the diversity of our globalized modern world.

Our aim is to form a hub for multicultural artists who do not necessarily affiliate with a single culture; a place that celebrates the power of storytelling regardless of gender, color or nationality.

Why don’t we open new doors and see on stage a reflection of what is currently happening in the world?

Fact is: Theatre in the city is not as diverse as the actual city.

Below are stats published by the Asian American Performers Action Coalition:

Ethnic make up of cast on broadway and non profit theatres 2011-2012

When in fact, more then half of the population is non-caucasian.

Gender inequality is also flagrant in theatre, with women usually cast in supporting role:

             

Help us open new doors, and create entertainment reflective of the 21st century! 

THE PLAY

We live in a world full of conflicts. Whether based in a country directly or indirectly involved in it, it is there. We hear about it every single day on the news. A lot of family have migrated as a result, raising their children in a multicultural environment. But what is it truly like to live day in, day out, in those extreme conditions?

Here is a little video of Chantal Bilodeau, Holy Land's translator, talking about the play:


This will be the US PREMIERE of the play who has had a lot of success worldwide. Holy Land has been translated into several languages and had productions and received rave reviews in Paris, Vienna, Prague, London, Milan, Jerusalem, Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paolo, Stockholm, Hamburg and the Avignon Festival.

A city under siege. The landscape is white, dusty and devastated. Carmen has disappeared at a checkpoint. Her daughter Imen must face the soldier’s house searches alone, a soldier who listens to Stravinsky. In the house next door, Alia, the midwife, prepares her coffee as if nothing else matters while Yad, her husband, gets away from it all by smoking tobacco and drinking arak.  The only hope seems to reside in Jesus: the cat. A dark and humorous story of 5 characters hanging on to the banality of day-to-day life, at times to the point of insanity, as a way to transcend the atrocities of war.

BIOS

MOHAMED KACIMI (playwright) was born in Algeria in a family of theologians. Mohamed is a poet, playwright, novelist, translator, journalist and the president of Écritures du Monde - an organization that puts together international writing residencies. He is a recipient of the Prix Lugano du théâtre, the 2005 Prix SACD de la francophonie and a Jury Special Mention from the Grand Prix de littérature dramatique 2007. His plays have been translated into several languages and been performed worldwide. He has written multiple books including an encyclopedia of the Arab world for children. He is based in Paris.

CHANTAL BILODEAU (Translator) is a New York-based playwright and translator originally from Montreal, Canada. Her plays and translations have been presented in the U.S., Canada, Mexico and Italy. Recent awards include the Woodward International Playwriting Prize, First Prize in the 2011 Uprising National Playwriting Competition, 2012 Earth Matters on Stage Ecodrama Festival. She has translated over a dozen plays by contemporary playwrights Sébastien David (Quebec), Mohamed Kacimi (Algeria), Koffi Kwahulé (Côte d’Ivoire), Étienne Lepage (Quebec) and Larry Tremblay (Quebec). www.cbilodeau.com and artistsandclimatechange.com

TRACY CAMERON FRANCIS (Director) is an Egyptian-American theatre director and interdisciplinary artist.  She has directed and developed work with HERE, Red Bull Theatre, New York Theatre Workshop, Williamstown Theatre Festival, LaMama Umbria (Italy), NY Arab American Comedy Festival, CultureHub (Lamama), Monarch Theatre Co., NY International Fringe Festival, Falaki Theatre (Egypt), Alwan For the Arts, International Wow, EBE Ensemble-among others.  She has worked as a teaching artist for recent immigrants at The International Center in NY and has been invited to present at numerous conferences on international collaboration and Middle East Theatre (Georgetown, Brown University). Tracy is the Artistic Director of Hybrid Theatre Works, core member of Theatre Without Borders, member of Lincoln Center Directors Lab and associate members of SDC.

And please, spread the word, pass it on! Thank you so much!!

Many thanks to Diane Zouein for the amazing animation www.dianezouein.com and Karim Douaidy for the beautiful music www.karimdouaidy.com
