story:
Short Summary

Three years ago, a chance meeting of three theatre artists in New York spawned a dream. A director from Italy, an actor from Colombia and an actress from Australia began an epic journey of cross-cultural collaboration. The idea was to create a theatrical experience exploring the disparity between the rich and poor in contemporary society which would speak to a diverse international audience. The result was a modern re-imagining of August Strindberg's Miss Julie, performed in English and Spanish. Our dream was to eventually perform in the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogotá, and this year that dream will come true. After a season in Bogotá in August 2013, Miss Julia was invited to be a part of the festival's 2014 Colombian program.

http://festivaldeteatro.com.co/ (full Colombian program to be announced soon)

This new bi-lingual adaptation by SITI Company's J.Ed Araiza brings together 7 artists from 4 different countries! Miss Julia is an international collaboration between renowned Colombian film and television actor Jhon Alex Toro, Australian theatre artist Tina Thurman, Colombian actress Gina Jaimes, Italian Stage Director Lorenzo Montanini, with music by US violinist Helen Yee and Colombian percussionists Juan Manuel Vergara and Daiana Mutis. 

Set in Colombia on Midsummer Eve, Miss Julia and her servant Juan have an encounter that will change their lives forever. As Juan tries to rise from the depths of his servile life, Miss Julia wants to escape the bonds that tie her to a meaningless upper-class existence. The result is a power play of love, lust and a battle of the classes which becomes violent and seemingly out of control.

This bi-lingual production, performed in English and Spanish, will be a clash of cultures, a dance of death combining heightened physicality and rich naturalistic text. This unique take on Strindberg's text makes Miss Julia as profound today as it was 100 years ago.

What We Need & What You Get

To make this international collaboration a reality we need to raise funds for the artists airfares to Colombia. We have a number of exciting perks including unique photographs of our time in Bogotá, personalized behind the scenes DVD's, audition coaching, sunset sailing cruises on the Hudson river, personal concerts and dinners cooked in your home, by members of the cast.

Other ways in which people can help is by sharing this campaign on social media or we will also take donations of Frequent Flyer points.

The Impact

Our goal is to promote cultural exchange between Colombia, the US, Australia and Italy by presenting a classic piece of drama that is accessible to both Spanish and English speakers and to those who are not regular theatre goers. At the Iberoamericano Festival we will also have the chance to perform for and meet international producers and presenters with the ultimate goal of touring the piece globally.
story_txt:
Short SummaryThree years ago, a chance meeting of three theatre artists in New York spawned a dream. A director from Italy, an actor from Colombia and an actress from Australia began an epic journey of cross-cultural collaboration. The idea was to create a theatrical experience exploring the disparity between the rich and poor in contemporary society which would speak to a diverse international audience. The result was a modern re-imagining of August Strindberg's Miss Julie, performed in English and Spanish. Our dream was to eventually perform in the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogotá, and this year that dream will come true. After a season in Bogotá in August 2013, Miss Julia was invited to be a part of the festival's 2014 Colombian program. http://festivaldeteatro.com.co/ (full Colombian program to be announced soon)

story:
aWe Creative Group is comprised of like-minded Artists, Writers and Entertainers whose main objective is to create, grow and inspire. Our main focus is creating aWe inspiring original pieces developed through a collaborative process, that can educate, inform and spark a creative domino effect.  ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE.

 

Our Story: aWe Creative Group was founded in 2005 by Amy E. Witting and her constant collaborators Kerry Fitzgibbons and Billy Weimer.  In 2009 the quartet was complete when Amy met Tiffany May McRae teaching theatre in Ecuador with Dramatic Adventure Theatre.  Together we have been working on the play G.I. Joe Jared; Based on One Really Bad Date for over a year now. Due to the overwhelmingly positive response to the play we decided it had to keep moving and growing. Meanwhile Amy (the playwright) visited Scotland last August and attended the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and a plan was hatched- G.I. Joe Jared must be performed in the festival. Once the plan was put in motion we were surprised by the news that G.I. Joe Jared; Based on One Really Bad Date will be published this Spring by The New York Theatre Experience!
 
Impact: It is important for aWe Creative Group to show the world what is happening in NYC in blackbox theaters, more often than not, it's the best stuff going on in the city and this play is no exception. It is a beautiful play about friendships, loss, and horribly awkward dates. We are hoping to raise enough money to get there and show the world what a special piece this is, and if we don't reach our goal, we're going anyway. We just may be in some debt :) If we pass our goal we will put the money towards our fall production of On Halloween Night, as well as a Children's Show, The Untitled AWE Project. aWe Creative Group has been working toward creating a Children’s Theatre Curriculum that will be launched in 2012.  Through Amy E. Witting’s twenty years of babysitting experience, along with the impact Children’s Theatre Programs had on each member of aWe Creative Group it’s become a passion to create a program that will keep the arts alive in children who don’t have access to arts programs in their schools. 
 
What we need, what you get and where is your money going: Our ultimate goal for aWe Creative Group is to raise $32,000 to produce our fall production of On Halloween Night, as well as, launch our Children’s Theatre Program.  Our initial fundraising goal for The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is $10,000.  We are hoping to raise $10,000 in order to produce our play here at East to Edinburgh in July and bring a cast/crew of five to Scotland for three weeks in August. You will have the opportunity to donate in $20, $50, $100, $250, $500 and $1000 increments, but anything you would like to donate would be much appreciated. For your donations you will receive anything from a picture of Tiffany looking up a kilt, a magnet, a signed copy of the play, two tickets to the NYC East of Edinburgh production, and to our top donors a very special "reading" with Jared. Your donations would go towards travel expenses, entrance fees, program fees, advertising, costumes, rehearsal space, and perhaps a meal or two.  If we surpass our goal we will be using the money for our fall production of On Halloween Night, and our upcoming Children's Show--The Untitled AWE Project  expected to premier Winter - 2012. 
 
 Other Ways To Help: We will be performing at East of Edinburgh which is in NYC, July12th, 13th, 14th at 7pm and July 16th at 2pm at the 59E59 Theatres. So please come see us then and tell your friends! You will have a special opportunity to see the playwright perform in the play on July 16th at 2pm.  She will be the understudy in Scotland, and is busting out her acting chops for one performance only in NYC!
 
Thank you so much for your time and support- aWe Creative Group truly appreciates it and sends the love right back!

story:
THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR HELPING TO MAKE OUR CAMPAIGN A SUCCESS!

We're so humbled by all of the generous support - but we're not done yet!  We still have time in our campaign and have heard that there are still people out there that want to donate so we've set a new goal - $2500!

Why $2500? (Or why can't we just be happy about the $1500?)  Because this venture isn't a one time project. 

Our last company meeting was electrified with all the ideas our members have for future projects and productions!  Every dollar we fundraise and don't use for this production of Island helps us be that much closer to making those exciting productions a reality - here's a teaser of some of the inspiring work we're looking forward to bringing you:

  • A full production of Island outside of the Festival format
  • A series of plays structured around the work of an underappreciated Japanese playwright with actors and puppets sharing the stage
  • A top secret project that will allow our group to produce our first collaboratively created show
  • A fun romp through the brain of one of our group's own members
  • An existential production that is updated for today's audience
  • and much, much more!

Our Story

Island is the inaugural presentation of the newly formed Black Cat Theatre Group - a venture over 10 years in the making. 

We have been working on the play for several weeks in anticipation of a presentation in August 2011 but we just received word that we have been accepted to present at the BoCoCa Arts Festival!

What does that mean?  That means we have just over a month to raise the funds we need to produce in the festival - and that's where you come in...

The Impact

Your financial support of this project not only secures our ability to produce this production but also demonstrates to future funders that we have a base of supporters for our organization, allowing us to have a strong showing for foundations and companies that may grant funds for future projects.  

Your donation today ensures our success and sustainability tomorrow.


Why $1500?

Why $1500?  With complete funding we will be able to: secure our spot for the festival, build costumes for our performers, purchase props, rent lighting and sound equipment, execute a marketing plan that we hope will sell out our tickets, and cover any last minute details or emergency expenses.

Additionally, every dollar that we fund above the $1500 goal goes towards securing a venue for our August 2011 presentation of Island.  And we cannot say enough that whether you donate $5 or $500 your donation MATTERS.


Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways to help other than donating money (although we hope you'll do that too)!

Follow us on Twitter, Like our page on Facebook, share this campaign with others (via the neat tools above and below), and/or buy a ticket to the show (details coming soon)!

About the Play

New playwright Ben Ellentuck's latest work is a tale about memory, about relationships, and about fate. The woman searches for a husband she cannot remember as the man tries to piece together what it is about her that he cannot place.

Island's study of relationships and how those relationships inform our identity are carefully and subtly addressed. This leaves room for the play’s main theme to break through and touch on a fear that exists for all of us - exploring what memory means to us and revealing the tragedy of when it fails us - when the forgetting defines us. Ellentuck’s witty prose keeps subject matter that could otherwise be heavy and deeply tragic lightly balanced with comedy and absurdity.


About Black Cat Theatre Group

Black Cat Theatre Group is committed to producing performances that revive the fundamental human connection that differentiates theater from all other entertainment options. We have an uncompromising dedication to make our productions accessible to the widest possible audience while keeping our ticket prices affordable. We believe in making theatre part of the popular culture again by exposing the greater community to work that provokes introspection and social awareness; reinstating the theatre as a cultural force inspiring both individual and societal change.

story:
Co-presented by Pangea World Theater, 20% Theatre Company and Rare Productions, the first-ever MORPHOLOGIES: Queer Performance Festival will present performance and collaborative arts that expose, highlight and expand the spectrum of queer expression and culture, and the transformative social impact it has on the world.

MORPHOLOGIES promotes the lives, politics, and experiences of the queer community, both locally and nationally.

The festival will take place November 9-19, 2012, in Minneapolis, and will feature performances by:

  • Scott Turner Schofield (11/9-11/10)
  • Ryka Aoki de la Cruz (11/12)
  • D'Lo (11/14-11/15)
  • Andrea Assaf & Samuel Valdez in Outside the Circle (11/16-11/17)
  • Qwo-Li Driskill (11/18-11/19)
  • and more local artists to be announced!

For a more in-depth schedule please visit www.pangeaworldtheater.org or www.tctwentypercent.org.

Venues include The Ritz Theater and Intermedia Arts. There will also be panels and workshops throughout the Festival.

FESTIVAL GOALS: 1) shift consciousness of/about queer identity through performance; 2) maintain and contribute to the growth of professional and emerging queer performers; 3) facilitate conversation surrounding queer identities challenge mainstream notions of gender and sexuality; 4) foster multicultural queer experience.

Please consider a tax-deductible donation in support of the first Morphologies: Queer Performance Festival. Grants and ticket sales can only cover so much, and we still need to raise $3500 to support accessibility and outreach efforts -- including funds for ASL-interpreters, outreach/marketing, and for scholarships for tickets and workshops.

Whether you can give $10 or $100 or $1000, every dollar will help us ensure that this Festival is accessible to all.

Donate $25 or more and see a Festival performance for free! Check out the donation levels for specific perks!

Other Ways You Can Help: Please share this Indiegogo page and spread the word! Contact us to find out more about other ways you can help support this Festival and how to volutneer - info@tctwentypercent.org or pangea@pangeaworldtheater.org.

THANK YOU!

story:
Help Further Nia's Passion:

 

Join TEAM Nia today! Nia has the honor of being selected by world renowned Dance Theatre of Harlem to attend the 2013 Summer Intensive program which is two weeks long, Nia has also been selected by Northwest Tap Connection to attend The Chicago Rhythm Festival to participate in their intensive week long training workshops! I'm sure you'll agree this is a big deal. Nia loves various aspects of dance (as you'll see in her video). Nia promises to do her best which if you know her...you KNOW that's true. She will apply the same dedication and work ethic that she applied in becoming Student Body President. What an honor this is for Nia. She's simply buzzing with excitement. Her family sees this as a gateway to further her education with scholarships for college (which both her parents feel is coming quickly). Having these accomplishments on her transcripts will give Nia the edge that is needed for both academic and social advancement. 

 

 

What We Need & Why We Need It

 

This is the part that's tough...just being honest. However, you deserve to know especially since you are joining TEAM Nia. Although both parents are active in Nia's life let's face it the concept that it takes a village is more real today than ever before. Nia's mom Shawnette (for description purposes only) is technically a single mom. An incredible one if I may add. With that, she is the breadwinner for her family. She has never wanted to impede or stifle her children's ability to go after their dreams based on budget. This requires everyone to reassess what's important. The total amount needed is $7,777.00. This will cover travel expenses, food and lodging for Nia, Shawnette (her mom), and her sister Bria. They are definitely a package deal. The best part of this process is what it does for each of them. Nia gets to follow her bliss! Nia, indirectly gives Bria permission to go for her dreams (organically she does by watching their mother Shawnette) on an even grander scale. Shawnette gets to step outside of her comfort zone and watch her both of her daughters learn that there truly are no limitations if you work hard! What greater gift is there for a parent? 

 

One of the things that we think would be cool to offer for your support is a postcard from N.Y, Chicago or both (depending on your level of help). Nia will personally write them to each friendly sponsor. Another item is a ticket to one of her live performances if you live in the state of Washington (or have a scheduled trip that correlates). If you are out of area, a dvd of her performance will be provided in AVI format.

Although we can't imagine it happening if we don't with your help reach our entire goal we will continue to use the resources raised and you may see Nia & Co. tapping in Downtown Seattle to raise the difference. She's raised $200.06 so far. Don't you admire that she is out there doing her part? 

 

Another reason to join TEAM Nia!

 

What's Important About Joining TEAM Nia?

Glad you asked! I say that somewhat facetiously I admit. Allow me a couple of sentences to share. We ALL hear and read about children that are aimless, do we not? Well, here is an opportunity to help a child that has her head on straight, passionate about several things, well-rounded and kind. Here's a chance for you to actively make a difference. For the amount of your Starbuck's budget or one less pair of shoes from Macy's or Nordstrom's (Nordstrom's Rack included) you can send Nia to Dance Theatre Of Harlem and The Chicago Rhythm Festival. It will be greatly appreciated. Imagine how much her confidence will soar knowing that YOU believe in her! That's what's important about joining TEAM Nia.

 

It Takes A Village

We can't get Nia to both Chicago and New York alone we need your help! Please let people know about Nia. Tweet it, share the link on Facebook, Pinterest, MySpace (it's new and improved they say), email, Linked In and any other sites you are affiliated with. We are envisioning GREAT things for Nia. What's even better is that Nia is envisioning great things for herself! If people can spread links about cats, jokes, hollywood break-ups and everything in between...surely spreading the word about an incredible young lady is okay. I guess I should say imo (in my opinion) on that one.

Thank you for your consideration. To quote lil Miss Nia herself, "she'll do her best"!

story:
"Davide is dead. After little Giovanni, baby Davide is dead too. His life was a meteor. He left us at 7 months old. That tiny loving bundle has been devastated by cancer. He was from Acerra. Let’s cry.” Father M. Patriciello, Caivano, Italy, December 2016.

Davide was not the first and sadly not the last young victim of cancer due to toxic waste in the 'land of Fires". Too often, almost every week, one child dies.

We write to extend an invitation for you to join us in our mission to address the devastating environmental issue facing the residents of Campania, Italy, where for years, due to toxic waste and carcinogenic contaminants in the land and water supply, mothers are battling the loss of their children to cancer. As a native of Campania, this is a deeply important and emotional issue for me.

 

After reading The Gospels of the Land of Fire by Father Patriciello, and watching a collection of interviews with the suffering mothers of Campania, I was moved to act. As a trained choreographer and dancer, I began work on Terra dei Fuochi / Land of Fires, a performance project that blends the conventions of documentary theatre with modern dance to tell the story of the mothers of Campania. I started a dialogue with Marzia Caccioppoli and with the association Noi genitori di tutti www.noigenitoriditutti.it (We are the parents of all), an association of mothers and fathers from the region who have lost their children to cancer. Marzia lives in Casalnuovo di Napoli. Her family left Naples looking for a pleasant place with clean air in the countryside. Instead, her son Antonio died of cancer at the age of nine.

 

But we need your support. We need $9,000.00 to cover the last expenses of the project. We ask that you consider lending your financial support with the understanding that no donation is too small and all donations are tax-deductible for U.S. residents. A percentage of the donation will be given to Marzia and her Association.

To accompany the performance, an informational booth will provide details about the toxic waste situation afflicting Campania Felix and how this situation can be compared to others around the globe.  We aim to provide further education in the increasing land and water contamination issues facing our global community. 

Today, I am joined by an entire company of dedicated artists of excellence from Campania, and neighboring communities, in the creation of Terra dei Fuochi / Land of Fire, including Composer Alberto Falco (Napoli, Campania), Lighting Design concept Marcello Falco (Napoli, Campania), Dancers Bianca Delli Priscoli (Salerno, Campania) and Laura Orfanelli (Abruzzo).

We are proud to announce that La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club has invited Terra dei Fuochi / Land of Fires to receive its world premiere in March 2017, as part of their 55th season, and in doing so lend their support to the mission of the project.

We have been granted a residency as well by prestigious Chashama Org.. The residency took place December 7-20, 2016 with performances on December 15, 16, 17, 18.

 

*Performance photos by Barbara Gentile Photography

story:
Off the Middle - In Other Words

Off the Middle are a new theatre company dedicated to working with young talented theatre makers to produce playful and relevant new writing in London and across the UK.

Fresh from a residency at The Lyric Hammersmith as a result of their Emerging Artists Award, we are bringing our first production 'In Other Words' to The Hope Theatre from February 28th - March 18th.

'In Other Words' is a heart-warming, intimate, and deeply moving love story, which explores the effects of Alzheimer's disease, and the transformative power of music in our lives. Brought to life by two actors, we are led through fifty years of Arthur and Jane’s relationship. Focused on their connection to a Frank Sinatra song, we jump in and out of memories and experience, for brief moments, a failing mind as it loses its grip on reality.

We have an incredible production team in place, and are working with two amazing charities, The Alzheimer's Society and Playlist for Life. We need help raising the additional funds required to ensure this production reaches its full potential, and allows Off the Middle to share its work with as many people as possible.

Background

Matthew Seager wrote the first draft of 'In Other Words' in 2014 when facilitating music and reminiscence workshops in a dementia care home during his last year at University of Leeds. He was blown away by the effect playing relevant music could had on individuals. Residents who seemed totally unable to communicate and were cognitively unaware, would stand and sing along to a meaningful song from their early or adult life.

After an extremely well received work-in-progress performance at The Arches in Glasgow, 'In Other Words' was awarded a development residency at The Lyric Hammersmith in January 2016. Following a successful sharing of the work, we were delighted to be programmed by The Hope.

Our dedicated production team is comprised of new and existing company members all with plenty of experience in creating professional theatre of the highest quality.

Writer: Matthew Seager
Producer: Stephanie Withers
Director: Paul Brotherston
Assistant Director: Euan Tyre
Sound Designer: Iida Aino

What We Need & What You Get

We are proud to be working with The Hope Theatre, who have just been included in the final shortlist for the Fringe Theatre of the year UK at The Stage Awards. They were also the first Off West End venue to open with an in house agreement with Equity, to ensure a legal wage for all actors, stage managers and box office staff. It's extremely important to us that our fantastic cast and production team get paid a legal wage, and this is reflected in our campaign.

We are committed to making powerful and thought provoking theatre of the highest quality and, being a new company, need all the help and support we can get to be successful. We are asking for a additional funds to help contribute to all aspects of the project. This includes:

  • Cast and Stage Management wages (34 %)
  • Production team wages (35%)
  • PR and Marketing (8%)
  • Set, props and costume (6%)
  • Printing and media design (7%)
  • Rehearsal space (5%)
  • Contingency (5%)

We want to make sure you get us much out of this process as you can, and that we can thank you for your contributions. There are some lovely rewards on offer, which you can see on the side of this page.

Other Ways You Can Help

It is totally understandable if you feel unable to contribute financially, and we would like to highlight other ways you can support our company and this project.

Help us to make as much noise as possible by sharing this with your friends, family and colleagues, and pass on the information to anyone who you think might be interested.

Also, come to the show. We really believe that we're going to make something special, and want to share it with as many people as we possibly can.

Remember that you can also use the Indiegogo share tools. 

Thank you so much for any support you are able to offer in helping us tell this story.

'In Other Words' runs from February 28th - March 19 2017 at The Hope Theatre.
https://www.ticketsource.co.uk/event/166179

story:
Short Summary -

Very recently, I got the opportunity to audition for the very prestigious CAPA—Cape Academy of the Performing Arts– and to my delight, I got accepted to be a part of their Three Year Diploma Course.  The only problem with this is that I won’t be able to attend the  Three Year Diploma Course,  unless I get funding or sponsorship

What it means to me -

I can’t express to you, the amount of love that I have for dance; it’s my everything!  If it wasn’t for dancing, I wouldn’t be the person  that I am today—that’s just how much dance has shaped and been a part of my life. To get the opportunity to be a part of CAPA, means that I would be getting a chance to do what I love and hopefully,  make a career out of it.

The beautiful thing about dance, for me - is that as an individual, in today’s society, it’s so hard to be able to make people hear my story; I am often afraid of being judged and made fun of, I have often packed all of my feelings away or felt like I didn’t matter– but as soon as I am allowed to dance, all of that changes, I become unafraid of showing my imperfections, of being myself and letting people see who I really am. 

What CAPA offers me -

Commenced in 2005, the CAPA full time course in Contemporary Dance and Theatre Studies prepares students to cope with all aspects of the professional world, both physically and mentally, but above all, manages to maintain a standard of excellence second to no other institution in South Africa.

Students on this program have the added benefit of working with guest artists from the industry on a regular basis.
Graduates of this school are currently working most successfully in the industry both nationally and internationally.

This course is designed as a post-matric education program of study in Dance, Voice Training, Drama, Musical Theatre Studies and other practical, and academic subjects, pertinent to the development of the professional performing artist. 

The South African theatre industry has undergone significant positive development in the past 7 years, and CAPA has developed this course in keeping with the needs of the dance and theatre industry as a whole.


My journey so far -

 I started my journey in dance, when I was nine years of age. Since the start of my journey, nothing has ever been easy; I’ve quite often had to work to pay for some of my classes and there were many times that my parents weren’t even sure if they would be able to pay for my classes—but they have always, without fail, managed to come up with the money.  I know that my parents would do anything to make sure that I go to CAPA; but coming from a family of eight, I’m not their only priority and it would set them very far back, in order to send me to there.

I have been dancing for seven years; in that amount of time, I’ve worked for many hours, dancing and trying to improve myself—whether it was at the studio, or at home. The things that I have achieved in the amount of time that I’ve been dancing, are an indication of my hard work and determination. When it comes to exams, eisteddfods and competitions, I have never achieved less than 80%; and in the last two years, I haven’t gotten below 90%.


What I need -

By helping me, you're helping to sculpture an individuals life, helping to make my story be heard, but best of all, letting my dreams come true. Any small amount is much appreciated, even if it is just one dollar, it will make all the difference.  Anything that you will do, will be very much appreciated. Anything that you will do, will be very much appreciated.

Tuition fees for the year - R58,000

Traveling costs for the year, costumes and extras -  R12,000


The impact -

I hope, that if I manage to get funding, I can start helping others change their lives and make our community a better place—the difference starts with you though.

“DANCING, IT’S LIKE DREAMING WITH YOUR FEET.”

story:
Have you ever wanted to be inside "a horizontal field of deep intersubjectivity"?*

SUPER|object is a curated, immersive evening of art in two parts: a) a series of new performance works, and b) a celebratory experience for artists, spectators, and curators to gather, connect, and creatively cross-pollinate. A call for artists is out now! Go here for more information:

Emerging artists in Philadelphia need spaces to create and build community. Community in turn creates stronger artwork. Prior to the event, there will be a rehearsal/skillshare evening for participating artists, emphasizing process and critique. We want to bridge the gap between established performing artists who are connected with large arts institutions, and early career artists who are still searching for mentorship. SUPER|object seeks to do this by offering a space for emerging artists to rehearse, dialogue, and network.

SUPER|object is a “space without a place”: although we aim to create a home for emerging artists, we are not tied down to one physical location. Our goal is to completely transform the space that we land in, in order to create an immersive evening that stimulates all the senses. In order to do this, we need your support!! Here is our budget:

$400 for space rental
$50 for promotional materials
$200 for installation supplies
$200 for artist stipends

We look forward to seeing you in the SUPER|object.


*what does this mean? Check out: https://vimeo.com/105294432

story:
WedRepCo is a dynamic group of NYC-based actors, writers, producers and director dedicated to exploring the role and limits of narrative theater in today's society.

Since 2010, WedRepCo has introduced over 50 new plays to the New York theater scene. With MEET PREY LOVE we look forward to continuing our mission.

To accomplish this, we ask assistance from you – our audience. It takes so little to support our efforts, and in return, we promise to continue to entertain you, challenge you, and experience, with you, the joy of contemporary theater!

To accomplish this, we ask assistance from you – our audience. It takes so little to support our efforts, and in return, we promise to continue to entertain you, challenge you, and experience, with you, the joy of contemporary theater!

story:
Who we are: 

We are a a newly emerging theatre company (founded by a British Australian – Bj McNeill and a Pole - Nastazja Somers) born from the need to create contemporary, challenging and political work and to bring theatre back to the people. We met during our training at drama school and discovered that, despite being from opposite sides of the world, we share the same values and ideas when it comes to creating theatre and this is how No Offence Theatre was born! 

We want to work against the current trend that theatre and art in general is becoming an elitist industry, and create theatre for all people no matter who they are or where they are from. Whether our work is liked by many, few or none; we want to create for everyone. 

As artists we do not believe that the objective of theatre, or any form of art, should be solely entertainment. We do not believe in theatre that exists only to entertain people, and too often entertains only those select few that can afford it. We feel that creatives should be responsible for exploring all types of issues and problems surrounding humanity and the world we live in. We strive to create unconventional, raw and truthful work that will both challenge people emotionally and make them question the status quo. 

This Project... 

This project is particularly important to us as it is not only the debut play by Bj but also because it is our first project as a theatre company so it is our first offering to society as artists under No Offence Theatre. Our reputation relies on the journey of this play being a successful one. (Check out our video for what Torn Apart is about!!)

What you help us achieve.. 

Although it sounds idealistic, we do believe that theatre can change the world and instigate positive shifts in society. Even if it is just one person in the audience during one show that takes a message away that promotes equality, awareness or understanding about humanity it means we are doing our job right!

If we can finance our project we will be able to propel "Torn Apart" further to reach a greater audience and have a better chance of achieving our dream of effectively instigating positive change in society. 


What We Need & What You Get 

Unfortunately nowadays our artistic freedom is often tested by the reality of living in a capitalistic world. As a new company we stand no chance in getting government funding, hence we rely solely on the kindness of strangers and our own pockets (and there isn’t much in them). We are aiming to raise £3000. To cover the costs of the following...




    We managed to achieve a 3 show preview for Torn Apart at Theatre N16 in Balham, London on the 29 & 30th of November. This opportunity was in part possible due to us having a fundraising event (we raised £1200) to cover our costs. If we can raise £3000 we will be able to give our audience a longer run and in the most professional way possible. 

    If we don’t reach our goal we will make the most out of the situation. We will still put the show on (it might just take us a little longer to get there!) possibly by organising another fundraising event and getting a few more shifts in our restaurant and office jobs. Whatever situation we end up in financially, we will continue to work creatively, we will always pay our actors and anyone else who is involved in this production, by doing so we put money back into the arts! 

    To put in short: If we get this £3000 we will be able to share a show that is honest, political, thought provoking and comes from a place of thorough process that consists of freedom and experimentation.

    The Impact

    As the newly elected leader of the Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn said “The arts must never be the preserve of those with privilege but open to all”.

    We could not agree more with this statement. Art is one of the most important facets for humanity. Over the last couple of years the art industry in the UK has suffered immensely from all the cuts implemented by the Tory Government. People from less privileged backgrounds are often completely shut out from the world of theatre, as it is something beyond their financial reach. We do not agree with this and it makes us want to change things. We want to create for EVERYONE! Theatre is about change and looking at its history we can really see that!

    This is why supporting companies like ours, companies that start from absolute scratch and have nothing, but passion and dedication, is so vital to the society we live in. After all theatre is about truth, so why should anyone be deprived of the right to explore it?


    Risks & Challenges

    We are trying to work within a process that is not the norm in the London theatre scene. We are both 'continental' when it comes to how we approach rehearsal process, as we believe it should be longer than the norm. Unfortunately more rehearsal time means more money, which of course is an extreme challenge, but it also means richer more thoughtful art.  Our impetus to have a longer process comes from the need to explore and not be restricted in our explorations. 

    Since "Torn Apart" is our first project for No Offence Theatre, our reputation relies on the success of this piece.
    The reality is that starting a theatre company in London is extremely difficult, mainly due to the competitiveness and a huge lack of funding for companies like ours. We know that we will never stop creating, but at the same time we more than expect to come across a lot of challenges on our way; challenges that could hold us back.

    There are hundreds of companies and productions in London that disappear into the abyss of theatre, remain unseen and often unfinished due to the lack of funding and the costs of living in this ridiculously overpriced city. These companies and productions often generate incredible and moving work, but stand less of a chance in succeeding when in competition with commercial art ,that most of the time takes precedence over them. However we believe in our company and its mission and we would appreciate if you did too, by helping us you can allow us ingrain more determination and passion in our work.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute financially, please help us by posting our video and link to our Indiegogo campaign on your social media such as Facebook and Twitter! 

    Please follow us on Twitter @NOffenceTheatre and like us on Facebook : No Offence Theatre.

    We are relatively new to this industry, so if you wish, you could offer us a word of advice or if you would like to help us in some other way, please feel free to contact us!

    Also please support us by coming to see our 3 show preview @ Theatre N16 at the Bedford in Balham.  Dates are the 29th & 30th of November. We would love to have your support and share our work with you in the flesh!

Even if it is just one person in the audience during one show that takes a message away that promotes equality, awareness or understanding about humanity it means we are doing our job right!
If we can finance our project we will be able to propel "Torn Apart" further to reach a greater audience and have a better chance of achieving our dream of effectively instigating positive change in society. 
   What We Need & What You Get 
Unfortunately
nowadays our artistic freedom is often tested by the reality of living in a
capitalistic world. As a new company we stand no chance in getting government funding, hence we rely solely on the kindness of strangers and our
own pockets (and there isn’t much in them). We are aiming to raise £3000. To cover the costs of the following...







We managed to achieve a 3 show preview for Torn Apart at Theatre N16 in Balham, London on the 29 & 30th
of November. This opportunity
was in part possible due to us having a fundraising event (we raised £1200) to cover our costs. If we can raise £3000 we will be able to give our audience a longer run and in the most professional way possible. 
If we don’t reach our goal we will make the most out of the situation. We will still put the show on (it might just take us a little longer to get there!) possibly by organising another fundraising event and getting a few more shifts in our restaurant and office jobs. Whatever situation we end up in financially, we will continue to work creatively, we will always pay our actors and anyone else who is involved in
this production, by doing so we put money back into the arts! 


To put in short: If we get this £3000 we will be able to share a show that is honest, political, thought provoking and comes from a place of thorough process that consists of freedom and experimentation. 

  The Impact

As the newly elected leader of the Labour Party
Jeremy Corbyn said “The arts must never be the preserve of those with privilege
but open to all”. 
We could not agree more with this statement. Art is
one of the most important facets for humanity. Over the last couple of years
the art industry in the UK has suffered immensely from all the cuts implemented
by the Tory Government. People from less privileged backgrounds are often
completely shut out from the world of theatre, as it is something beyond their
financial reach. We do not agree with this and it makes us want to change
things. We want to create for EVERYONE! Theatre is about change and looking at
its history we can really see that!
This is why supporting companies like ours,
companies that start from absolute scratch and have nothing, but passion and
dedication, is so vital to the society we live in. After all theatre is about truth, so why should anyone be deprived of the right to explore it?

   Risks & Challenges
We are trying to work within a process that is not the norm in the London theatre scene. We are both 'continental' when it comes to how we approach rehearsal process, as we believe it should be longer than the norm. Unfortunately more rehearsal time means
more money, which of course is an extreme challenge, but it also means richer more thoughtful art.  Our impetus to have a longer process comes from the need to explore and not be restricted in our explorations.  Since "Torn Apart" is our first project for No Offence Theatre, our reputation relies on the success of this piece. 

The reality is that starting a theatre company in London is extremely difficult, mainly due to the competitiveness and a huge lack of funding for companies like ours. We know that we will never stop creating, but at the same time we more than expect to come across a lot of challenges on our way; challenges that could hold us back. There are hundreds of companies and productions in London that disappear into the abyss of theatre, remain unseen and often unfinished due to the lack of funding and the costs of living in this ridiculously overpriced city. These companies and productions often generate incredible and moving work, but stand less of a chance in succeeding when in competition with commercial art ,that most of the time takes precedence over them. However we believe in our company and its mission and we would appreciate if you did too, by helping us you can allow us ingrain more determination and passion in our work.


   Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute financially, please help us by posting our video and link to our Indiegogo campaign on your social media such as Facebook and Twitter! Please follow us on Twitter @NOffenceTheatre and like us on Facebook : No Offence Theatre.We are relatively new to this industry, so if you wish, you could offer us a word of advice or if you would like to help us in some other way, please feel free to contact us!Also please support us by coming to see our 3 show preview @ Theatre N16 at the Bedford in Balham.  Dates are the 29th & 30th of November. We would love to have your support and share our work with you in the flesh!

story:
Our Story

Theatrum Elysium, the La Crescenta Valleyï¿½s newest performing arts organization, offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovationï¿½from every background and medium, Theatrum Elysium strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us.

True to its name, Theatrum Elysium is an artistic paradiseï¿½a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, Theatrum Elysium is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We at Theatrum Elysium are committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

The Production

This spring Theatrum Elysium invites audiences to delve into the silly side of sadness, presenting Sara Ruhlï¿½s thought provoking comedy, Melancholy Play. Following the strange adventures of Tillyï¿½a dispirited everywomanï¿½and her friends, through her dabbling in psychoanalysis, to her overnight self-realization, to her ultimate transcendent enlightenment, Melancholy Play, hilariously holds the mirror up, offering each of us an opportunity to reimagine our own journey toward happiness and the people and places along the way.

 

Set in an altered universe complete with twins separated at birth, an abstract expressionistic landscape and one dramatic almondï¿½Melancholy Play promises to challenge our perceptions of our Prozac nation and to explore the social niceties that define our mental health, all while never forgetting that laughter is indeed the best medicine.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on Theatrum Elysium's Melancholy Play - opening May 3rd, 2012!

 

The Goal: $500 for the show's production budget and marketing efforts!

 

Theatrum Elysium is giving all supporters of our inaugural production a Supporting Cast, Producer or Executive Producer credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person ï¿½ no matter their talents ï¿½ can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream ï¿½ that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone! I'm Maria Riboli(www.mariariboli.com), the director an co-producer of the gripping drama "Family of strangers" written and produced by John Pastore. I am extremely passionate about this beautiful theater piece!

There is nothing more thrilling than being able to bring experiences and relationships to life through theater.

"Family of strangers" has all of that and MORE!

I have over 30 years of theater experience in New York, Italy, England, France and I’m pouring my heart into making this powerful drama into a memorable theater production in the heart of the Theater District in NYC!

We need your help in bringing this amazing story to life! I am not backed by any company or theater and we are putting this show up from scratch!!

Any contribution from you will help us to fund this project. $1, $5, $10 or $50 will be helpful! Anything is appreciated and accepted. Please help us to bring this show to LIFE! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $6,000 for this show and we know that with your help we can DO IT! We can all be a part of creating magic on stage! 

The money will go to paying for: Theater space in the heart of the Theater District in NYC (Stage II at Roy Arias Studios and Theaters 300 West 43rd Street NY), rehearsal space for our amazing actors, the costumes and the set for "Family of Strangers", and advertising! This is a non-paid gig for all of the actors and the crew but if we can fund all of these things, with your help, then I would LOVE to give our cast & crew something for all of their hard work and passion! 

AND there are some perks for you, the contributor! Check out our perks section to see how you can get a shout out on our FACEBOOK page (www.facebook.com/FamilyOfStrangerThePlay), a signed "Family of Strangers" poster from the cast and crew, your name on our website (www.family-of-strangers.com ), or free tickets to the show!! 

If we do not reach our goal the money we raise will still go to funding for Theater space, rehearsal space and the costumes/set for the show. But I am confident that we will reach our goal with your help! 

 

The Impact

"The truth doesn't always set you free!"

 

A desperate desire to learn the truth about a tragic and traumatizing childhood event drives siblings Evan and Jessica to clash while their last parent lays on his death bed.

Jessica’s emotional roadblock continually prevents Evan from regaining his sanity which he is convinced can be returned to him by revealing this childhood secret from his father before he dies.

Will the revelation and truth from this traumatic childhood event bring peace and sanity to Evan like he hopes? Or is it best to keep some things hidden forever?  Time is the enemy, as the two siblings want vastly different outcomes from this life - changing situation.

Writer John Pastore teams up with Italian born director Maria Riboli to bring New York City a tale of family secrets and emotional rollercoasters with this gripping play. This spring, the clashing, secrets and dynamics of family life will be brought to life with an amazing and versatile cast at the Roy Arias Studios and Theaters in March of 2013.

No family is free of secrets, shame or lies. Will the truth of past events bring peace to this family or catapult them into a world they were not prepared to enter?

 

It is just like looking into someone's window during their most dramatic moments in their family life!

I've been in this business since I was 6 years old! I've acted and directed in Italy, Paris, London and of course NYC where I also teach acting at my own acting studio (www.mariariboliactingstudio.com)

I was the executive producer, co-director and female lead in the theater production of "BAAAHHH!!!" which was accepted at the 2007 Fringe Festival, and then we extended the show for a full sold out month at the Payan Theater at The Roy Arias Studios & Theaters, and taken to London! This, amongst many other theater productions, Broadway readings, voiceover projects for Verizon, Rosetta Stone, Barilla and now being the spokesperson and Director of Beauty and Wellness for Borghese on NBC Shopping Network, has given me amazing experience in how to bring things to LIFE! 

My latest production was “Want & Need” (www.want-need.com). I was the producer, director and female lead in the play. We had an amazing sold out run in November in the heart of the theater district in NYC! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are hard and we know that everyone cannot contribute financially. PLEASE help us to spread the word about the show and this fundraiser!

Share the link to this fundraiser with all your friends and family!

Don't forget to visit our site and LIKE our FACEBOOK PAGE! =)

www.facebook.com/FamilyOfStrangersThePlay

www.family-of-strangers.com

 

The mystery begins February 27th @ 7:00 pm (Preview)

February 28th @ 7:00 pm (Preview)

March 1st @ 8:00 pm (Opening Night)

March 2nd @ 8:00 pm

March 3rd @ 3:30 pm

March 6th @ 7:00 pm

March 7th @ 7:00 pm

March 8th @ 8:00 pm

March 9th @ 8:00 pm

March 10th @ 3:30 pm

March 13th @ 7:00 pm

March 14th @ 7:00 pm

March 15th @ 8:00 pm

March 16th @ 8:00 pm

At Stage II at Roy Arias Studios and Theaters

300 West 43rd Street, New York, NY 10036

 

For Tickets please visit www.smarttix.com (search "Family Of Strangers")

story:
Who Is "The House Theatre of Chicago?"

The House is an award-winning theatre company devoted to the development and production of original theatre by daring and innovative artists. Founded ten years ago by a group of close friends, The House fuses Movement, Music, Magic, Combat, Dance and Spectacle to ignite the audience’s imagination and put the impossible on stage. 


It is the mission of The House to unite Chicago in the spirit of Community through Amazing Feats of Storytelling.


The Story

The House’s fantastical re-imagining of this holiday classic centers on Clara’s journey to save her family from the Rat King before Christmas, with the help of a Nutcracker, a gift from her beloved Uncle Drosselmeyer. What unfolds is an epic holiday story that weaves riveting dialogue, astonishing puppetry, beautiful song and spellbinding spectacle together into a darkly moving story of magic and mystery.


The Nutcracker is an adaptation of the original tale by E.T.A. Hoffman, written by House Company Members Jake Minton and Phillip Klapperich, with an original score by composer and House Company Member Kevin O’Donnell, and directed and choreographed by Company Member Tommy Rapley. 


What We Need & What You Get

The House wants you to invest in our effort to brighten the holidays for everyone. In addition to helping make the show better and braver and more magical than ever, you're gift will enable us to open our doors to more non-profits that serve kids and families in need through our On The House program. On The House offers free transportation (in an awesome Trolley bus!), admission to the performance, and post-show cookies with the cast. Holiday magic? You can give it!


Your investment at any level will help us maximize our own charitable efforts and make The Nutcracker's magic grow stronger. With your generosity, The House will be able to spread holiday joy to audiences who need it the most. 


Spread the Word!

If you’ve already invested (thank you!) or are unable to do so right now, there are still other ways to pitch in! Click on any of the sharing options at the bottom of the page and spread the word! 


And most of all, we hope to see you at the Chopin Theatre November 13 - December 30 for The Nutcracker. Thanks!

story:
Small Pond Entertainment and Band of Gypsies present: Band of Gypsies 2: Music and Dance!

In this unique new program, based off of the Small Pond Musical Theater Writing Lab format, choreographers and composers were paired to create original dance scenes. And the best part? The show benefits Drea's Dream, a foundation that helps children with cancer through the power of dance and expression. You can help make those dreams come true by sponsoring this collaboration. We've started a campaign to recognize those generous donors who help make the Band of Gypsies 2 both a successful artistic and philanthropic endeavor. Our goal is $7,000. How much can you support us?

See the video from the first Band of Gypsies to see what we're about!
